reviewText:
I feel the need to make an actual review for this game, because too many positive reviews for it are just memes and can be overshadowed by the more comprehensive negative reviews.

Hotline Miami can be tough to talk about, because Hotline Miami 1 was such a hit that this game will always be compared to it based on HM1's merits alone. The original game was about a masked serial killer who got mysterious phone calls threatening him into carrying out hits on mob locations. The whole story was pretty strange and trippy, with very little being what it seems. The gameplay was super fast and hectic as you ran around scavenging whatever you could find to beat the brains out of the army of mafia waiting in the buildings. The combat was close quarters-oriented with some enemies with guns, but mostly melee focused. Each mask had different abilities that affected your starting weapon, or gave you abilities like killing punches or spawning more guns as random pickups. All in all, it was a fairly good game with all of this.

The reason why I didn't really like Hotline Miami 1 was because the AI was actually fairly buggy and reacted either very sluggishly or hyper-quickly, without reason. The level design was very tight, and due to the ridiculous speed of everything, it felt too hard to control. I would finish a level and feel like I'd gotten lucky.

Hotline Miami 2 managed to fix a fair amount of the problems with the first. The combat is slowed down somewhat. Guns  fire slower, melee weapons swing slower, and the level design is more open, allowing some more freedom of movement (the combo meter also lasts longer naturally). The result, in my opinion, is that the gameplay feels much more tight and controlled. The weapons swings feel like they have more weight to them, guns kill much more effectively, and the levels feel less restrictive. However, I've seen a lot of people say that they felt the opposite, and that they were driven more towards using guns because there are more enemies with guns, so melee is now useless. In the same vein, people hated the more open maps because they felt that there was a tendency to get shot from off-screen by an unseen enemy, or through glass.

I would say that Hotline Miami 2 is somewhat less casual than the first, which is why I think so many people feel that it's too hard. I bought both games together, and after I finished 1 I jumped straight into 2. The difficulty spike is noticable; it's been stated by the developers that it was primarily geared towards players who'd played the first game and knew how it worked. That being said, I didn't find it too hard to get into the groove of Hotline Miami 2. I died a ton at the start, and really all the way throughout, but it never felt like I had died due to BS game design, but rather my own mistakes or miscalculations. I think HM2 is meant to be played with a bit more planning in mind. You can rush in and fight, but it doesn't usually go well. However, it's also not like you need to plan your every move. You just need to observe enough that you know what you're about to get into. From there, it gets much easier. I said earlier that I felt like I'd gotten lucky when I'd finished a level in HM1. In HM2, I had felt quite the opposite. In each level, once I knew what I needed to do, I felt like I was much more in control. I finished levels and felt satisfied, without the tinge of anger or the I just got lucky that time" feeling.

As for the gameplay problems: There are definitely more guns

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is closer to the last levels of the first game (Biker) than the rest of Hotline Miami (Jacket and all his masks), and thus feels like a direct continuation rather than just a new coat of paint. This opinion might seem a bit obtuse now, but I will explain later on why it is an important distinction.

So, why is it a continuation rather than a new take?

Well, at first, the difficulty is brutal right off the bat. This game is aimed at people who already played Hotline Miami 1 and are familiar with the concept of its ultra-violent twitch gameplay associated with tight level design forcing the players to plan their route according to the situations.

And then, the playable characters are mostly forced, just like Biker was, and they have an equally narrow skillset. Biker had a hatchet and three knives to throw but could not pick up weapons? Tony from Hotline Miami 2 has his insta-kill fists but is unable to pick up weapons.

The game moved on from the freedom of choice offered in the majority of Hotline Miami 1, and forces a more controlled experience. This idea goes further, as a lot of levels are designed so tightly that the chaotic action of Hotline Miami 1 has been replaced by puzzles with barely more than one way to solve them.

Moreover, the gameplay is overall less rough around the edges, with more solid surfaces that block bullets, and most especially a seemingly slower speed, I feel more like I have to anticipate every movement rather than play on the fly and let my instincts and skills take over. More 'slow', less 'flow'.

So here I come to the point that I made at the start: Hotline Miami 2 feels like a more controlled experience as a direct continuation to the Biker levels, rather than the early levels with their chaotic sandbox design that allowed for a much wider variety of approaches.

However, enough Hotline Miami 2 levels are not so tight and can offer variety, and  a lot of missions offer a choice between different characters or weapons. So the game still does a good job at offering variety. My observation is just that the variety feels forced, rather than the sweet spot and perfect flow that I felt Hotline Miami 1 achieved.

Hotline Miami 2 is more polished that the first one. Way more polished. The levels, atmosphere, sounds/music and storylines have all been crafted with great attention to details and take the player on several journeys that make this sequel well worth playing. The game definitively feels fresh and ambitious rather than 'more of the same', and its controlled chaos makes the first Hotline Miami still relevant with its less polished but more chaotic and free ultra-violence.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is neither a step forward or a step back when compared to its legendary original. It is in some ways better than the first and in some ways worse. It is really up to the player to determine if it is as up to par or even better than the first. I'll sum it up quickly in a PROS and CONS list.

PROS

- Amazing soundtrack as usual. Not as iconic as the first but definitely more versatile.
- Slick retro graphics that are slightly improved and more vivid than the first. Soldier's missions also throw in a more hazy variety. And the last level...prepare yourself.
- Cleverly written and delivered story that isn't shoved down your throat. In some ways it is open to interpretation, but it is more focused and clear than the original's narrative.
- Interesting and engaging characters...whether you hate them or not (screw Manny Pardo though. You'll know why once you play the game).
- Core gameplay itself is as slick as ever. Nothing new as the system was good to begin with.
- Upcoming level editor for near endless replayability and experimentation.
- GOTTA GET A GRIP!

CONS
- Some levels have very annoying level design with an abundance of windows. Level design is NOT the same as Hotline Miami. It is one of the key break-offs and differences actually. Maps are significantly bigger and that is bittersweet. You will die a lot more times by a goon with a gun off-screen that you couldn't see. This may also be because of slightly smarter AI and I believe field of vision.
- Lackluster hard mode. The hard mode is filled with artificial difficulty to the point where it could be viewed as unfair. With the already larger maps, adding in even more windows is frustrating.
- Smooth gameplay experienced from the first can be notably delayed and interrupted because of the level design/hard mode (or both) in some levels.

NEUTRAL
- No more iconic mask catalog like you oh so loved in the first game. Instead, you have different characters with different abilities and playstyles depending on the chapter you are playing. The Fans are a group that have masks that each have their own unique ability, such as dual submachine guns, combat roll, or Tony's lethal punches. There's also the budget Batman known as The Writer, and The Soldier, who permanently wields a gun that can have refillable ammo on drops and a combat knife. These characters change how you play the game completely, instead of just perks like the masks in the first game. However, it really depends on what you like. The game is different because of this.


Overall, I personally loved this game. It is one of my favorites, period. I can't decide if I like it more than the first, but I'm definitely pouring more hours into it. I don't believe it SHOULD be compared to the first, but obviously that's inevitable seeing how legendary the first installment is. If you are a fan of the series, I definitely recommend this game. If you liked the first purely for the gameplay, you may be disappointed here as it is different in many ways.

9/10

reviewText:
I'd like to preface this review with a warning to anyone who hasn't played the first Hotline Miami: play that one first. Hotline Miami 2's story and difficulty assumes you've done so. There are other, more critical reasons as well, but I'll touch on that later. This review will be written with those who have played it in mind, but there will be no spoilers for either game.

IntroHoly heck, it's finally here! After two long years and much angst, Hotline Miami 2 is finally on Steam, with new characters, levels, and more groovy tunes than you can shake a bloodied bat at. There's also a semblance of story this time, which is both exciting and slightly worrying: after all, wasn't part of the fun of the first game putting the soggy cardboard puzzle peices together? After about 10 hours marathoning through it all, I'm ready to give the verdict on whether or not Hotline Miami 2 is a worthy successor to the original cult classic.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is the hugely anticipated sequel to Hotline Miami, a brutal, top-down, fast paced action game. In Hotline Miami 2 you play as a number of different characters who basicaly kill people for fun, they aren't the nicest people in case you hadn't guessed. There's a couple of familiar faces from the first game, such as Tony but most of the characters are new.

Sadly, for me at least, Hotline Miami 2 just does not deliver on what it could have been. It's a decent game but does not come close to how good the first game was.

As you know I had already posted a negative review of this but after playing it a little more I have decided to rewrite my review and change the recommendation.

+Same great pixel graphics
+Another outstanding soundtrack
+A number of very different characters each with their own style
+Most of the characters you play as are so called fans of the original crew which I thought added an interesting level of depth to the game world
+The same brutal gameplay we all know and love from the original
+More gore than you could ever dream of
+Can be played with KB&M or a controller
+A couple of new weapons which are fun to play with
+One of the characters can dual wield which is a hell of a lot of fun
+One of the characters is in fact two characters you play as simultaneously!

+/-More of a focus on firearms rather than melee weapons. Personally I don't like this since I much preferred melee in the first game but it really depends on what you like more
+/-Levels are far more open and are a lot bigger than in the first game. Personally I thought this slowed down the pace of the game and made it more difficult to know where enemies are but again it comes down to what you prefer
+/-You can now take a hit from some of the weapons without dying

-Far too many windows which leads to lots of cheap deaths
-The game's AI is pretty bad. The AI's reaction to what's going on is a considerable downgrade from the first game, I found myself being able to shoot in an adjacent room (with an open door or window) or sometimes even in the same room as enemy AI without them noticing me which is beyond ridiculous, it also means that you can no longer use gunfire to lure enemies closer to you for a melee kill
ariety when it comes to melee weapons, most of them have been removed and there are no unlocks
-No more human shields
-Enemies frequently get stuck on doors
-The level editor still isn't implemented in the game

Verdict:
6

Hotline Miami 2 is a decent game that captures the brutality of the first game well and gives us another great soundtrack, sadly it just isn't as good as the first game. I'd recommend getting it on sale unless you really cannot wait.

El K.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is the highly anticipated sequel to Hotline Miami (duh).  Hotline Miami (which from now on I will call hlm because thats easier to type out) is a crazy top down shooter with a super dope soundtrack. It's filled with violence and moments that leave you just in awe. HLM2 has lots positives and negatives and I feel that the easiest way for me to do this review is if I split this into a list of Pos/Negs and then give my final word on the game.

PositiveSoundtrack
The music in this game actually manages to improve on the first game's. The songs get you super pumped up and ready to blow heads off or get you feeling mellow and make you reflect upon the bloodbath you just caused. I really reccomend you buy the soundtrack here.
Weapon variety
There are a load of new guns and melees for you to try to murder someone with. The guns are a welcome change, the gun play is sorta refreshing now, because it feels like there is an actual variety in what gun to use.
Story
Some people may not like the story, but personally I really enjoyed the way that they did the story. There was backstory to HLM1 and it showed the world after the events of HLM1 too. I won't spoil anything but the ending is definitely going to annoy a lot of people but personally I thought it was a great way to end off the game.
NegativeLevel Design
You probably expected me to complain about this because frankly everyone has. The levels are way too big and open which would be only half as bad if the levels also werent littered with windows and it is very very annoying to get sniped from some butthead across the level.
Hide and Seek"
The game has basically become playing hide and seek in order to clear levels due to the size and windows leaving you out in the open and vulnerable to be shot by someone you cannot see.
Soldier levels
The soldier levels are honestly one of the most unfun levels in the game due to being limited to one gun and knife the whole time and having to refill your ammo only to get half the normal amount of ammo. It leads to you camping the nearest ammo bin and just luring people to you.
Hotline Miami 2 is a game for the diehard fans of the first game who want a conclusion to the story and are willing to deal with the new style of play in this game in order to recieve the conclusion they dearly wanted. If you're not a fan of 1 or don't really want to play the story I'd reccomend you stay away unless you're excited for the level editor that's soon coming and want to play community creations."

reviewText:
I loved Hotline Miami. Sadly, I just cannot recommend this one. It just doesn't have what made Hotline Miami fun to me.

What I loved about Hotline Miami was that each level was a bit like a puzzle. You worked your way through it, with each death teaching you something new until you found the optimal route through the level. The levels were often small and claustrophobic, with narrow corridors and many rooms. Melee was a very viable strategy as you could lure enemies through chokepoints. Hotline Miami 2 throws this all out in favor of big open levels that rely more on guns and often render melee unfeasible. I find myself moving slowly through levels, hiding behind walls while waiting for enemies to come into range of my gun so I can safely dispatch them. I am often killed by off-screen enemies who I cannot even see when using Shift to extend my view range. Many deaths are a case of bad luck instead of a mistake on behalf of the player. Whereas my experience with Hotline Miami was fast and frantic, my experience with Hotline Miami 2 is slow and ponderous.

The final nail in the coffin for me is the technical issues. If I enable V-sync, I get mouse lag which often gets me killed as I cannot turn fast enough to kill enemies. If I disable V-sync, I get terrible screen tearing that makes the game unbearable to look at. If I try to play in Borderless Fullscreen mode, I have to put up with the mouse lag again.

Sad to say, as much as I loved the original Hotline Miami, I'm getting a refund on this one.

reviewText:
I recommend Hotline Miami 2. But let me start with the not so well executed parts of this game:

Space around alot of obstacles imply you could walk around them, but blocking your way with collision instead. Limited character selection in combination with the sometimes linear level design makes it frustrating to complete a stage, giving you less options to approach a level. While some characters and their abilities make it easy to go through a stage, some other loadouts can completely frustrate the player. Gladly there is a 'rewind' option.

On the other hand, the way they wrapped up the story expecially with the well selected soundtrack (once again) and the new character selection is top-notch. Makes you want to complete it twice because you didn't get the ending!

Some reviewers mind the look-further function which snaps weirdly. I agree, but must say: Use it wisely. No need to downgrade due to a minor detail that you can surely work-around to enjoy the game.

They added a new snap function, which allows you to snap to enemies even if they are not inside your field of view. In addition I also enjoy the ability to sort of explore the character by finding out what his or her secondary ability is and how to play the character in the best possible way.

I'd also like to mention that small 'puzzle' elements, e.g. 'how do I get to this gun to kill these bodyguards?' are HIGHLY satisfying. Or picking up the only gun behind a door to mow down 7 mobsters who rush toward you shortly after. Another example is using a sniper rifle in an open level, which is amazingly satisfying as well and breaks the usual very hard gameplay up a little.

To sum up: Killing people is a simple job, but who said it will be easy? You will swear and cheer and retry. You will have your frustrating moments, and the AI is very unforgiving and fast. There is a harder difficulty as well for people who will actually see that murdering people isn't that bad.

Do I recommend it? Absolutely.

Oh, and around 50 songs used are in this game. Grab the soundtrack!

reviewText:
I can't really recommend this game without some caveats, but it is by no means a bad game. Your mileage may vary.
If there was shrug instead of a thumbs up/down I'd be using that.

The Good-Music
Still good, but doesn't loop in some situations, and in other cases is barely even there. Likely technical issues that may be patched in the future.

-Some gameplay decisions
I actually really liked how the developers used gameplay to characterize Evan, the writer. He isn't a psychopath or a killer like most of the player characters, as such will not kill enemies unless the player forces him to. Instead he will knock them out with blunt objects, unload firearms, and refuse to pick up knives. However, if the player executes two downed enemies he will fly into a rage and kill enemies violently. You get more points for neutralizing enemies non-lethally, likely because it is better for his mental health.
The player is still given the option to play how they want, but through gameplay it is readily apparent what Evan would prefer to do, and that is pretty neat.

-The VHS effects
are actually pretty convincing and well done. And I know how hard those are to do.

The Bad-Story
I personally felt that the story was worse, and will try to say why without spoiling too much.
I felt that it takes itself too seriously, tries to explain too much of things that are irrelevant while glossing over things that would make the story a cohesive whole. The experiences of some characters are completely pointless from a story telling perspective, perhaps a casualty of having so many different playable characters. It also becomes apparent that it takes place in an alternate history, which I feel is a step down from first game being vague about the setting.
Also violates the rule of show don't tell" far too often.

-Level design
The first game encouraged recklessness
date: allowing the player to rely on reactions and instinct to get through levels. This was possible thanks to the tight and focused design of many of the stages
recommended: separated into small chunks. A player could reliably use walls and doors to their advantage
hoursPlayed: as very few areas were wide and open.\n\nHotline Miami 2 plays more like a top-down cover shooter. Single "floors" in this game can be the size of entire chapters from the first game
voteText: which severely punishes the reckless
helpfulPercent: instinctual gameplay style the first game was known for. Wide open areas
votesHelpful: windows everywhere
votesTotal: extremely long hallways
votesFunny: and way too many dudes with guns are the culprits here. As a result
commentsCount: players will move towards an extremely cautous playstyle
column16: advancing slowly and checking every angle constantly
column17: lest they lose five or even ten minutes of progress. This is much less interesting
column18: more frustrating
column19: and more importantly
column20:
much less fun.

-Glitches and AI
Enemies in the game act unpredictably
column21: some will run to the source of gunfire when they hear it
column22: others will stay still. Enemies will often melee you through walls
column23: or shoot you from offscreen
column24:
and get caught on geometry (most often doorways) vibrating rapidly and becoming invulnerable. The one AI partner in the game also has hideous pathfinding and gets stuck on doors often as well.
Hopefully these issues will be patched in the future.

In conclusion
column25: as someone who enjoyed the first game I find myself enjoying this game less. But as I said at the beginning
column26: your mileage may vary."

reviewText:
Let's face it, Hotline Miami 2 is not going to please everyone. In fact, it didn't please some of HM fans. However, I still recommend this game. Basically, it's sharing the same mechanics as Hotline Miami 1. It is still about ♥♥♥♥ing enemies up with that feeling of doing it flawlessly.

The levels changed a lot from Hotline Miami 1 when it comes to the size. Levels in general are just HUGE, which leads to this problem, the first time you'll play, you will die a lot by enemies off screen that you can't see even by Shift looking. The game is even harder than the first. I've seen lots of people complaining about the amount of windows, but that didn't bother me that much, overall I like the levels in this form,  they are designed well for the most part, and all of them have a route to run them and doing a great Rank.  Sadly, some of the object in game are not that well designed. Like the thing in Dead Ahead that looks like a turbine, engine, or whatever, you don't really know if it will block you or not. However, it's not happening too much on the levels.

Hotline Miami 2 tried to rebalance the weapons and the masks in general. Remember Tony and its completely OP mask in the first game? Forget it there, it was nerfed very baddly. You can just use your fist to kill, and the devs make you fight enemies in a level where you are forced to bait them because they have guns. A Biker set for Tony would have been nice, using throwing knives and then using your fist. The game is more oriented on using fire weapons, it nerfed the OP knife, and with how the levels are designed, you will use guns most of the time. Finally for the weapons, now all of the fire weapons are one shot, one kill, except for the fatties, which is a good thing.

Some new enemies are there, and they are fine, except the Grabbers that are just glitchy as hell grabbing you through walls! Talking about glitches, there are a few bugs that are annoying, like stucking yourself, being hit in a corner and you shouldn't be. When it comes to the masks you have WAY less choices, but let's face it, in the first HM, some of the masks were useless,

Story wise, the game answers a lot of things from the first game, but it's really a mess because of all those flashbacks etc. It was still entertaining to follow the story, especially with all those different characters.

Overall, I think you should get that game at some point, either at full price, or with a discount. It's an amazing game.

And ♥♥♥♥ you Tony.

reviewText:
[This review contains absolutely nothing close to spoilers - I say this for the sake of people like me, who absolutely hate having the things they love spoiled to any degree]

This is the first time I have felt so strongly about a game that I've actually been motivated to really review it in depth. I've been wanting to since around the fourth chapter, but I stuck around to the end to make sure what I had to say still remained valid, or if I was going to be proven wrong somehow.

I wasn't.

First off, I am an enormous fan of the first game. I've put 40-50 hours in on PC, and have beaten it on PC, PS3 and Vita [with the hidden ending on all three]. I love playing random games of it here and there. I'm decent at it - not great, but can usually get Bs and above on most maps.

I was thrilled when I saw that Hotline Miami 2 was coming out, and while I didn't get a chance to play it launch day, I was eager to the next day. The first few chapters were fun... but then it became glaringly obvious that not only was the narrative style different in this game [which I didn't mind at all and still think is interesting now that I'm done], but the mechanics were as well. Gone is the system of accumulating masks as you go, opening up playstyle [and replay style, playing late-game masks on early maps] - instead, the game features a large cast of playable characters, each with their own unlocks [or not]. While some of these are interesting, I feel that the restrictions this puts on gameplay hamper more than enhance. While this system of multiple characters is necessary for how the plot is delivered, it forces the player into certain playstyles / decisions depending on the map / character.

The other major mechanical change comes in the layout of the maps, and that most of them are - as other reviews have stated - entirely too filled with windows, or enormous open rooms / hallways. The original did have some instances of this, but for the most part HM1's maps were tight, lower-visibility rooms / halls which meant you were more free to be stealthy and enemies were restricted in their vision. This is not the case here - all too often during your first play through, you're going to find yourself sniped by an enemy nearly the entire screen away, which was able to see you due to the layout of the map or line of sight through a window. Eventually I just got used to this, but it was extremely frustrating. HM1 had a few maps where you'd get shot through a window you didn't know was there [until this happened], but it seemed very, very frequent in HM2.

Along with the above, I felt like a few times some maps were geared towards a specific plan as being the only way to beat the map. Maps which start you with a certain character, and in a certain place, where it seemed that unless you do X, then Y, then Z, you'll get killed every time. This is unfortunate, given the first game's freedom to clear maps in different ways, depending on mask choice and random weapon drops. Hard to discuss this without spoiling maps, but again it felt like there were a few situations that felt like I had very limited options.

Most of the time, though, my strategy for beating any given map was this:

1. Find a room with as few windows as possible, run to it praying I don't get killed
2. Pop around door to bring enemies running, or shoot a gun to bring them running
3. Kill them as they came through doorway [maybe]
4. Repeat until this doesn't work, then go clean up the rest

Many, many times for me, a given map would have enormous piles of dead bodies clustered near doors, because it was the least-frustrating way to beat the map.

And then there are the glitches - and this game has a lot of glitches. The worst for me tended to be the doors - enemies passing through doors, about 50% of the time, became invincible. This made it very difficult to spring out from beside a door and hit a dog / human coming through the door, because most of the time they'd be invincible. I'd miss, then they'd end up killing me. The glitch regarding enemies spinning in place, or spinning in doorways has been mentioned frequently. I noticed another glitch, which for all I know might be intentional and not a glitch at all, but in one of the early chapters my aiming crosshair seemed to move erratically - it didn't circle around my player like normal, it seemed to circle random parts of the screen around my character, and he stayed focused on it wherever I moved him. Eventually this stopped though, and I never saw it after, which again makes me wonder if it was some intentional, but annoying, quirk.

This game is also ludicrously, unneccessarily hard. Hotline Miami 1 was pretty hard, but it's what I'd consider Demon's Souls" hard - when I'd die

reviewText: Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number, seems like the perfect way a sequel should be executed. In theory. The game features significantly MORE of everything, there's larger maps, a considerably longer campaign, more playable characters, more missions, overall going with the assumption that Bigger=Better. This is generally true, as it is not a sequels job to evolve gameplay in significant ways, thats the job of new IP's. What a sequel is generally supposed to do, is take an already stellar concept, and add on to it, refine it, fine tune every small detail until it reaches the potential it always had. Wrong number does this in many ways, and for the most part does it beautifully. However, as I was about 2 hours in to wrong number, I noticed something that greatly concerned me. I had stopped playing it. The original Hotline is in my opinion perfect. Every single aspect of the game was executed flawlessly, the tone, the atmosphere, the soundtrack, the vague and ambiguous story, the incredible adrenaline rush as you murdered dozens of faceless mobsters for the thousandth time that level, and how you snap back into reality when the music stops, and you realize the horrific atrocities you've just committed. And then you do it again. Anyway, there was not a single time for my entire first playthrough of the original Hotline Miami where I stopped playing. Even though the game was, when you think about it, very repetitive, I was never bored. It concerned me when the sequel didn't have the same effect. Granted, it's considerably longer, but I don't think that's the only reason. I decided to delve deeper and try to find out what exactly went wrong in Hotline Miami 2. Let's start with the pros.\n\nThe story in Wrong Number was absolutely fantastic. It opted to drop the Vagueness of it's predecessor, to  great effect. Wrong Number tackles significantly bigger topics then HL before it, and ends up succeeding with flying colors. For the first few scenes, I was somewhat concerned that the story would be more convoluted than Season 6 of Lost, but as it progressed, I understood the tale the writers had in mind, and really enjoyed it. You play as a multitude of Protagonists" this time around

reviewText:
Get the first game instead.

While Hotline Miami 2 is quite fun and feels fresh, there is only a single winning strategy: peek out of a doorway or corner, and beat down the fifty enemies that come through. Rinse and repeat on the next corner you find. The maps are too open, and have WAY too many enemies in them. The first game was about overcoming challenges, the second one is about overcoming twenty challenges in a row, and failing one of them puts you back at the start. Generally not very fun.

They did fix the mouse controls pretty quickly, so that's no longer a negative point. They're perfect as it is now.

The level design is simply where this game falls flat. Someone put it in a rather eloquent way: some levels made me feel like I was playing a top-down version of Counter-Strike
recommended: just buy the first game instead. You won't miss anything
hoursPlayed: the story isn't nearly as good as the first one. The only thing that's still just as good as the first game

reviewText:
To avoid the impression that I see nothing good in Hotline Miami 2 let's go through the good things first:
+New masks!
+New weapons!
+Good soundtrack! (by saying good soundtrack, I mean there were few good tracks tossed in there)
+Alex and Ash! Oh.. okay - this one needs some more details. Alex and Ash is a mask choice that lets you play as 2 serial killers at once. One of them - Ash - has a chainsaw and another has a ranged weapon - any ranged weapon you can find on the ground or the standart pistol that Alex gets at the start of the level. Very fun character despite buggy A.I.. Sad thing is that you can't choose any mask for any level you want now - there are different timelines and different roles you must take, so no - you can't go Fists of Fury every single level. And oh yeah - some masks are very unique, but the total number of masks reduced when compared with the first game.

Now let's get to the truth which is difficult to accept - Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is very hard to recommend. Don't get me wrong - this game is not absolutely bad, but it's a sequel to the Hotline: Miami, and as such it's not very fun. Actually it's far from the original Hotline Miami. Developers tried to make this game more realistic and that created a lot of problems. Let's talk about them. Before I start ranting on the combat system, let me tell that this game isn't as fast as the first one. And pacing really kills that mad blood lust of running without any fear of death from the HM1, because sometimes you have to play boring characters in long cover based shootouts (levels with a detective character are especially guilty of this). Other thing I didn't like was the story. It's forgettable and quite frankly, very generic when compared to HM1's Acid-Hallucination-Trip with a talking rooster who knows more about what's going on here than you do".
Okay

reviewText:
This is probably the most regretful review I have to make since I'm a huge fan of the first Hotline Miami game and was really looking forward to playing this one. Unfortunately, while I blew through the first one and loved every minute, this sequel was disappointing and hard to fight through.

Firstly, the controls were sticky: I'd latch on to walls and get slaughtered, unable to move around the corner or turn enough to attack. Often the bullets would even pass through the enemy or the doors wouldn't register connecting with the enemy. In both cases, I was quickly killed and made to start over.

Second, the story was too jumbled. It was an absolute mess. I understand the idea of running multiple storylines and that storylines needn't always line up perfectly, but this wasn't a good way to do it. The stories would switch almost chapter after chapter and, while they might sync up, most times they clashed harshly. Further, the stories weren't that interesting. There was two that I enjoyed, but the others just seemed boring or pointless. In trying to use so many perspectives, the developers ended up muddying the story.

Finally, the level design is far poorer than the first game's. They gave big, open rooms and gave most enemies guns. Coupled with sticking to the walls, I was often the victim of ten simultaneous shotgun blasts painting the walls with my brain. This could just be my own poor skills, but it often turned the game away from the quick-paced gorefest of its predecessor and toward a strategy game where I waited behind walls for ambushes and lured enemies into choke points. I may love strategy games, but I don't play Hotline Miami to get my fix.

As a successor to the wonderful Hotline Miami, this is a poor one. It has much of the aesthetic feel of the original, which I adored, and the themes are both an expansion and faithful redesign of the orignal game's. However, the problems I stated previously ruin the otherwise good experience. If there is another sequel, I will still purhase it and play it through. However, after this, I might wait for the sale. Preferably, a big one.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page [ http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
It may seem strange that this is a positive review at first, but i just thought that i should list the negatives of the game at the beginning of the review:The game IS kinda' more difficult than the original, but.... It's not more difficult because of good design. A better word to describe it would be: Frustrating.
For the most part, the difficulty in Hotline Miami 2 comes from a very different place than in Hotline Miami 1. In HM1, the difficulty came from well-made levels and good design, but in HM2, the difficulty generally comes from bad controls, bugs, and horrible level design.
HM2 is a much more gun oriented duck and cover version of the original Hotline Miami. Melee is fairly useless in HM2 and you are punished for trying to use it instead of guns.
I have to say.... I was really disappointed in Hotline Miami 2 when i first played it. It seemed to be a huge let-down.
After i got over that, i tried it again and went much farther into the game.
My opinion has changed and i think i was too harsh on it: Hotline Miami 2 is worse than the original in many ways, but it is definitely its own game. It doesn't completely copy HM1 and it has a feel of its own. While i was disappointed in many ways and i still prefer the original, Hotline Miami 2 has many things that make it special and fun, as well.
The new characters are interesting and fun to use, and the music and art are still very good. I also really like the look of some of the new menu screens and such, like the pause screen and level select.

Overall, Hotline Miami 2 is not quite as good as the original, in my opinion, but that's all it is:
My opinion.
It is possible that many people will like Hotline Miami 2 MORE than the original, as it is just very different.

I would definitely not say Hotline Miami 2 is a bad game, but i would also not say that it completely succeeds as a sequel. That said, i think that every Hotline Miami fan should at least try the game to see if they like it because it's still a good game and brings many new things that the original did not have.

My rating for Hotline Miami 2 is:
7.5/10

reviewText:
The perfect example of why more =/= better in video games.

Where the first game was a tightly designed masterpiece this game is bloated and full of hundreds of little annoyances that really ruin an experience so reliant on repeatedly doing the same thing to win. Poor level design (♥♥♥♥ing windows), enemies shooting from off your screen, inconsistent AI reactions and patrols (normally a great feature in games but not here), randomised AI weapons and occasional glitches really ♥♥♥♥ing annoy you when they get you killed cheaply during an otherwise fine run. It's also much more likely to limit your options if you take the wrong weapon (i.e. not a gun) with you through to the next level's start and in general the game is a lot more limiting in terms of playstyles than the first.

Having larger levels hurts in general since you'll be losing more if you die and really just results in boredom. It also makes hunting down that one remaining enemy before your combo dies a common experience contributing to the 'only one right way to do a level' issue and the general slow feeling of the game. Indeed the first game's addictive and fast, brutal combat is now just a slow trial and error memorisation game where 1/10 tries will be ended by something largely outside of your control like the ai acting incorrectly. I'm all for difficult games but they need to be challenging, not frustrating.

Jumping between characters out of order might have made for unique storytelling but in terms of gameplay it's ♥♥♥♥ing annoying to swap from one set of abilities to another and back again repeatedly. Frankly the game also feels a little long in a bad way with lots of the earlier levels being quite samey. This isn't a huge issue, I suppose, and is probably better than it being too short but the game is still introducing new enemy types and characters with new gameplay styles (13 in total, not counting masks) in the 20th ♥♥♥♥ing level. Hard mode helps a little but isn't an option for your first time and makes the game even more frustrating by ♥♥♥♥ing with the level design and weapons.

On the subject of the story specifically it wasn't terrible by any means (other than the ending...) but it wasn't worth the effort of piecing together the timeline of the various levels. I personally preferred the original game's approach of limited exposition and showing over telling also. Here we just have a ♥♥♥♥ton of characters dumped into the game who are introduced and eventually dropped with no real purpose or overall plot. If we're going to have a story that so often gets in the way of gameplay and pacing it should at least be a ♥♥♥♥ing good one.

In theory there's more replayability here as not only can you try for top scores on each level but also play the game through again on hard mode and have a ♥♥♥♥ton of different playstyles available. In practice I doubt I'll bother playing it through more than once on each mode while I still play the original game through now and again after 100%ing it. Part of this stems from the problems with hard mode. While it's good that the developers didn't just throw more enemies in and call it a day there are cases where levels are nearly uncompleteable with the wrong weapon (and god help you if the RNG gives guards the wrong weapons too).

I'd probably still recommend picking it up cheaply and playing it through at least once and it certainly isn't all bad. There are few games of this style and fewer yet worth playing at all and had this game come before the first one I'd probably be a lot more impressed. The soundtrack is good and the art style is fine though one level at least is annoyingly dark to the degree of hurting gameplay (maybe an intentional choice but difficulty for the sake of difficulty is again a poor decision). The game just needed to be more focussed to be truly classic like the first.

reviewText:
Peh. So they turned a brilliant psycho rampage game into an annoying cover shooter.

The level designs feature too many windows and firearms, enemies constantly fire from outside your view and with the bigger maps restarting becomes more like a chore. All of this means you have to advance slowly and carefully, abusing the view distances and such. Gone are the days of improvised driller-killer rushes. There's less choice in picking masks before levels so don't expect as much freedom in your playstyle and weapon picks. On top of this, there are more enemies which are immune to certain weapons and they interrupt your flow as you have to backtrack to find the correct weapons to kill them. It's not a freeform killer puzzle anymore.

Even though the soundtrack is good, the gameplay just isn't fun enough. Just grab some Perturbator and Carpenter Brut albums and go replay the first one with those instead.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 has pretty much became my favorite game this year. The story, the characters, THE ♥♥♥♥IN AMAZING SOUNDTRACK, and the levels gives me the same enjoyment  I felt with Hotline Miami 1.

Unlike the first Hotline Miami the difficulty is a bit higher but it's so satisfying racking up a huge combo  and seeing the gore as you rip and tear through your enemies.

I say if you enjoyed the first Hotline Miami this one is totally worth your 15 bucks.(even more with the soon to be added level editor.) It's a perfect and bittersweet ending to such an amazing series.

10/10

reviewText:
Back when I first played Hotline Miami, I fell in love with it. The quick, versatile gameplay accompanied by an 80s style retro soundtrack was amazing and really complimented the game.  This isn't about the first Hotline, however, this is about the second. Hotline Miami 2 fails to live up to its predecessor; however, it does have some interesting features that makes it feel a bit more fun at times.
I’ll jump right into the pros, the soundtrack, for one, is amazing. Just like the first game, the soundtrack really drags you into the gameplay and just feels great. Whether you’re simply playing peek-a-boo with the enemies or running down a hallway guns blazing, the music blasting will certainly pump some blood in your veins.
The graphics, although very similar to the first game, have improved. It still has that arcade feel, but more refined. Along with that, the developers have really made the levels feel less bland overall. The detail in the game is immense and really adds to vibe of the game overall.
The last real good thing I can say is the different characters you can play as. Whereas Hotline 1 was restricted to just Jacket and Biker, there are so many other characters you can play in this one. Most of them have something that makes them different from the others, whether it’s rolling around or using two characters at the same time (my personal favorite.)
Unfortunately, there are only so many good things you can say about this game. One of the core elements of a video game is the gameplay itself. Hotline Miami 2’s gameplay is extremely disappointing. Hotline Miami 2 is centered around guns like crazy and it’s gets to a point where the whole game is frustrating in itself. Whereas Hotline Miami made guns an ineffective way to the finish the level, and even frowned upon at times, Hotline Miami 2’s levels have most if not all enemies wielding guns. Pair that up with terrible shooting controls and extremely open levels and you got a recipe for disaster.
Speaking of levels, the level design in terms of gameplay is far from great. The levels feel so big and open that it makes it very hard to spot enemies, forcing the game into a game of peek-a-boo and sometimes even blind shooting just to bring out enemies.
Honestly, I really want to like this game because there are so many fun things about it. But even then, the sheer gameplay and hollow story brings the game down. Hotline Miami was never meant to be a gun game with tedious levels and terrible design; it was meant to be fun arcade style mess-em-up with a vague, but compelling story. As much as I want to give this game a good rating, Hotline Miami 2 is ultimately a disappointment that doesn’t live up to its hype.

reviewText:
It's very hard for me to recommend Hotline Miami 2, at least until it's map editor releases.

The original Hotline Miami is one of my favorite indie games period. It featured fast paced and very violent gameplay that meshed very well with the game's atmosphere. It felt like a drug trip and the entire game felt like unleashing your aggression on the world.

Hotline Miami 2... is all over the place. Unlike the first game, where you mostly played as a single silent protagonist. In HLM2 you change perspectives to a different character basically every level. The problem with this lies in how this necessitated the removal of the mask system. Most of the levels in the game don't allow you to select between different masks. Only very occasionally letting you pick between a different weapon. Because of how often the game changes perspective I never understood what was happening in the storyline. It felt almost like it was intentionally designed to be nonsensical which really made me feel contempt for the whole thing.

This all would've been fine had it not been HLM2's biggest flaw, which is it's level design. In the original Hotline Miami there was a rhythm to the gameplay, and each level almost felt like a playground. It felt very spontanious and switching between the different masks made replaying a level feel very different every time.

HLM2 on the other hand features much larger maps. Because you usually can't pick a mask at the start, every level feels like it was designed to only have one playstyle in mind. You have to hold the shift key down at all times while playing to move the camera. This is because the game frequently features gun wielding enemies you can't see that instantly kill you. Along with hyper aware enemies behind glass walls that force you to move very slowly. It makes every level feel like trial and error and it makes the difficulty feel very unfair as a result. I don't like sections where I'm forced to use a gun to kill enemies that can't be damaged otherwise. It makes the game feel more repetative and less spontanious as a result.

I honestly don't think HLM2 is all that good. It feels like the developer didn't really have an idea for a sequel so he just phoned in most of it. I might recommend this game once it's map editor comes out but even then, it's vanilla campaign feels like a chore to play through compared to the original.

reviewText:
This has probably been said before, but everything about this game is amaaazziiiiinng.

The gameplay. It will be a challenge and it feels rewarding when you get a big combo or do something else that's awesome. EDIT: Oh, and killing people feels satisfying. Not in a crazy or sadistic sense...

The soundtrack. Hoolly ♥♥♥♥, it sounds fantastic. Fits the game well, too.

The variety. There are a lot more levels and you can play as multiple characters. One can dual wield SMGs, you can be mother♥♥♥♥ing Rambo with a machine gun and knife, a pacifist writer who you can turn into a murderer, or  a god damn gang leader high on drugs.

The replay value. Of course this doesn't apply to everyone, but there are achievements you can hunt for, a hard mode to complete, and the upcoming level editor that has support for the Steam Workshop.

EDIT 2: Sorry for another edit, but I wanted to say that Dennaton have really nailed the visuals of the game and there is a good amount of story in this game.

Oh, and there are Payday 2 things included, so that's a plus.

td;dr - It's worth the $15/$20 dollars.

reviewText:
An overly violent top-down shooter which focuses on the player's fast reflexes, strategy and how they can adapt to unexpected changes...
The first Hotline Miami was the first game in years to make me pull an all-nighter out of me. reviewText:
After one of the most surprisingly entertaining indie titles Ive ever played (HM1), this sequel had a ton to live up to. It succeeded in some ways, not so much in others.

Cons:
- A crosseyed inducing storyline. While not complex, the bouncing around from different char to different timeline back and forth, zig zagging.... wasnt needed. The story was nothing special, and this style of telling didnt cover that up.
- Technical issues (hopefully will improve with time), being able to fall out of the level/screen, NPCs getting stuck (typically around doorways)
- A general feeling of things being overproduced
- No real improvement to general AI
- Random parts of story telling being interactive completely unnecessary

Pros:
- Longer. A few more levels, but the levels themselves are significantly larger
- Some new additions to weaponry or how its used provides some (slightly) more varied gameplay
- Some great new tracks
- Game plus mode for better replay value
- An editor (not incl yet), should extend the lifespan
- Its still Hotline Miami!

reviewText: Recklessness is NOT rewarded, and I feel the game suffers greatly for it. Prepare yourself for an extended, Hotline Miami-themed cover-based shooter. You are forced to use guns in many of the levels, even though the scoring system still only gives you half the points for firearm kills. Levels are often overly long with lots of open space and way too many gun-toting or melee-proof hostiles to get creative. Pressing R to Restart has never been a more painful experience. This not to say there aren't some great moments in the game that recapture the magic of the original, but they're fleeting. A far as art style and music go, HLM2 is effortlessly cool with an OST well worth picking up on Steam. However, on the merits of gameplay, I can only recommend this to fans of the original.

reviewText:
The storytelling in this game is fun, I especially liked the way the mechanics change when you're playing the nonmurderous writer guy. The masks are much improved, rather than giving little stat boosts they significantly alter the playstyle; the coolest one being the mask that makes you into two people.

However... they made guns useful for more than throwing at people in the worst way possible. All the maps are vast and spacious, to the extent that you typically can't see the other end of a hallway if you try to look. This means that you need guns to clear out areas blindly, and means that fighting people who have guns when you have a melee weapon now primarily consists of baiting them and waiting for them to chase you rather than the first game's well-timed bloodthirsty charges.

I don't hate this game, but unlike the first one I don't feel eager to go back and try for better scores on the levels.
voteText: 41 of 63 people (65%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Overall, it pales in comparison to the first game.

Hotline Miami mostly took place in tight corridors and was focused on melee combat, there were firearms but they were more limited and the placement of enemies with guns was far more deliberate so that it added challenge without being faux difficult.

Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number however has a lot of large open levels with the majority of the enemies having guns, so a lot of the time I ended up being shot from off screen. This meant a lot of the time I was playing far more cautiously because I couldn't run through the levels quickly like the first game and trying new strategies for getting big combos. Because of the randomness of the gun enemies I kind of just went from room to room hoping the enemies would be in the right position so I wouldn't get shot, so overall it was less fun than the first game where you could get very precise. It was very annoying being shot through a window because an enemy had moved there when you fired a gun and in the last death he wasn't there. The first game was challenging but it was also fairer, because it felt like when I died it was my own mistake in mistiming, whereas in the second game I often died because I got shot by an enemy off screen had shot me, often through a window and I had no way of knowing they were there. The large level design doesn't help that I get shot from off screen and enemies can you see. Its just really cheap compared to the first.

The storyline also felt was misguided in that it overexplains things that happen in the first game and was too easy to follow. I liked how the first game was simple in the plot and the second game adds a lot of characters and lore that I felt didn't really work with the first game. The ending was cool though.

However the music and aesthetic are just as good and you can still have some fun with it at times. Its not a bad game, its just overshadowed by the first in a lot of ways. If would only recommend it to fans of the first game who want more levels, for anybody else I would say just play the first one.

reviewText:
Ahh. The sequel.
This game has some similarities to the first Hotline Miami, such as the control scheme, the pails of gore that everything is liberally soaked in, and some of the characters and masks are familiar.
It stops about there.
Hotline Miami 2 has a more pronounced storyline with a cast of characters, not just playing as Jacket and Biker and talking to the 6 people you talk to.
There's the Fans, who try to follow in Jacket's footsteps, Martin Brown, who has a show to put on, Richter, who will do anything for his mother, Jake, who is getting phone calls, Detective Pardo, who needs his five minutes of fame, Evan Wright, who needs answers, Beard, who has orders to carry out, and The Son, who needs to keep the russians in order after the death of his father.
And, of course, there's weaponry.
Axes, hammers, dual wielding mini uzis, pistols, bats, pipes, length of chain, knives, nail guns, bottles, bricks, and pretty much anything else that isn't nailed down or comes from the hands of your enemies.
The legacy of loyalty, murder, insanity, and blessings continues.
Welcome to Miami.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is the prime example of how a sequel should work.

Something that's to be admired in Wrong Number is the sheer amount of tie-ins and piecing together it does. Hotline is NOT Five Nights at BleachShots, this isn't a game where you frantically try to piece together a non-existant story. Hotline is a game with a set story that you'll never figure out. It is a game of unique-ness, and most of all a game of greatness.

Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is the second and final (excluding the upcoming fan-made mod, Midnight Animal) addition to the Hotline Miami series. In other words, Jonatan and Dennis know when to end a game. It differs from the original game, with now multiple protagonists to play as (all of whom tie in with each other) with varying playstyles (kinda.) The game also features Hard Mode, which inverts all of the levels, as well as adding harder baddies to fight. You will have to work to 100% this game, much more than you will for Hotline 1, and that's the pure beauty of it. It might bs you at times with off-screen enemies, but that's just how the Hotline games are supposed to work. Hotline Miami isn't based on luck, it's based on map recognition and memorization, trial and error is a must here. Don't let that turn you away though, just go ahead and enjoy this masterpiece.

reviewText:
Do you enjoy killing people? Do you enjoy a bit of challenge. Do you consider yourself a masochist? Then get ready to press R for reset! Cause here comes Hotline Miami 2!

This game is just plain out amazing. It's satisfying to kill enemies, racking up combos, and frustratingly easy to get killed. When I think about Hotline Miami, I think about how easy it is to get killed. And that is a good thing, cause this isn't a Run and Gun game. This game is all about being strategic, planning ahead, getting a good idea of what is waiting for you. Otherwise you are going to die a lot until you learn from your mistakes and get better.

The story continues off where Hotline Miami 1 left off. The main character (who is refereed to as Jacket according to Payday 2) now lives in infamy for taking on the Russian mafia. Thus introduces the cast of characters: a group of people trying to impersonate Jacket to earn some fame, a crooked detective that takes care of cases his own way, and an author researching about the Chicken Masked man, and a group of soldiers in Hawaii... huh... and a few other characters.

So instead of many different masks you instead get to play as many different characters who have their own way of killing people. My personal favorite is Ash and Alex who are pretty much two characters in one, one kills people with a chainsaw, the other shoots. The levels are also large and expansive which can be bad since there is sometimes not a lot of cover, so you'll get shot pretty easily, especially if your playing as Tony one of the masked bandits that can only melee enemies. Sometimes you'll need to be on your toes in case the next area has a guy not to far from where you came from. Like I said before your not going to get far from just rushing, you need to plan ahead and know where the enemies are at, and what you might attract if you start shooting. And once you get a good plan put together you'll be killing people without a scratch.

Also the music and the graphics are just fantastic!

Also on a extra note: when you start the game it will ask you if you want to skip and sexual content that is shown in the game, course if you were following the news you'll know what to expect. And as far as I know there is only one instance of any sexual content.

In conclusion Hotline Miami 2 has its flaws. Sometimes you'll breeze through a level, other times you'll get shot by a guy you didn't see or didn't expect, but in the end you'll be satisfied as you walk back to your car passing by all the dead bodies of every single person you have single handedly killed.

Final Rating: Bloody Amazing!

reviewText: Welp it's been a year since the game came out and there is still no level editor. The level editor has been in development for a total of two years now - at least. reviewText:
(long review, lot of words, if you want it summed up quickly, skip to my final conclusions)

I really want to love this game, I really do!

I am a humongous fan of the first game, playing it over and over again, challenging friends to speedruns, finding the secrets without any help and so on. So naturally, I was pants creamingley excited over this game! So this review really comes from the heart.

This game has tried to trump what made itself good in the first game, but unfortunately falls short by quite the margin. There's alot to talk about so I'll put the main points in bullets.

- Story: One of the biggest downfalls to this game. While the first game was a simple, straightforward story with a mysterious, convoluted ark to it which bred alot of speculation, Hotline 2's is a jumbled mess! It leaves off with jackets ending and subsequent arrest. It follows a sleuth of other people who have devived or been influenced form his actions, unfortunately, this ends up being a jumbled mess, with many character arc's ending before any development could be made (and you'd be surprised who's!), or simply leading to no where. Worst of all, avoiding spoilers, the ending turns into a total Deus Ex Machina to what would otherwise be a fulfilling-yet-unexceptional ending. After the game, I franticallylooked around, maybe there was a super secret I'm missing! A hidden ending to the arcs! A secret back story that will tie this in that I'm surely missing! Unfortunately, at this moment, I'm mistaken... And that saddens me greatly

- Level design: Possibly the biggest culprit for me, there was an insatiable need for this game to be Harder" by the developers but they've done this the completely wrong way! Long hallways with shotgun wielding foes who see you before you can see them

recommended: as sometimes your going to need to restart entire levels because the RNG placed a shogunner right in-front of the spawn position! Too many bad decisions which rely too much on luck an cheese tactics in order to beat! Now don't get me wrong

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is the Skwisgaar Skwigelf Advanced Fast Hand Finger Wizard Class of murdering dudes. If you thought you were hot ♥♥♥♥ because you wore a chicken mask and beat the Russians down with ease, Hotline Miami 2 is here to thoroughly disabuse you of that notion by starting off at the difficulty level reached at the end of Hotline Miami and AMPING IT UP FROM THERE.

The developers have stated this is the last game for the franchise, and they've taken every opportunity to mess with the set dressing. Level layouts are larger, which means you need to be absolutely careful of where you're going lest you get shot by a dude with a gun through a window (which kind of breaks the flow of the fury-murders). Not only that, but there's new types of enemies, including the kind of crazy ♥♥♥♥er near the end of the game that blends in with the environment that you can't kill with gunshots that runs really really fast at you that you have to throw something at and then ♥♥♥♥ing murder his crazy ♥♥♥♥ing face while he's down, JESUS CHRIST just thinking about that guy sets my hairs on end.

It's not like Hotline Miami where you get to choose from all sorts of different masks, instead the game cycles you through several different characters over the course of the story, and they either play close to the original or have special powers/restrictions (such as Tony's Fists of Fury (Killing punches, no weapons), or Evan's Fists of Don't Push Me Over The Edge Or All Of You Are Going To ♥♥♥♥ing Die). There's one character out of the bunch who sucks, and his name is The Soldier. The Soldier is really fussy and will only use the weapon he brings onto the battlefield, because he won't deign to touch the fully loaded Automat Kalashnikovs dropped by the soldiers he kills, and he will only reload his gun with 5.56mm and shotgun shell ammo stolen from USSR branded ammo crates. This is behavior I expect from the Valley Girl Soldier Squad, not a special ops soldier who goes out on one-man military sponsored murder sprees. No wonder America lost the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ war in this game.

So yeah, Hotline Miami 2 is mechanically sloppier than its predecessor, but that's fine. The atmosphere more than makes up for it. What I liked about Hotline Miami was its unorganized, hallucinatory atmosphere and storytelling, and the game continues that in spades, adopting a sort of Pulp Fiction-esque structure and a home video slasher ambiance to flesh out the backstory. It's not going to tell you the story outright, and it's not going to be a pretty ending for everyone involved. But the thing is, there's a bunch of little details that you'll pick up on if you're observant, and those little details help connect the web of the story in unexpected ways, changing little details, and in one instance, unlocking a secret level. Of course, you don't have to if you don't want to. The end won't change too much, and it will be just as ugly.

The soundtrack in this game is JUST AS AMAZING AS THE FIRST ONE. I did myself the disservice of looking it up on YouTube months in advance of the game's release, and because of that the impact of that music was dulled, and that felt like a sadness. But that does not make the soundtrack any less awesome - there's 49 different music tracks from many talented and (somewhat) obscure artists, and not a single one sucks. You will enrich your life by throwing yourself at the artist Soundcloud and Bandcamp pages after you finish the game.

Hotline Miami 2 is the kind of sequel that Portal 2 was - it doesn't quite live up to its predecessor, but that doesn't make it any less worthy of your time. I would actually recommend that you become familiar with the first Hotline Miami, because this game is not going to wait for you to get up to speed with it. It will kick your ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Dear... god. After the first game I was incredibly psyched to be playing this one. More characters, levels, etc, seemed like a great deal. This game has 2 MAJOR issues that upset me deeply every time I play it.

1- general level design. In the first game, you could look, figure out what was going on in other rooms, and deal accordingly. The levels in this are far more intricate, more windows, more open spaces, and long corridors, which make it really hard to judge what enemies are doing off camera and where it's safe to be.

2- AI. The first game's AI was very consistent and predictable, meaning that if you attempted to do something one run that worked, it would almost definitely work again if you replicated it. This is not the case with Hotline Miami 2. Enemies often seem to notice or ignore you at random, and *especially* if you're playing as a character that needs to lure enemies more? A massive amount of finishing a level comes down purely to LUCK.

In short this game's level design is severly lacking in comparison to the first's and has unpredictable AI that lend the game less to player skill and more to pure chance. Not satisfying and constantly very frustrating, and NOT in the same way as the first game.

reviewText:
Overall, this game is amazing. I'd give it a 9.5/10, it is challenging, has a great story, sticks to it's complex art style and is accompanied by a beautiful soundtrack. It's definitely worth the money and thus, a must when on sale.

PROS:

- Runs very smoothly
- Very dynamic, the gameplay is consistently entertaining
- Interesting storyline, you play as multiple characters and get to see the events from multiple perspectives
- Great, psychedelic soundtrack
- Loads of violence!!!

CONS:

- Extremely steep learning curve

If you enjoyed the first one, you will absolutely love this! I have never been this hooked into a game, it's like a magnet!

voteText: 31 of 48 people (65%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is quite hard at first as the developers have created a new varity of levels, mostly made of glass and fatties.
The game is based on a bunch of people all influenced by the main protagonist (Jacket) in the first game.
On that note the story jumps around from these people to give a change of tone and to make the story harder to piece together.
The ending is viewed as bad by the majority of people at first, but just reflect on it for a couple of hours.
There is a hard mode but (Thank God) there is no achievement for A+ hard mode, do it if you want to break your keyboard.
On the topic of A+ the grading system has changed, when you score, for example 50000/50000 you will get around about a C but if you get 100000/50000 you will get an A+. So basicly, your score needs to be double the amount on the right. (Hint: Combos)
Here is a list of the characters for your personal use:

The Fans: They look up to Jacket as a hero and try to copy his actions
Manny Pardo: A police detective who is jelious of Jacket, close friends with Evan
Beard/Soldier: The guy who runs all the stores in HM1, in 1985 war, Jacket's very close friend
The Son: Son of The Father who Jacket killed at the end first game
Henchman: Very close friend of The Son who fears Jacket
Richter: The guy with the rat mask in HM1 who shot Jacket and feels sorry for him
Jake: That guy found  dead  in Chapter Ten: Hot & Heavy from HM1
Martin Brown: Acting in a film based on Jacket   or just having a mental breakdown (Debatable)
Evan: Writing a novel based on the killing sprees of Jacket, close friends with Manny Pardo

Play the first game before this as the entire story revolves around it, from March 1985 to December 1991 the story of both games spans, well the first is just in 1989. Enjoy and don't forget to get a grip!

reviewText:
The game is disappointing.

Levels are too large, gunplay is focused on way too much, gun-related enemies are too frequent in number, and window placement is actually disgustingly abundent.

The amount of times I've died because I simply had no chance from an ememy sniping me from across the giant map is honestly too much. The window placement is also incredibly scumbaggy.

I'm not saying the game is too hard, no. There's a difference between too hard, and terrible map design. Terrible map design is unfair and simply annoying. I also don't want to be pretty much forced to use a gun in a Hotline Miami game, of all games.

I liked the story, but I could rarely focus on it because I was focused on memorizing the amount of people who can shoot me offscreen so much.

Maybe I got overhyped. Maybe I'm just overreacting. But I didn't enjoy this game. I'm sorry.

reviewText:
I've never written a review before but this game has compelled me to do so.

This game is 15% exhilarating (fun), 85% tedious (not fun).

The shootouts can be phenomenal and white-knuckle exciting.

However, those exciting moments are very, very few and far between, when compared to the sheer tedium and repetition involved in completing each level in the second half of this game.  I do not kid when I say that some levels took me 300-400 tries; HM1 was not even remotely close to being this repetitive and frustrating.  This is not because HM2 is “hard” or “challenging,” It's because it's shamelessly tedious and hardly balanced.

Many people complain about getting sniped by off-screen baddies.  While this is true, it did not bother me too much, as you can still hide most of the time, and I rather enjoyed the large maps.

What sucks about this game is how so many levels require nothing but pure LUCK.  Not skill, practice, tact, strategy, timing, etc..  Just luck.  For example, melee fighting is almost entirely a crapshoot; timing and skill play almost no part to the potential for victory - it’s random.

I’ve put 24 hours into this because I tend to get OCD with games and strive to finish them.  But this is hardly a game - it’s WORK.

I really want to love this game and give it a thumbs up, because the shootouts can sometimes be incredible.  But the vast majority of your time is spent trying to lure baddies somewhere so that you can melee them, and since the success of each melee fight is mostly random and based on luck, you will be waiting / luring / melee / dying over and over again, many hundreds of times for many levels.

reviewText:
Here we go... as promised... Hotline Miami 2 is getting reviewed (half a year later) and I will just start off with the TL;DR for anyone with the attention span of a 30-minute-old baby:

TL;DR

Hotline Miami 2 is not only a sequel in literally every conceivable way in comparison to the original: bigger, bolder, better graphics, music, audio, enemy variety, level design (you ♥♥♥♥in' heard me), story and a billion other things I probably can't remember right now, but also in the top 3 games of 2015 (out of all 3, I frankly can't really decide which of the 3 is the best, one day I may pick after all ^^)!

PROS:+ The Campaign is much longer! While HM1 could be done in 2.5-3 hours, HM2 will take between 6.5-8 hours (Steam told I took 7.0 exact hours).
+ The story, while being pretty much (not all of it, but most) an explanation of the weird plot that HM1 was, is fresh enough and twisting enough to be better in pretty much all factors and  is one of the best storylines of the year.
+ Improved sprites and animations  make it a welcome addition to the sequel in comparison to HM1
+ Levels are now MUCH bigger and, in general, ALOT longer,  though some fans will not appreciate this change. Some have gone to great lengths to bash the game just because of this instead of... you know... gitting gud"...
+ The soundtrack is a billion times better than anything put in the original's in my opinion!

reviewText:
This is a difficult one.

So first things first, is the gameplay: it's not as fun as first game because game forces you to use guns, levels are too open to do melee and aren't too thought out as in 1, where you could play as you wanted to. Forget about masks, this game features about 9 characters that have their own equipment(or none whatsoever) and playstyle. Meaning there's not much choice to be had.

Biggest problem in the game are AI, enviroment and doors. AI gets stuck on doors and spins in circles giving them infinite invulnerability frames. There's a two man character that includes melee and gun option which seems like a cool idea but the concept fails because one of them is following you and gets stuck on walls doors and so on. Besides that when you're going to lure in enemies(and you will have to) they will get hit by doors no matter what you're using melee or guns leading to dropping your combo.

Story has issues because of many characters that they did not develop. It was also scattered for unnecessary reasons, just to make things more complex to understand. They tried to make something out of it but didn't know where to go half-way, ending it before it could reveal itself.

Overall it's a good game but isn't so polished as first, music is still a blast though.
I wish steam had mixed recommendation because my feelings neither negative nor positive.
