reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 takes things a step further in this sequel to the successfully brutal, bloody top-down action shooter of crazy-aimbotting enemy AIs who have the reaction time of a zebra on steroids and psychotic junkies who eat pizzas everyday yet have the killing skills better than an elite black ops soldier.


STORY:
Whereas the first game was rather simple in scope, mostly revolving around the main character Jacket, Hotline Miami 2 features a diverse cast of characters that stretches throughout the story.
It may have turned out to be too amibtious, as the story immediately gets convoluted with a
frequent change in setting, time period and characters. Even halfway in the game, I still
barely understood what the ♥♥♥♥ the story was about. Or I guess that also has to do with the fact that I just didnt care much about the story.

SOUNDTRACK:
The music is just great but hardly anything that stands out. It aptly accomodates the whacked atmosphere of the game.

GAMEPLAY:
The 'scenes', the actual gameplay, is what makes HLM1 so exceptional. In HLM2, the devs decided to take a different spin on the action, all of which has only impeded the game's quality.
Perhaps one of the most noticeable change here is the significantly more open level design.
Numerous enemies patrol large open spaces that make you one big walking target for them.
To assist the player, the game gives you ability to look beyond your FOV. Seems useful, but not
when enemies have an eagle vision even wider than yours. It's easy to get killed out of nowhere
when enemies can spot and snipe you, even when completely out of your screen's expanded view.
How can you even scan across your environemnt 360 to ensure complete safety while also shooting enemies in front of you? You can't.

Most annoying in the enitre game is the utter lack of customisation given to players.
Controls are not quite as fluid and hindered by unresponsiveness and inconsistency.
Want to try executing that guy lying helplessly on the floor? *presses spacebar, yet nothing happens.
Press again after 2 more tries, the player finally goes for the execution too late as another enemy comes and whacks you dead.
Want to pick up that handy baseball bat lying right below your feet? Nope, the game makes you pick up this useless gun without ammo lying nearby instead.
Run out of ammo and need that fresh new machinegun over there? Nope, the game makes you pick up some puny knife instead.
I don't know how the devs even thought it was a good idea to limit the controls so much, they even have the key binding for executions being the same key for the Corey's Dodge/Roll key binding (which btw is a very useless ability).

And the crosshair...the crosshair...it's annoying as ♥♥♥♥ to deal with.
The devs have stubbornly chose to keep the crosshair white, a color suitable for some levels, not for others. In bright levels like Stronghold, the crosshair near completely camofladges with the background, making it extremely frustrating trying to play through the level.
Simply offering some crosshair customisation option would have fixed this nicely. Again, the devs didnt bother.
You know what else they didnt bother? No brightness setting, no gamma setting, no video settings at all. Howdo hoo, whereas all other games out there would offer at least these crucial settings, the only thing this game allows you to customize is its very, very limited controls.

This proves in the final Act 6 level Catastrophe, where Dennaton once again thinks it'd be 'challenging' to make a level so ♥♥♥♥ing dark, enemies like the black dogs and large black thugs are almost invisible to the naked eye yet are able to spot you from afar like it's in f***king daytime.

It doesnt help that I dont have that good of an eyesight, the lack of any gamma setting simply made me falling prey to such a disadvantage.
It doesnt matter how good the player's skill is, if you cant even see the ♥♥♥♥ing crosshair or the enemies, that's just extremely BS game design.


Furthermore disappointing is the removal of several masks from the original game, all for the sake of the story.
In fact for most of the levels, you dont even play with a mask. This all depends on the characters
you are forced to play as. Playing as 'The Fans' give you the most options on picking masks but
for all other levels, you're pretty much forced to play by the set rules.


CONCLUSION:
In Hotline Miami 2, Dennaton Games tried aiming high on target but instead hits all places wrong.
Being quite a fan since the first game, having played to the fullest and achieved plenty of A grades and even S grades, this wonderful sequel has only managed to turn my initial enthusiasm into regret and dismay.

With its unpredictably bad and half-♥♥♥♥♥ lazy level design, unfixed bugs and glitches of enemies clipping and utter crap controls and options available, HM2 has made it more of a huge annoyance to  get through than a game to enjoy anymore.


PROS:
+ Music is the same great list of soundtracks.
+ A more ambitious story

CONS:
- Sh****t open level design
- Controls are unresponsive and badly implemented
- Lack of choices, lack of masks
- Intentional lighting issues of some levels being too bright, others being way too dark
- - Too unpolished and rushed, with too many bugs and clipping issues in levels


SCORE: 2/5

reviewText:
I'd give the game a neutral rating if I could, however since its either thumbs up or down I'm going to have to say thumbs down.

The camera is horrible in HM2.  A complete step back from the first game.  The camera feels much more zoomed in for HM2 then it did in 1 and as a result enemies easily snipe you from off your screen, which becomes very frustrating after a while.   I feel like half the fight in this game is combating the aweful camera and camera controls.

The actual combat is just as good and satisifying as HM1 if not better.   The different characters/masks you can choose per level also makes the game more varied and interesing then HM1.  That being said if the camera issue was fixed (which at this point seems to be by design) the game would be an easy thumbs up for me.  However, because the camera is so terribly frustrating to work with it makes the game unfun and just a headache for me to play.

tldr,
terrible camera/camera controls
great combat and varied styles

Ok to pick up on sale.  Don't pay full price.

reviewText:
UPDATED REVIEW: March 15th. [Original review: March 12th]


So here it is, the brutal conclusion to a brutal series...

Yes, Wrong Number is easily the most brutal game I have ever played and I don't say that lightly. Not only that, but it concludes my favourite indie game series of all time. Perfectly. With the mystery that shadows Hotline Miami 1, Wrong Number answers all of these questions. And you're gonna be shocked alot as the storyline unfolds. The savage raids and executions done by the fans, will tackle what you originally thought was acceptable in HM1, and soon you'll realize that this is a very different game. Wrong Number is alot more darker, and by this, I mean there is more of a sense of right and wrong with characters decisions (no spoilers). Considering the first game was 90% mindless violence, 2 explores depth and story, but believe me, the violence is still in full swing... Infact the violence sometimes feels ugly and dark, and you're not sure if your actions are good or bad... The storyline is alot more indepth, as it illustrates the timeline of many characters and events alot more than the first Hotline Miami did, but it does include some familiar faces, or should I say masks... This game is DEFINITELY for people who completed HM1. It's tougher. Way tougher. The maps are bigger, levels are longer and there's plenty of people to get through.

It serves as a prequel and a sequel (or, basically to quote Borderlands - a pre-sequel). But that's it, no more about the storyline - I'm dodging spoilers as much as possible. But I will say this... the twins are alot of fun to play as...

In fact, my favourite thing about Wrong Number is The Fans. Every mission I played as a member of the group, I had a blast. Especially with the Twins. Total chaos. My least favourite is probably The Bear - the guns and arm control are pretty cool, but there were moments where I wanted to throw my guns down and beat the hell out of someone. With the twins, you have both! Left = guns, right = chainsaw. That's a win/win right there... Tony is pretty awesome too, but enemies standing in awkward spots with machine guns can be a buzz kill as you can't pick up ANY weapons. The Zebra I rate just below The Bear, the rolling skill is pretty useful, but only in unique moments (handling small group of enemies). Where as with the Twins - guns can be the dinner bell and the chainsaw and the kill = perfect.

The game is alot more complete and wholesome compared to HM1. In my opinion, the soundtrack is alot more punchy and fits the action and pace perfectly. The feel and mechanics of the game remain intact, however each character has its own unique skills and rather than controlling 1 character with a range of favourited masks, instead you have to master each character's preferences and get used to their style. More weapons, play modes and 'replay-value' achievements, and of course the upcoming level editor make the game feel even more complete (SPRING SPRING SPRING).

The hype for this game has been very intense - fake phonelines, figures, clothing, digital comics and for a select few, a special edition vinyl box-set. Wrong Number is the more professional out of the 2 games and its promotion has had alot to do with it! You should play this series AT LEAST 4 times (in my opinion) - Hotline Miami and Wrong Number on Steam AND Vita. Steam because its the original experience, and Vita because its gameplay is superbly smooth...

It is a shame to know this is the end, but at the same time, this concludes the series perfectly. Hotline Miami is a modern-day classic. And even though some might not agree, it ended perfectly. And finally, to answer your question, yes. I do like hurting other people.

ORIGINAL REVIEW FOR HOTLINE MIAMI 1.

reviewText:
EDIT: I want to clarify this: I don't think Hotline 2 is a bad game by any means, it's still good on it's own, but I believe it doesn't match the level that Miami 1 had. It does have very fine points and better attributes than Miami 1, such as being longer and more variety. But as a lover of the first, it doesn't do justice for me. Not hating.

This was difficult to determine... But I came up with my answer.

Hotline Miami 2 is the sequal to the high-octane, action-packed original from a few years ago. Miami 1 turned out to be one of my favorite games of all time, so I was very excited when I saw that a supposed bigger and better sequal was going to be announced.

However, it didn't become that. And here's why: The level design and it's overall structure... And then some. Read on if you're curious.

I should go over the pros first, shouldn't I? Well, the positives I can say about this game is that it has a bigger and better story, much more varied and bigger levels, new masks, and another good soundtrack. Most levels in Miami 1 were very simple and left lots of room for creativity, simple and effective, I loved it. This one is different though, boasting more characters to play as, with bigger stages, and more missions in general. I guess you can say it's more fleshed out.

There's also a hard mode" after you beat the game

reviewText:
A more than worthy successor to the critically acclaimed and award winning Hotline Miami.

Hotline 2 is very different from the 1st for many reasons but here are the most obvious.
1. The screens/maps are A LOT bigger.
2. Melee is pretty worthless now. (goodbye tony)
3. A lot more focus on the story.
4. Fewer masks, but now you play as more than just 2 characters.
5. The Level Editor
_______
So number 1; the levels are very big in Hotline 2. Which means you really have to be very cautious because you may get shot from someplace you can't see. Some say it causes unfair deaths but since most enemies have guns you'll be able to make it through, just don't play it like how you played in Hotline 1. And since the maps are big and most enemies have guns, it leads me to my second point.
___
Number 2; Melee is pretty garbage, Tony, sadly is worthless... and you won't find yourself playing as him unless you want to play peek-a-boo around corners all day. The reason for melee being worthless is number 1: most maps are huge and most enemies have guns. Put both of those problems together and you'll be only picking up guns.
___
Number 3; There is a lot more story in Hotline 2, which is a good thing, because it lead to there being more characters but also the story is great too. I don't want to spoil any of it, but the game takes place before, during, and after the first game.
___
Number 4; You don't play as a single person with many masks in Hotline 2, you play as...
Beard (From the first game, which is really cool. His parts to the story are awesome)
Manny Pardo (Best character, starts with a shotgun in his trunk and can use gun takedowns)
Evan Wright (Also best character, when you begin the stage he will only knock out enemies, not kill them. But if you choose to beat an enemy on the ground more than 2 times, he will kill him, kill 2 enemies like this and Evan will tear off his shirt and be able to kill like normal)
The Fans (which are labeled below and ends at 'Mark')
Corey (can perform rolls to dodge bullets and melee attacks)
Tony (one punch kills, but can't pick up any weapons, he's bad in the game as already established)
Alex, and Ash, bro and sis (you play as both these characters, one weilds a chainsaw while the other can pick up and fire weapons, their basicly easy mode as is Mark.)
Mark (duel wield MP5's, he's the best for speed runs. Hold down the right mouse button and he'll move his MP5's to each of his sides, which is actually pretty useful in many moments if used right.)
The Henchman (starts with a silenced pistol and only has only one level sadly)
Jake (from the fitst game, the lethal throw mask, start with a nail gun mask, and inner warrior mask which means he plays like Tony)
Martin Brown (starring as the Pig Butcher, plays normally like jacket but slower)
Richter (from the first game, has very fun levels and interesting depth behind him, plays like jacket)
The Son (son of the russian mob boss, he is only one person but you can chose between The Fans gimmicks)
*Plus Jacket and Biker are returning for the level editor. Jacket being able to use all of his masks from the first game in the level editor.
___
Number 5; The long anticipated level editor... Goes into Beta Dec/10/15, and will be removed later the same winter and then released shortly after. All characters, masks, and anyone you played in both of the Hotline Miami games will be playable here. All items, furniture pieces, and weapons, will be in the level editor. You will also be able to make multiple floors on your stages. But sadly you will not be able to put in your own music in these levels due to copyright. You will be able to share your own and play others levels after the beta when the full version is released.\nEDIT***********
Level Editor is now in beta, it is buggy as hell and if you wanted to buy this game only for the editor, you'll need to wait a little longer.
9/10 until crashing bugs are fixed

reviewText:
DO YOU LIKE HURTING OTHER PEOPLE?
If you feel the first game left the explanation a bit open ended then the sequel is just the game for you. While explaining the motives of some of the first game's characters, the 2nd game also builds up another story which revolves around ''The Fans''.

A group made up of five people that idolize the first game's protagonist as a hero and follow in his footsteps.[4 if you count Alex and Ash as 1].

The story kinda gets mixed up while trying to explain all the events that happened or about to happen but if you can get a grip on the events everything is clear as crystal.

Levels designs made in such a way that you feel they were orchestrated around the sountracks that are used. Bringing forward talented Retro Electro/Synthwave/New Retrowave artists such as Carpenter Brut, M.O.O.N. Scattle, Perturbator and many more that injects us with that sweet remastered 80's style. Definetly worth it if you liked the 1st game.

reviewText:
I haven't finished the game yet but I can already say that it has been a disappointment. So much so that I even felt I had to write a review (something I've never done before).

Like many others have pointed out before, Hotline Miami 2 is lacking in almost every respect when compared to HM 1.

You are constantly fighting enemies off screen, unloading guns down hallways and huge rooms hoping to kill enemies you cannot see because if you don't, they will kill you immediately. As a result, you are constantly moving around looking for enemies off screen who will snipe you. It's tedious and doesn't feel in the spirit of the first game which was frantic but still felt fair.

Cheesing the AI plays a much larger role too, since there are so many enemies armed with firearms, that your best bet is to lure them into kill rooms and just unload your magazine into the doorway. While this also true in part for HM 1, it was mostly a last resort. In HM 2 you'll find yourself using this tactic much more often, which has never been the fun part of the game.

The fun part was to plan how to tackle each room in advance and then try to execute that plan with precision and speed. Now most rooms are full of gunmen some of which you can't even see, so you are forced to either shoot them all, or again lure them into a funnel or kill room. No variety there.

This also aplies to amount of melee weapons in the game. MUCH less choices there and thus less variety in the execution  animations.

Also, AI doesn't seem as consistent anymore. Shooting a gun won't automatically make everyone run towards where you are, making it much easier to get away with not being stealthy. Even so the game seems more difficult, but it does so because of the wrong reasons: larger levels focused on gunplay, much more enemies. It all becomes more focused on twitch reactions, not on planning and executing.

While presentation overall is still great, the sequel takes a poor direction in terms of design in my opinion. Just replay part 1.

reviewText:
I wish this game was Hotline Miami.

The level design is no series of room, but more or less a series of corridoors. In Hotline Miami 2 successful strategys are often use slower pace, unlike Hotline 1 which was fast and aggressive. This game really reminds me why I enjoyed Hotline Miami through its level design. The first game made your failure yours alone and not as if the game cheated you, Wrong Number fails to do this. Deaths in Wrong Number are often a result of off screen enemys makign deaths more fustrating and degrades the experience.

It appears in Wrong Number the loss of mechanical satisifaction is due to an increased emphasis on story. In Hotline Miami one I never engaged with the story as it was such an insiginificant aspect of the game. The story was previously told in the shadows of the levels and never meant to be experienced by those who did not search for it. Wrong Number Story is unavoidable like the sun, but fails to have any impact on the player.
The only feature of this game that compensates for this lacklust game is its soundtrack, which like the first is entrancing and enhances the adrenaline rush.

I cannot recommend this game as the emphasis on story fails does not compensate the game diversion from mechanics resulting in it not recapturing the initial Hotline Miami experience.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is a game with some pretty mixed opinions right now, and I was feeling the same way for a while until I got better 1,000 deaths later, and kept at it. I want to start with the soundtrack first, it is incredible. When it comes to the soundtrack it's a matter of opinion, but I felt it was just as good, if not better than the first. There are also many more tracks in the game, so it's nice to not hear the same song on 3-4 levels throughout the game. I can honestly say that I enjoyed every track in the game, and that none of them felt weak, even the slower ones that play during dialogue.

The game does share a lot of issues with the first game, which is dissapointing. You still get snagged on doorways and corners, sometimes you just can't pick up the right gun from a pile of weapons, and it can still be a bit difficult to tell where your crosshair is. Some issues are actually worse than the ones present in the first, the biggest example being the very large areas littered with enemies and windows. This makes it frustrating when you can't find cover, or you get shot by an enemy that wasn't on screen. These areas make it difficult to get good combos, and if you do manage to get an A+, it doesn't feel very rewarding because luck is what most likely got you that rating for some levels.

The story is probably the thing that is being complained about the most, but I have to disagree. It is confusing, and jumps back and forth from past and present, but is still very dark and interesting. Some characters have little to no development like the fans, or the fat dude which feels like a bit of a wasted opportunity. The story isn't phenomenal by any means, but it was still enjoyable, and just as mysterious as the first game. The best part is that fans will still be talking about it, and making theories for a little while.

While the large and open areas were irritating, there are still some seriously great levels and moments in the game. It's upsetting that there is a lot less variety of masks this time around, but some of the missions, like the writter levels really stand out and are a nice change of pace. Hotline Miami 2 is still a very good game. There are some questionable decisons, and some levels can be much more frustrating than its predecessor, but you will still have a blast. Also remember, the level editor will help extend the life of the game, and it isn't out just yet.

reviewText:
I am a die hard Hotline Miami fan.  I have purchased maybe 5 extra copies of HLM1 to spread to friends.  I am a huge advocate.  I loved every minute of it multiple times.

I cannot reccommend HLM2.  And it tears me up.  HLM1 rode the line of frustrating and fun.  HLM2 is just frustrating.

Why?
1: More enemies with guns means less of the melee beatdown madness that really got your blood pumping in HLM1
2: Longer/larger maps mean armed enemies will VERY often kill you from outside your view.
3: Little to no options to select your mask/character during missions - meaning you cannot develop/perfect/test a playstyle.
4: Story - and this is a big one - TRIES TOO HARD.  The first told a very meta story that was intesting but unobtrusive.  Here, you feel like a story is being told because of all the scene changes and characters, but like the first, no real story is present.  More questions are left unanswered.  That was fine in the first game because you werent supposed to care.  Here, it felt like I was.
5: The music is not quite as good as the first but very close and probably the best part of HLM2.

I am very very very sad I cannot reccommend this game.

reviewText:
I REALLY want to like this game, I honestly do. I loved the first game to death (and will continue to do so, one of my favorite games of all time) but this game just doesn't feel right.

The Story
The story is pretty cool and all, tying up loose ends, and deepening the plot of various things, it's just that I feel it tied up TOO many loose ends. The thing about Hotline Miami 1 was that it's storyline was vague and if you just went through the game blindly mission-to-mission almost non existent, but if you payed attention, read diologue, and thought about it, it had a really mysterious and shady storyline, riddled with lies and inaccuracies, which was perfect. It felt smart, Hotline Miami 2 does kill a lot of fan theories, assumptions, and makes a lot of the actions the player does in the first a bit redundant, because the game is on a set story line where certain characters didn't/did die.

Gameplay
The gameplay is mediocre. Instead of having the camera set so the player's ALWAYS in the middle of the screen the game now does this awkward effect where if you go to the edge of the level it stops focusing off your character, making precision shots harder and more irritating to get. There's also a HUGE focus on guns, now, with tons and tons of guns in the game, and only few real melee weapons. Hotline Miami 1 had a mix of these, supporting ridiculous weapons such as a pool cue, fireaxes, katanas, even boiling water! Guns were also a big focus too and were also supported. Nearly all levels support guns and guns only, with wide open spaces and windows surrounding you nearly all the time with few areas to have breaks. There's also less masks/perks/whatever for stages, which means less playstyles and more use this mask to win (I.E. Alex & Ash). And a lot of the masks/perks for different characters are reskins
date: with the only character having unique masks being Jake
recommended:
who has like 2 chapters of screentime.

Music
Music is 10/10

reviewText:
There's not much of a learning curve. I guess they expected you to have started this game right after beating HLM1, because there's little in the way of starting you out slow - it's right directly into enormous, maze-like floors, full of dogs, people impervious to gunfire, and endless upon endless hallways of glass with gunmen behind them, ready to to do a 180 and snipe you across the map with a shotgun. And when you kill the dogs, the fatties who slap your ♥♥♥♥ if you try to melee them, the glass-hugging gunmen, along with fifteen other wandering mobsters, you get sniped by a person you didn't see off screen and have to do it all again.

Remember when you could beat most levels in HLM1 in one furious instinct-filled blitz, using nothing but melee weapons and the gimmick tied to your mask? Yeah, you really can't do that much anymore. It's still possible, but the maps are too big, long sightlines cater too much to gunfights, there are multiple enemies who are literally impossible to beat without using guns (which seemed like a copout in HLM1), and the masks are much more restrictive and you can't choose from as many at a time, if you can choose at all.

I can't beat this game. Call me a casual and a b4ddie, but I can't force myself through another thirty-mobster-strong floor of glass walls and fat men and getting sniped from offscreen if I'm truly not having as much fun as I did with HLM1. There's little experimentation and blitzing through levels, it's all about hesitantly entering doors, baiting enemies to chase, hitting them at the right moment in the patrol, and trying the same route over and over and over again until it works, since there's often times no other way to complete a floor except for that one.

I haven't played the game since a week after its release and I have no urge to go back. At least it unlocks content for Payday 2 and the soundtrack is good.

reviewText:
I'm still not sure if I like this game or the first Hotline Miami more but I think this game is really good. I had some complaints about enemies shooting me off screen but besides that the rest of the game is great. The game seems to focus more on precise execution of a plan over reaction. While this was present in the first game Hotline Miami 2 punishes you way harder for not having a plan, whereas sometimes in the original Hotline Miami I could just bs my way through a level on reaction and still do well.

The soundtrack is better than the first games since now each level has its own theme, most of which are good.

The story makes very little sense. The main issue being that many events lack context. The problem is that the game never gives you that context. Why am I fighting Russians in Hawaii? I still didn't know by the end of the game. This and many other plot points feel unresolved by the end and while some questions are answered in general there are too many questions left unanswered to feel satisfied. The best way to describe the story is that it feels like you’re in an alternate reality United States, but the game does not feel the need to explain the differences of the reality so you are just guessing why some things happen the way they do.

Hard mode is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. If you play hard mode expect: extra windows, more fat guys, more guys with guns, no middle mouse targeting, and ammo in guns being cut in half on pickup. (This means that if you are holding a gun that has 4 shots and throw it now has 2, if you throw it again it now has 1 shot, even though you only threw the weapon and never pulled the trigger once.)

Overall Hotline Miami 2 is a good game but hard mode is only for the dedicated.
voteText: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Okay, I've been mulling over what kind of rating to give Hotline Miami 2 and how it compares to Hotline Miami. Here are some things that notably stand out to me;

1. The disjointed narrative really doesn't make sense in the beginning unless you pay a lot of attention to what is going on and who you are playing as. There are very, very subtle details that you should pay attention to.

2. This game follows an alternate reality rather than modern day, where Russia attacks and takes control of part of Hawaii. It was something I really wasn't expecting due to the first game's focus on Jacket rather than what was going on around him.

3. The controls seem a lot looser than the first, which really makes things a bit of a cluster and a half, but it is manageable. However, since HLM2 relies more on gun play than melee, why wouldn't you tighten down your aiming? I prefer free aiming than locking on.

4. The level design really could use some work; levels are often too large with a lot of gun wielding baddies that would like nothing better than to end your day with a bullet. Believe me, almost clearing out an entire level only to be killed by the last enemy is an incredibly frustrating experience you will come to know time and time again. Either zoom out the camera so we can see more, or make the levels smaller.

5. The music, like always, is incredible. I'd rather not compare it to the first because the two really stand up on their own.  HLM has more of a lively, ecstatic feel while HLM2 is more gloomy and hollow, tying well to the theme of both games.

6. HLM is more about reactive gameplay and reacting to your surroundings while the sequel is more about planning your route through the sections and using each character's mechanic correctly. I will say Evan's mechanic of not killing enemies and unloading weapons was refreshing and cool.

7. HLM2 is about two to two and a half times longer than the original, which is both good and bad. Good for more gameplay, bad because it may overstay its welcome.

8. HLM2 is noticably harder than the original. The difficulty spikes rather early on, but you will eventually be able to handle what it throws at you.

9. I did notice that sometimes you can get hit with a bullet and not die instantly, but there will be blood on the ground where you were shot. I don't know what determines this or what causes it, I just know its a thing.

At the end of the day, I have to give Hotline Miami 2 a 7/10 because of its story and music. The gameplay surprisingly didn't get repetitive, but having to replay floors over and over again just got incredibly frustrating. I saw a good comparison of HLM2 to Super Mario Brothers 2 Japan (SMB: The Lost Levels); take the most difficult and satisfying parts of the game out and expand upon them to where it is ball-bustingly hard, but you eventually earn the title of defeating it.

Also, it's quite dirty to exclude the soundtrack from the special edition, but that's just my opinion.

reviewText:
Here's my review for Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number. CONTAINS SPOILERS FOR BOTH HOTLINE MIAMI GAMES

Hotline Miami 2's story is mainly about the reactions of characters to what happenned in the first game and it also gives some more backstory to the original hotline miami.
NOTE: the stages aren't in chronological order.

First of i'm going to talk about the characters and their stories.

The first characters you meet in the story are the Fans, a bunch of lowlifes who think that Jackets actions were good.
They're also the main protagonists of the story.
Corey the girl in the zebra mask.
She has the ability to roll dodge, that makes her temporarily invulnerable for  gun fire.
Tony  the guy with the beaten up tiger mask.
Same as the first Hotline Miami mask, it wil give you the power to kill enemies with 1 hit but you won't be able to pick up any weapons.
Thats a bad thing since Hotline Miami 2 is more focused on the use of weaponry, long hallways and big rooms...
Alex and Ash, both wearing a swan mask.
The first time in Hotline Miami where you can play as 2 characters at once.
You can use Alex' chainsaw to kill fat enemies and you can use ash to shoot people while you're executing someone with your chainsaw.
And then there's Mark the big guy with the bear mask.
I can't say really much about him other than that he's big fat guy with 2 smg's with both 32 bullets in them.
Dennaton added something new, the ability to shoot at 2 directions at once while holding mouse 2 as mark.
It can be really usefull in some stages (Deathwish,Take over...).
They try to do the same as Jacket did in the first Hotline Miami game, killing Russian mobsters.
The reduced Russian Mafia activity has left them to aimlessly improvise targets, and they quickly find themselves doing favors for their friends, who often have loose gang connections.
They were also veterans in the war in Hawaii.

The second character we meet is the handsome and brave detective Manny Pardo.
The dirty cop killing gang members and getting away with it using his badge.
He's trying to find the Miami mutilator.
There's not really something special about Pardo other than the badass shotgun animation and the executions with guns.
He's also the first hotline miami character who uses firearms to execute enemies.
His story has a big plot twist.

The next character on the list is the redneck called Jake.
I can't say much about Jake.
He joined 50 Blessings, in hope to do something for his country.
Later he got phonecalls, telling him to do horrible stuff.
A reward for his actions was a mask of his own.

The next character is Martin Brown.
He's a famous actor who wants to make a movie about Jacket.
He gets a dream where he gets interviewed and where he talks about his dark desires to kill children...
1 guy with a chicken mask stands up and asks him if he likes hurting other people.
It's just a movie martin answered. But his movie went terribly wrong.
O, he also executes enemies faster than any other character in the game.

Evan, the friend of Pardo is making a book about the masked maniac killings.
His playstyle is very different than other characters, he doesn't kill anyone and instead of using guns he disarms them.
Anyway up to the story.
Evan attends the trial of Jacket and takes notes.
He then talks with his friend Pardo and asks him if he knows someone he can talk to about his book.
Pardo sends him to a Russian mobster called Petrov, evan gets 2 questions before he getsthe ♥♥♥♥ out of here."
When he's halfway done he finds a note on the table from his wife.
She left him becaus he's more with his work than with his family.
He has the choise to reunite with his family or to continue his book.

Evan was a reporter before he was a writer. He went to hawaii to look at the situation of the war.
There he makes a picture of Jacket and Beard
date: 2 members of the elite team.\nBeard has 2 weapons: a knife and a weapon of your choise (m4

reviewText:
Hotline miami 2 is the long awaited sequel to the 2012 top-down ultra violent action/puzzle game Hotline Miami, and what may just seem like a level pack at first comes with just enough variety to differentiate itself from the first game and always keep you guessing about what might happen next.

In the original, almost every level would follow the same structure, you pick your mask, you enter the level, you kill everyone, you leave. But Hotline Miami 2 contains several different level structures with each one standing out so gameplay never feels dull. Whilst you no longer have a broad selection of masks every level, you are given a small selection (around 4 usually) of different masks or weapons, unlike the original game, every mask feels truly different and makes you adapt your playstyle accordingly, your selection is rarely kept the same as well, preventing you from locking down on one strategy and forcing you to think on your toes on what is the best way to tackle a level. However that is not to say you are always even given a slection at all, on some levels, many times the game forces you to play as a character and work around their advantages and disadvantages, you could be stuck with someone who refuses to kill anyone or you could be given someone who starts with a silenced pistol, it's this kind of variety that makes Hotline Miami 2 stand out from it's predecessor.

Hotline Miami 2's level design encourages a much more gun focused style of play than the first game, in the original Hotline Miami enviroments were a lot smaller enabling the player to be able to get through almost the entire game using nothing but melee weapons. Whilst melee is not useless in Hotline Miami 2 it certainly feels less helpful as areas are much wider and require enemies to be taken down from a distance.Hotline miami 2 also requires much more planning to beat a level as in most stages you are not able to just run out guns blazing since the areas are so wide and glass is everywhere, you'll find yourself dead in a matter of seconds. In order to beat levels now you have to know your surroundings, you have to know where your enemies are at exactly what time this results in a very cover based stlye unlike the first game which encouraged a lot more recklessness and whereas this may turn off alot of people I enjoyed this style of play a lot although I didn't prefer it to the more reckless style of the first game. But thats not to say those levels aren't in the second game, and when they occured I enjoyed the change of pace.

Hotline Miami 2 included a much greater emphasis on story and decided to try and answer all the the things the first game didn't, the game takes place before after and at the same time as the first game and time periods switch so frequently that it feels like you have to be writing notes to catch the story the first time through. However when you slow down and think about it the story is quite interesting as you realise who certain characters are and how they affected the first game, but it's not the most mid blowing story ever told and you don't really have to worry about if you didn't catch it, overall I'm glad they put a greater emphasis on story however some of it feels slightly irrelevant.

Something that really made Hotline Miami stand out from the crowd was it's soundtrack, It had so many incredible songs, each on tells you exactly what the mood is, no matter what the level was it would get your blood pumping and kept you pushing on through a level. Hotline miami 2's soundtrack does all of this and more, there is just as much variety, from ambient, mellow tunes to fast paced, adrenaline fuelled rock, Hotline Miami 2 executes the mood with it's soundtrack flawlessly and is no doubt worth a purchase.

That's not to say Hotline Miami 2 doesn't have it's problems, some people may not like the new style of larger areas and more planned style of gameplay and I have heard about people getting several annoying bugs however I have only had the occasional spinning dog glitch but nothing else.

Overall these are the pros and cons
+varied gamplay
+masks really make a difference
+great visuals
+stands out from the first game
+interesting story
+godlike soundtrack

-the occasional bug (personal experience)
-some may not like the change of pace in the gameplay
-occasional unfair death

I would give Hotline Miami 2 a 8/10 due to how it shook up the formula just a little but just enough to make it feel like a truly different game and a very enjoyable experience. Do I think it's better than the original? Probably not but a game would have to borderline perfect to do that and I think Hotline Miami 2 is a more than worthy sequel.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number may not be for everyone but it is an amazing experience for those that choose to brave the challenge. It not only expands on everything the first game brought to the table, but adds unique gameplay features and unbridled difficulty. In comparison to the first game, the gameplay is much more varied. Instead of masks simply giving you a weapon to start with or changing your character's speed they'll completely change the way you play. From the chainsaw and gun wielding duo, Alex & Ash to using a long range sniper and close quarters knife combo this game really explores the possibilities of a top-down shooter. You'll hear some complaints about difficulty but as someone who loved the first game, it's pretty welcomed. The original Hotline Miami was one of my go-to favourite games. I'd just sit down and kill some mobsters for 15 or 20 minutes, Over the course of a few years I put quite a bit of time into the original Hotline Miami and it became pretty easy. Wrong Number realized this and knew that there had to be a steeper difficulty curve. It starts to bar on the difficulty of old NES and SNES games which may seem unfair to some people but was more of reminiscent or nostalgic feeling for me. The game never feels impossible but rather incredibly challenging.

The music is just as good (if not better than the first game) and alone is worth the purchase. You'll find the soundtrack pumping you up to clear the next room or just chill you out while you're selecting a chapter to replay. I purchased the vinyl soundtrack and it was worth every penny.

As for the story; Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number keeps the retro 1980s (and early 1990s) vibe the first game established and drives it home with a mosaic of eighties and nineties movie tropes. In true Hotline Miami tradition they paint the whole picture through disjointed and hazy visuals in cut-scenes as well as subtle background imagery allowing for you to still come up with wild theories and discuss the story with your friends. The games art is unmistakeably beautiful and tranquil at times while being disturbing, gory & over-the-top violent the rest of time. Dennaton has said this will be their last Hotline Miami instalment and they manage to send the series off in a melancholy, dark and beautiful tone.

To sum everything up, Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number will probably not appeal to those who are faint of heart or are seeking a more relaxing experience. But will be very satisfying for those who a looking for a insanely challenging retro game. Especially to who enjoy the 80s/90s neon blood-spattered world. Hotline Miami 2 will go down as one of my absolute favourite games of all time.

reviewText:
What a lot of people complaining about level design don't realize is that this game simply has a different play style to it. The open corridors and heavy window use is simply a different way about designing the game and requires a different way of thinking. Veterans coming from the first game didn't expect to have the learning curve that they did with this game because the same methods used in Hotline 1 will get you nowhere except for a corner shooter. You can play this game without baiting and corner-shooting but you have to learn to. Dennation made a very nice decision to make an even more punishing game play, even for veterans.

Pros:

+ The soundtrack is amazing, seriously amazing. Very well put together songs by the talented artists of the first game as well as many other new additions from different equally as talented artists.
+ People will disagree with me, but the story. The jumping around is hard to follow, but the actual story has so many neat little secrets and reveals so much about the first game, as to why Jacket even started killing and what happened as a result. I will be completely honest, I DID NOT expect the ending but I actually enjoyed it.
+ Rather than giving you a bunch of masks at the beginning, a lot of which have no use (I'm looking at you, Rick :'( ), the game switches you between a couple play styles that it forces you to use. The choices you do get, when you get them, are all viable.
+ Same art style and rules as the first game, so they were able to introduce many new concepts but still were able to keep the same base game
+ Still as difficult and wonderfully frustrating as the first

Cons:

- A bit buggy, enemies can get stuck in doors or shoot into invisible walls
- Missing some fun features, like taking human shields (I never used that anyway) and stealth executing standing enemies.
- Ground executions take twice as long, which can be very annoying.


I mean, if you enjoyed the first, you'll enjoy this. But don't expect to be an immediate expert.

reviewText:
Despite this being a really good game, it doesn't feel like an improvement to the original game. I'd recommend you to buy the first game first, and then decide if you like the over-all concept. This one is more of a cluster-♥♥♥♥ to be honest.
The mask-piking thing was really cool and interesnting, but now you play as multiple characters, and there aren't that many levels where you can choose the mask, and you can only choose only four masks. That isn't near the amount of masks in the first game.
The soundtrack and graphics are slightly better, but everything else, not really.
Oh, and the level editor is pretty cool.
TL;DR: If you liked the first game, you'll definitely enjoy this one as well.

reviewText:
Let me start this by saying that I absolutely loved the first hotline miami game, I thought it was absolutely wonderful and played the hell out of it, which is why it pains me to make this review negative. The main draw of Hotline Miami is the fast split second combat where you act faster than you can even register, and if you fail you just try again. In this game however, that's not so true. Why is that? Simple, there's a LOT of enemies with guns in this one, and there's also a lot of windows and wide open rooms. This means that you either need to use a gun yourself, or you can do the old last resort of sticking your head out the doorway until they notice you, duck back, and wait for them to come to you. This was present in the first game but was only very rarely needed and was only there as a last possible resort, in this game it's basically meta.
There are some other points one could bring up, the masks feel a lot more varied with more unique bonuses, but some of these feel like double edged swords, and aren't very consistantly usable, an example being a mask that let's you kill with punches but are unable to pick up any weapons at all, something very bad when ranged attacks are so valueable, also a mask you can use in some levels can't be used in others.
The story feels all over the place skipping ahead and rewinding to different characters, it's not the kind of story you can understand in one go, at least not without writing down when everything is happening and creating some sort of timeline. And finally one of the most important parts of making a game where you die a lot is letting you get back up and start immediately again, this was usually the case in the first one, but here a little too often you're going to find yourself sitting on your hands as you wait for an enemy with a gun to walk out of sight before going through a door, or somehting of that nature.

So to close things off, if you played the first one, and are interested in getting the second, I'd only suggest it if you think you can handle all of this. If you're thinking of getting into the series, start with the first one.

reviewText: Better than the original. More of the ultraviolence that the first game brought, plus some cool alternative levels that you don't expect. The story is fantastic so far and the new masks help to differentiate each character and give them their own personalities - plus awesome personalised abilities, such as the new roll, or the ability to control two characters at once.\n\nThe soundtrack is one of the best I've ever experienced in a game and helps to set the tone when you're carrying out these horrible killings. reviewText: I am torn apart by this game (like most of the enemies you will meet). For everything good that it does, there is almost always something annoying happening to counteract it, whether it be glitches or game mechanics. Towards the end of the game, I questioned whether I was actually playing it because I liked it, or just playing it to see it to the end.\n\nThe gameplay. You will be killed by an offscreen enemy many times, and while you can do the same to them, I would rather be able to see where I am shooting instead of firing blind. The huge turning point between this game and the first is that the levels are larger, meaning the gameplay has turned into a lure and kill" strategy game. You will not be able to run into a room and spray gunfire everywhere (in most of the levels). Something else that really irked me is that you can't effectively pick up a weapon that you want. This seems like a minor detail at first
date: but when you have certain types of enemies that can't be shot or bludgeoned rushing at you
recommended: it's a different story. Enemies will get caught in doorways and twitch non-stop
hoursPlayed: as if they are telling you to hold the door for them next time. They will also randomly spin in place
voteText: and I'm not sure whether this is intentional or not because it happens to the same enemies everytime. I also feel like there wasn't as much thought put into the enemy placement; it feels like they went the Dark Souls II route and just put enemies everywhere in order to make the game feel harder than it really should be. Whenever I saw I unlocked hard mode after beating the game I just laughed and thought: "...Well I'm never playing that."\n\nThe music. What can I say? It was universally accepted that the soundtrack to this game would be excellent... and it is! However
helpfulPercent: sometimes the music can get obnoxiously loud. I'm talking take-your-headphones-off-loud. The first time this happened was so unexpected I nearly jumped out of my seat. This seems like it should be a good thing
votesHelpful: and to be honest you can really get into the music at first
votesTotal: but then you die 50 times and hear it loop 37 times. This is especially noticeable in the final stage of an act. It's as if it's trying to tell you
votesFunny: "AM I GOOD? YOU KNOW I AM." You're probably wondering why I didn't just turn it down. I could have
commentsCount: but the fact of the matter is that I shouldn't have to.\n\nThe plot. Hotline Miami 1's story intrigued me
column16: and the mystery surrounding Jacket and the phone calls are what pulled me in. I am pleased to say the plot in Hotline Miami 2 is fleshed out more than the first. There is a lot more dialogue this time around
column17: adding personalities to the many characters in the story. The story is very hard to understand your first time
column18: unless you're really good at paying attention to minute details and keeping track of dates. Think about it like if the movies "Memento" and "Pulp Fiction
column19:
had a baby and it was addicted to cocaine.

Overall, I feel like the story and music alone are not enough to make you want to play the game; and you realize just how repetitive the game is because it feels like it drags out near the end. So did I have a positive or negative experience with Hotline Miami 2? To be perfectly honest, I really don't know. When the music and plot are the more enjoyable elements of your game, maybe you should just make a visual novel instead.

reviewText:
Oh man, I still don't know how I fell about this one. First of all, I'm not a big fan of the level design. Many levels are much more open that I'm used to. This change made me drop my style from the first game and be really careful. Sometimes (when I picked Tony, who can't use any weapons now) I had to bait enemies one after the other so I won't get shot. On this kind of levels I don't feel like I did throughout Hotline Miami 1. It was hard, but if you gave it enough time, you were starting to feel confident and could rush through levels min-maxing your completion time (around 40 minutes for me). I don't think this is going to work here. Much more gunplay is required; the balance betwen melee and guns is about 30-70 for me.
On the other hand, visual aesthetic and soundtrack is still rocking, with a great surreal sequence near the end. Oh, in this one there's much more dialogue and story. There are multiple playable characters, some of whom had restrictions or bonuses. It's much more vital than masks in the first game. For example, one character doesn't use guns at all, and another can only equip ammo to his one weapon of choice. This is another reason why I didn't feel too confident - the story jumps around and sometimes I had a hard time adapting to new rules. I think the main reason I would come back to HM2 is the level editor coming up this spring.

Overall, if you enjoyed the first game, I think you should at least give it a try - maybe you'll love it, maybe you'll think it's okay. It misses the strong, fast style of Hotline Miami 1, but this game can still be a lot of fun. So, like, that's good. RIP Tony.

reviewText:
With substantial gameplay changes and expanded story, Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is an incredible sequel and closing game in the series. The game has many cons, which are only cons when the player compares them to the original while the game is perfect when not comparing, similar to the feeling transitioning between Sanctum 1 and Sanctum 2. The soundtrack is phenomenal and the artstyle solid, the game easily becomes incredibly frustrating due to what should actually be praised.
-much longer levels
-massively increased floors
-greatly varying gameplay
On one's first playthrough, these quickly become cons:
-angry at a level's design? It'll only be another 20 minutes
-huge floor and being killed by one of the last enemies on the floor and starting over
-not being used to a mask's major ability combined with its drawbacks will become incredibly frustrating and difficult until the player learns how to properly utilize the character.
There are many changes meant to make the game appear much more fluid and smoother such as more animations, and more enemies that are different and deviate from HM1's standard thug and larger thugs make it much more interesting. A major change is that with the game having characters that are not Jacket mean that a level is designed for that character and their ability, and will take time to become accustomed to but becomes incredibly rewarding.

The story is incredible and will take place from the 70s-90s jumping between character to character and elaborates on HM1, but Jacket is not the main focus in the game. The gameplay and soundtrack, combined with dialogue will make the player justify our love for violence in video games and pop culture, but at the same time ask, Do we need to justify it?" It has characters that have personality if you look out for it
date:
but can be missed by the rapid alternating.

Cons in the game at the moment are
-levels later become too open and easy to be shot at from all angles
recommended: or too small but packed with enemies\n-some gameplay elements do not make sense
hoursPlayed: such as the Hawaii levels having ammo crates scattered around that allow the player to restock their ammo only when fully empty
voteText: meaning you'll have to fire that last bullet to get 10 more for no apparent reason\n-the Alex and Ash pair (one has a gun that follows you and you play as the one with a chainsaw but also control the gun)'s gun-wielding AI's pathing is a mess
helpfulPercent: frequently walks into walls or falls behind and suddenly rushes through a wall to join you\nOther than the mentioned cons
votesHelpful: the game is phenomenal and when the player gets angry
votesTotal: take a break and come back to it. Easily can get overly frustrating and seem like a bad game
votesFunny: but on the second playthrough one will find details they missed and will be prepared for levels and can handle them much better and will enjoy it more. Both is and isn't what one completely expected
commentsCount: Hotline Miami 2 definitely has surpassed my expectations and brings closure and joy at what is left for me to play again and again."

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is a good game, but not a great one, and not all that I had hoped it to be.  Despite carrying all of the flaws of the original, it doesn't add much to make up for it.  Whatever was improved in game length, Hotline Miami 2 lacks in polish.  Levels are still fun, but expect to find levels a bit more like the bonus levels in HM1 or the Assault level instead of more thought out levels like miami disco.  The gameplay is significantly more limited, and has shifted from melee to guns.  Your mask selection is more limited as well, and during the times in which you're forced to play as one character in the vigilante missions, it can feel really cheap when you're burdened by that mask's flaws.  Overall, the gameplay is still good, but not great, and reminds me strongly of the second half of Hotline Miami 1 when you play as Jacket.  I would still reccomend it, giving it a 7/10.

Some bugs I noticed:

Spinning dogs
Floaty-feeling mouse, which I'm sure will be fixed in a patch.
Unlike the first game, bullet tracers come from the player, and not their gun.

reviewText:
Extreme letdown. Not sure how you go from the first game to this convoluted ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.
-♥♥♥♥ poor level design
-Complete neutering of the gameplay
-Rubbish nonsensical story. They are clearly trying to be deep" and "artsy" like some art student ♥♥♥♥. It's a shame they focus so much on the story this time around as it is complete crap.
In the first game you blindly follow orders from the phone and take down the Russian mafia while deeply questioning why you are doing any of this. In the second game you also deeply question why the ♥♥♥♥ you are playing this game. In HM1 you could choose which variety of mask to play as in every single level. In this game you play as 1 of a very few characters in very specific levels.
I can't even put into words how garbage this dumpster poop game is. If you really enjoyed the first one and you think you enjoy this one you are in denial. You want it to be the same great experience as the first so bad you avoid the obvious truth that the developers didn't know what they were doing. The game didn't need a sequel. This game is the equivalent of writers of a successful film being coerced into making a sequel and not knowing any reason why people enjoyed the first movie. A ♥♥♥♥♥♥ hollywood sequel.

The only redeeming factor is the soundtrack which is straight ballin'."

reviewText:
What's this? A Hotline Miami 2 review that isn't some bad joke? It can't be! Anyway, moving on.

Pros:
Great soundtrack, imo it manages to surpass the first game's soundtrack, which was amazing.
Nice visuals
Explains the events of the first game
Doesn't overstay it's welcome
Interesting characters, either by gameplay or story
Upcoming level editor for endless replayability
Has even more violence than the first game
Has a lot of replay value
Has more levels than the first game
Has hard mode which stays true to its name. Hard mode changes several game mechanics such as levels being flipped (possibly the biggest change along with tougher enemies spawning and ammo from dropped weapons being halved) and not being to lock on enemies
Fair combo time window
The game has a lot of subtle details, try to pay attention

Cons
Level design, you probably were expecting this, but they dropped the ball quite a few times on the level design. The main problem with levels is that they are just waaay too long, which a lot of time results in you getting killed by off screen enemies.
Doors feel like they are there to simply screw your combo up, in the first game they at least had some use if you were using the Don Juan mask, in this game they don't work as well, mainly because if you knock an enemy down you are probably gonna lose your combo since melee executions are now considerably slower compared to the first game
The AI is incredibly inconsistent, this is an old problem as the first's AI was also inconsistent, sometimes when you turn a corner enemies will instantly shoot at you while sometimes they don't even react, the dog AI suffers a lot from this, dogs will frequently ignore your presence then suddenly leap at you
Even though they appear in only one level I feel like its worth mentioning the ''fast'' prisoner enemy type that appears in ''Release'' doesn't work very well, a lot of times it feels like they simply clip through the wall/door and somehow manage to kill you, you need absolutely perfect timing to kill them seeing as them can only be killed with melee weapons. Plus it feels like the game gives a certain priority to the prisoner, it always feels like you attack first but the game decides to first register the prisoner's attack.
I am not 100% sure on this, but it feels like you can't look as further as in Hotline Miami 1, which is a horrible combination with the level design
The game has a lot windows, even more so than the first game, like doors, they feel like they are there to just screw you over. At least you can shoot enemies through windows or bait them, unlike doors which really aren't good for anything most of the time. Still, the number of windows the game has is frustrating.
The game has some minor bugs, such as enemies getting stuck in doorways and dogs completely ignoring the player, it's also possible for the player character to get stuck in walls, I believe this can happen during the transition of screens in the level.
Enemy placement can be inconvenient, one example of this is in the first screen of ''Demolition'', where the unarmed player character has to face off against a thug (FYI this type of enemy can only be killed with a firearm), two mobsters wielding melee weapons and an actual armed mobster.
You can't be as reckless as in the first game, mainly due to the fact that most enemies use firearms amd that the levels are very open and long. Plus windows don't help.

Neutral
The ending, I am not going to be spoiling it but I'm just going to say that it was unexpected. Either it was a good or bad ending is subjective.
The mask catalog from the first game is for the most part gone, you can only use the masks as The Fans (and there are only five masks). On the bright side you have 14 playable characters, some which play similar to others, but most of them are different from each other.

Hotline Miami 2 has its share of problems, but overall I think it is a great game. Maybe not as good as the first one for some people, plus you might hate the ending. But still, if you were a fan of the first game, at least consider getting this.

Notes:
You get some masks for Payday 2 if you buy the game. Plus you also get to play as Jacket if you buy the deluxe edition.
There is probably something I forgot to mention here.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is a hot mess compared to its predecessor, but a great game nonetheless.

For those who have played HM1:
HM2 is a great game overall, but falls short of the first one.
-Too many guns, makes the action less intense when it's a lot of spray-and-pray in the overly large rooms.
-On the levels, some are just WAY too big leaving the player wide open for one random bullet to put an end to all their hard work.
-Lack of masks was dissapointing (to me anyway); I anticipated having a more refined/polished mask system, which was present, but on a much smaller scale than the previous game.
-Forced characters puts too much emphasis on narrative and restrictive gameplay, something that was not present in HM1.
-Along with the narrative, it's convoluted to say the least, and supplementary information shouldn't be required to understand it.
-Addition of roll-dodge is neat, but is EXTEMELY annoying when trying to perfom an execution.
-Personally, the game is missing some of the close-quarters, high-intensity gameplay from HM1 (which is not necessarily a negative thing).
-Four main additions to this game: Guns, Glass, Thugs and Dogs

Annnnd on a lighter note...

-The music is stellar on most levels, though some levels have forgetful songs.
-Alex and Ash is a badass mask (in my opinion of course).
-The game as a whole is still Hotline Miami and is still worth a playthrough by fans of the series.
-The addition of hard mode (as if this one wasn't hard enough) offers more replayabilty.

Overall, fans of the series will enjoy this, however, expect more frustration than the first HM, and don't expect it to trump the first HM. It's strangely hard to recommend this, but it's still the same ♥♥♥-kicking fun that was to be had in the first game.

reviewText:
I played through the first game and loved it, with my only complaint being that the game was too short and the last few levels were effortless.

Hotline Miami 2 brings some interesting new things into the mix, but unfortunately the overall experience falls short. Compared to the first game, the level design is horrendous. You seem to have very few options a lot of times, and playing the whole game melee-only doesn't seem possible. Running into an area, guns-blazing, isn't a good way to beat the levels.
Many of the rooms are huge, and you can't even see from one side to the other with aiming. This is a real problem since it really hurts your ability to track enemies in the area. Ontop of this, many levels seem to just have an absurd number of interior windows... so if you walk into an open area, you are within line-of-sight of multiple different areas, all filled with rifle-toting enemies. You're going to get shot and have to restart a LOT. Because of this, the best way to clear levels is to play them out very slowly, not wasting a shot. This is the complete opposite of the first game.

The game is fairly buggy at times as well, compared to the first. Doors in particular are damn near broken. Enemies get stuck in doors frequently, seem to stop in doorways, lose sight of you in door ways, etc. In some of the more ridiculous levels I pretty much just abused doorways and made the enemies funnel into them just to thin them out to make the levels actually enjoyable. The AI is insanely bad as well, perhaps it's just a line-of-sight issue, I'm not sure. You can often kill a guy next to a stationary enemy, and that enemy won't even react. AI just seem to patrol paths more than anything, but on some levels killing a guy with melee causes enemies from all the adjacent rooms to swarm you. Pretty inconsistent behavior.

The game still does a lot well... The music is still great, the graphics are unique and interesting, there's some interesting design behind the pause menu, things like that. The story seems less interesting, but probably ends up about the same.

The game itself just seems much harder in general, and a lot of your deaths feel like it's due to a lack of information / clarity for you to react to, instead of you just screwing up.  An example being a black dog patroling across a black floor. You will pretty much never notice him until he kills you the first time. Also, there are a ton of random objects on the ground that prevent you from going around. I found myself getting snagged on them often while trying to dodge and run around. Some of them seem like there would be enough room to walk by them, but there's not. More frustrations.

I can't really recommend this sequel unless you're a huge fan of the first game, have played it multiple times, love to memorize levels or enjoy relying on your reflexes to carry you through levels.

reviewText:
Everything Hotline 1 was and more.
Let's get the complaints out of the way. They experiment with game mechanics that restrict the players options. It can be frustrating because some of the worst gimmicks, especially in the soldier's levels, feel unreasonably divorced from the game's memorable flexibility.
Level design is far more open, leading to annoying instances where enemies from off screen, even beyond the range of extended view, will open fire on you. The soft touch on randomizing weapons enemies hold, and their patrol path inconsistency, adds to pain.
IMO, finding the flow"
recommended: in the levels is far more difficult as a whole.\n\nStill
hoursPlayed: it is Hotline and more. I did enjoy some of the limiting mechanics
voteText: especially with the non-lethal Writer. It feels really cool to disassemble guns on the fly and knock thugs out. The story is as 'd'ucked as it ever was

reviewText:
If more Hotline Miami is what you need in your life (and let's face it, you PROBABLY do), then have I got great news for you! Hotline Miami 2 is exactly that.  More Hotline Miami. Fast and frantic gameplay that demands quick reflexes and patience, an unmistakable visual style that's as gory as it is colorful, and a soundtrack that bumps even harder than the original. At its core, with Hotline Miami 2, you really couldn't ask for more.

If you're looking for anything else or a game that expands on the mechanics and ideas of the original game, or found yourself completely fulfilled with the what the first Hotline Miami offered, then maybe give Hotline Miami 2 a pass.

For the most part, there's a lot of fun to be had here, however there are quite a few moments where the formula kinda breaks. This has a lot to do with the level design and stages being MUCH more open and featuring less cover for you to hide behind to formulate your approach to a situation. Though many guards have static positions or pre-defined patrol routes, there are quite a few more enemies this time around that randomly mill about, and in these larger areas it makes them much harder to keep track of. There can be many moments (particularly during missions set in Hawaii) where even when you're using SHIFT to look around, that you'll end up sniped by someone who you couldn't see off screen.  It's entirely deflating at best, and rage-inducing at worst, and it can happen too often for it to be hand waved away as a non-issue."  On the whole
date: the level designs just feel less honed and thought out than the original game.\n\nI will however
recommended: commend the confidence with which Hotline Miami 2's narrative plays out. It's a much more narrative-focused affair than the original
hoursPlayed: and though the issues the game addresses are largely more important to itself and its world rather than trying to make any kind of statement
voteText: the gusto with which the story elements present themselves and play out is admirable
helpfulPercent: and I can enjoy it for the big
votesHelpful: dumb thing that it is. The "movie" scenes/mission however feel entirely pointless and have no bearing on the actual meat of the story
votesTotal: and feel tacked on and thrown in to incite shock value. Really could have done without those.\n\nIn the end
votesFunny: this game isn't going to convince anyone that wasn't convinced with the first game. Like I said
commentsCount: if you want more of what Hotline Miami offered
column16: go in knowing that this game in no way can have the same kind of impact the original had
column17: and be mindful of the level design flaws."

reviewText:
Wow. It was worth the wait.

So let's start with the gameplay.. Pretty much identical to Hotline Miami, bar some new moves provided by masks such as duel wielding, dodge rolls, 'unleash inner warrior', and so on. These are really fun to use.
Difficulty wise, I felt that Hotline Miami 2 was a lot more difficult on particular levels, which is good, and they've even got a hard mode which you unlock after completing the game.. I'm yet to try this however.

Music. Possibly the greatest strength of this title is it's music. There's nothing like sending souls into the void to the sound of some upbeat yet dark music. Compared to Hotline Miami, I feel the music for this had a much darker tone to it, possibly due to the fact that the events taking place in HM2 are a bit more tense.
When you're playing the game, you don't even feel like you're killing these people, it's only until when you complete a mission and the music stops that you notice, after trudging through pieces of your 'enemy'. That's the power of the music they use. (Or I'm just too damn immersed.)

Hold on.. The phones ringing.

Right, so, story.. Now that's a difficult one. I'm not even too sure I know what happened, and of course I couldn't say anyway, loads of spoilers. I quite enjoyed it, you play from the view of many people.. Not all of them are murdering psycho's either. And they all have their own style of killing, sort of.

I'm not sure what to make of the ending either, I feel a bit empty.. It was awfully grim. No holding back by Dennaton Games.

Now I'm off, business calls.



tl;dr/overview.
Amazing game, a few new features and pretty sweet level designs. The story is hard to follow sometimes, and the ending.. Damn son. There was no doubt this wouldn't be an amazing game.

reviewText:
Remember that left side level in Hot and Heavy in Hotline Miami 1 where there is basically no way to beat everyone without baiting them out or using guns? Well, they took that level and made it the entire game.

Do you enjoy playing Peek-a-boo in doorways with enemies?
Do you enjoy firing a gun then sitting in the corner waiting to ambush all of the enemies, because of their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI?
Do you enjoy buggy doorways?
Do you enjoy characters without any personality whatsoever?

If you enjoyed these in Hotline Miami 1, you're gonna love this game. If you enjoyed rushing through the level and killing everyone in a huge combo, you're going to be endlessly frustrated by the level design that basically forces you to exploit the godawful AI. The story's not great either; it's endlessly vauge.

reviewText:
Sadly,
the Hotline Miami 2 is extremely bloated in comparison to the original game.
The story is extremely slow paced. You'll loose interest in the initial plot after
a couple of missions, leaving you with characters you don't care about.

They did their best to offer something new gameplay-wise, but end up
imposing restrictions on your play style. I.e. a character, who can't pick up anything,
and has to reload his gun from ammo crates, which are scarcely placed around the giant,
open levels.
You will run out of your ammo 20 sec. in and switch to sneak mode. But sneaking doesn't
work well in these open areas, which makes these levels not intense, but very boring and frustrating.
Hotline Miami gave you hard levels, but also all the tools you need to overcome them.
Hotline Miami 2 gives you boring levels, and takes your tools away.
Luckily, this applies only to a couple of giant and slow paced levels.

The game features 11 playable characters, out of which only 3 are an improvement
on the original formula. The other characters have either the same capabilities than the protagonist from the 1st game, or have less.

A quick overview:

The Soldier:         can't pick up weapons, can pick up ammo from crates
The Writer:          can't shoot guns. only blunt weapons
The Henchman:  no masks. Just a dude.
The Boss:            has the ablilities of all the fans except Ash & Alex
Jake:                    he has 3 masks to choose from
The Detective:    no masks. Just a dude.
The Pig Butcher: just a dude.
The Fans:            they have a veriaty of different abilities, depending on which one you choose to do the mission with.
My favourites are Alex & Ash, who are two characters you control at the same time, one wielding a
chainsaw for close combat, and the other wielding irearms.

For me, only the Fans were fun to play, because they had abilities which made the game more enjoyable.
They were like extended masks from the original game, going even further with the unique abilities. I also
feel they had more potential developing an interesting story with. I'd rather have a game half as long just with these dudes. Unfortunately, they all die half-way through the game, leaving you with these other interesting gameplay restrictions.

Bigger isn't better.
Bigger levels, not fun.
Bigger story, boring
Bigger pool of characters, unnecessarily frustrating.

If you disliked this game, there is a good chance you might like the original game, which is shorter, but knows what it wants and what it's good at.

reviewText:
While it's technically a good game, it's just not better than the first game. A lot of changes in design are mostly what came out during my repeated playthroughs. It's less about having a sandbox to tear through, and more about solving floors that are more like puzzles now. Many levels boil down to firing a gun to lure enemies, and killing them safely. Risky behavior isn't rewarded like it used to be, as just about every single level has gun-weilding enemies, usually in excess.

The characters are more interesting this time around, and there's some fun mechanics that were added. The Swan Siblings are the coolest, but they are extremely buggy in pathing. Dual MP5s are also fun to use. However, this game has less melee weapons than the first game; some weapons were even removed, such as sledge hammer, dart, scissors, etc. Tons of guns got added, though.

I feel like this game will be more worth it when the level editor comes out, and the design issue can be fixed with crowd-sourcing some campaigns out. The story itself is interesting (I like it, anyway), and the music is amazing, but the gameplay is somewhat flawed compared to the original. Many bugs persist from the first game, like glitchy dogs and pathing through doors getting wonky. No crashes, though.

Still: it's not a bad game. It's just not really an improvement or expansion for how long it took to develop. If you really want more of Hotline Miami, this isn't a bad investment. If you haven't played Hotline Miami, play that one first, if only to better understand the story.
