reviewText:
Walk in, use a knife, kill the guy, throw the knife, kill it with a guy, walk into a room, get shot, press R.

Sure, it's looks as repetitive as the original Hotline Miami and seems like its another killing spree type of game. As a sequel and a prequel to Hotline Miami, Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number offers a huge, variated cast, deeper, more therorizing clues to the original plot, and a new soundtrack that makes you finding yourself replaying levels just for it.

Hotline Miami 2 took me by suprise with it's greater maps, abilities that different characters had, numerous windows to shoot through (and be shot from) and it's continuous of Florida's most slasher filled retro shooter.

As a huge fan of the first Hotline Miami, HM2 won my respect and spot for one of the best games I've played. Recommended.
voteText: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'll be blunt here: Hotline Miami 2 takes pretty much everything that was great about the first game and throws it out the window.

The first game had a wonderfully surreal story that you couldn't help but like no matter how strange it got. Wrong Number replaces that with an overly convoluted story featuring a diverse cast of characters, almost all of whom you will play as during the course of the game. These characters are all put in difficult situations. Sometmes these situations are organic to the story, othertimes they are not. Charging through a building as a masket bandit picking off mobsters and villains feels right. A timid writer who has to fend off violent subway thugs while on the way to an interview feels tacked-on to add a few more minutes of gameplay.

Gameplay itself feels largely the same, which is a definite plus. However, there is one key difference...one I really can't forgive.
The first game was challenging, but understandably so. Every stage, while difficult, could be overcome with strategy and wit. The gameplay in Wrong Number is simply hard for the sake of being hard, and is neither satisfying nor fun.  Instead, it is frustrating and enraging.

The only way I can recommend this game is if you're a fan of being ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off all the time.

reviewText: Cows are the most common type of large domesticated ungulates. They are a prominent modern member of the subfamily Bovinae, are the most widespread species of the genus Bos, and are most commonly classified collectively as Bos taurus. Cattle are raised as livestock for meat (beef and veal), as dairy animals for milk and other dairy products, and as draft animals (oxen or bullocks that pull carts, plows and other implements). Other products include leather and dung for manure or fuel. In some regions, such as parts of India, cattle have significant religious meaning. From as few as 80 progenitors domesticated in southeast Turkey about 10,500 years ago,[1] according to an estimate from 2003, there are 1.3 billion cattle in the world.[2] In 2009, cattle became one of the first livestock animals to have a fully mapped genome.[3] Some consider cattle the oldest form of wealth, and cattle raiding consequently one of the earliest forms of theft.

reviewText:
Starting off with Hotline Miami 1: Loved it, my favourite Indie Game of all time.  Best sound track, Iconic characters. Amazing rewarding gameplay and great story. Probably one of my most favourite titles ever.

Hyped all the way up to release, even preordered the special edition then boom, day before release and I start to see Hotline Miami 2 reviews the day before it's about to come out and they are giving it mediocre reviews and saying it's a disappointment. Some other reviews pop up and they don't say anything that sounds much better. My stomach turns and I think WTF, I know reviewers can sometime's be harsh, and they can be wrong. Either way, I was going to play it and finish it.

So I finished it tonight and I have to say this. I don't know if the people who reviewed the game where tripping but what the actual ♥♥♥♥. Hotline Miami 2 succeeds it's predecessor in nearly every way. I can't actually think in any way it didn't come to think of it. I loved it, all the way through, it was harder, faster, better, stronger! :D Seriously, even though I don't trust reviewers much, I still take consideration into what they say, but now I do even less so.

Guys seriously I loved hotline miami 1 so much and 2 was amazing. It's better, the way sequals shoudl be. I just wish I could play more. I don't really agree with sequals unless was intentional, like your story was too long or you in your hearts of hearts felt that it was right. I am gutted they said they won't do another, but I also understand. I just wish it wasn't so definitive. I really will be picking up their next game, whatever it is as long as it interest me, which I am sure it will, I am quite open minded.

Some of them songs and moment of story and gameplay man.... pick it up, do two better and pick up the soundtrack and the special edition. Take your time and enjoy it, or just keep playing if you can't stop. I like to pace this sort of game so I have completed it a few days after release.

One thing you must do is just have those headphones up really loud and just lose yourself in the game.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is probably one of my favourite games on Steam. If you're thinking about picking it up, I'd recommend playing the first game before this.

The game plays the same as the first one, however to me has a slower pace which can make it easier. The story is told in a confusing manner by fastforwarding and rewinding throughout the game, looking at events prior and after the events of the first game. The story itself does not focus on Jacket himself, focusing on other characters such as the Russian mob boss, and the 'Fans' that idolise Jackets murder sprees. While the story may struggle to make sense at first, it makes sense when viewed chronologically and helps the player understand the story of the first game.

'Hard Mode' can also provide a good challenge once the game has been completed, with features such as a reversed map, less ammo in weapons, less damage resistance, extra windows and extra enemies.

The long-awaited level editor has recently been added, finally entering beta mode. This means crashes and bugs can occur, but this can be expected. Viewing user created levels is currently a little tricky as workshop has still not been implemented.

Overall the game is good, there isn't much to complain about apart from the slower paced, larger maps which can prove frustrating when dying deep into the level, however this can be expected from the Hotline Miami franchises gameplay. Would recommend both games.

reviewText:
I want to love HM2; I want it to blow me away, but sadly it doesn't.

The relationship between HM and HM2 reminds me of the relationship Manhunt and Manhunt2. The first was beyond belief. Both depict ultraviolent, grimy worlds. Both feature this silent anti-hero protagonist. Both had this visceral melee combat with later levels that delved into gunplay, smoothly and efficiently creating mass chaos in the final levels.

In the sequels, they seem to experiment too much. There are too many guns too early. There is too much enemy corner cheesing for an easy quick kill. Everything feels less rewarding and more frustrating. Both seemingly have weird censorship issues dodged by the first.

Both let you play your way the first time around and restrict freedom in the sequel. This soils the experience by the midpoint.

There isn't freeflow movement. There are things everywhere that you can get caught on. Some things can be shot over, some things can't.

Certain masks completely restrict weapon choices. Some characters are non-lethal. Some characters can't pick up any weapons and can only use fists. These are great and interesting design experiements, as masks, these could be really cool mechanics. However, these are forced choices in certain levels (level 12 is awful). Using fists is fine, except when a ton of enemies have guns and are at the far ends of rooms and must be aggroed by door-cheesing.

The ducklings are awesome and really fun to play, except when the shooter gets caught on every other piece of furniture and you're back to soloing with a single melee weapon anyway.

But what I really loved about the first game was the speed and free-flow movement. Hit the enemy with the door, grab the bat, smash his head in and his three cronies, throw the bat at the guy with the shotgun, steal the gun blast away the dogs chasing you.

In the sequel, you are forced to play slower because there are too many guns, too much glass, and too few weapon options (depending on your char). And that doesn't even discuss the fact that peeking is now impossible to play without. Some people may master peeking and walking, but I find myself stopping to peek and search for another annoying ♥♥♥ gunner in the top left room who is going to one-shot me through some glass that's off-screen somewhere.

The soundtrack is just as amazing as the first and is definately a highlight and reason to check out HM2.

Back to Manhunt 2 though, the biggest similiarity between these series is that the first one is simply a better title. It's awesome to see the series get expanded on, but the sequel experiements too much and fixes what isn't broken.

So, if you're a die-hard fan, check it out, maybe you'll dig the super-restrictive levels. They are definately a huge pain in the ♥♥♥ difficulty wise.

If you've never played the first, get that instead. You'll enjoy it way more.

TL;DR play the first one and if you can't get enough try this one out

reviewText:
My GOTY for 2015, and one of my favorite games of all time. Larger levels require more practice to get all the way through and it replaces the first games wide selection of masks with a small selection of options for each character/level, but I think it makes up for these. Once you get a room down, it's a very intense experience, and certain character styles (such as Evan Wright's ability to switch between non-lethal and full-blown PTSD rampage, or Jake's fast-paced timed nunchuck sessions) are more interesting than some of the HM1 masks.

A major difference between this and the first game (which I absolutely also recommend, and you should play before playing this one) is that the first has a minimalist story which is intriguing but exists only enough to provide a context for violence-fueled missions. This game builds up the story much more, moving to times both before and after the events of HM1. Some people dislike this change, but the story is great, and the ending is incredible.

Also, as a pro tip: A lot of people complain about getting killed by enemies you can't see in this one (because of windows). You need to use shift (or, on a controller, I think L?) to look around. No one can see you outside of your vision range.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number
The game, lets say, a bit dissapointing. The game itself stays true to the core, having it be a difficult, action packed game where you go around, simply killing people, and all the while having a good time, screaming at your monitor.

What's good about the game? Well, other than being Hotline Miami, the game offers a lot more weapons and a few new enemies, allowing new ways to kill. The Soundtrack is obviously amazing, in my opinion better than the first game, the feeling of starting a level and having that music shoot some adreniline in you, it's great.

Dissapointing, how?
Well, first of all the game allows you to choose your mask, or in this game, character. You can play as Tony (The Tiger), Mark (The Bear), Ash & Alex (The Swans), and Corey (The Zebra). Although... You don't get much choice, there are lots of levels where you don't play as the fans, rather than three others(Explained below) who are still fun to play, but don't offer the mask bonuses.

reviewText:
This game shines in every way, including the immense gore that infests the entirety of the game, a truly heart-pumping upbeat soundtrack full of 80's electro synth, The radiant colors and visuals, and the intense fast-paced action that keeps you coming back for more.

You're going to die alot in this game. The difficulty has been increased tenfold from the original Hotline Miami, So don't expect levels to carry you on their backs all the way to the finish. There's also a hard mode that's even more difficult.

There is a total of 9 playable characters in Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number. All of them are distinct in their own ways, whether it be their role in the game, or their kickass abilities they possess.

There is a Level Editor said to come out in Spring, which means the games value will last longer even after completing the game on Normal, Hard mode and finding the bonus levels.

Truly a work of art, I would seriously recommend this game to anyone and the original Hotline Miami if you've never played these games before.

reviewText:
Well, let me get one thing out of the way. My 'R' key has reported me to the authoroties for numerous accounts of violence, assault, battery, and even sexual abuse, so before I go to jail I'll write this review.

It's...

Beautiful.

Just buy the game.

Play it.

Hotline Miami 2 places you into the role of multiple characters with different agendas, with their lives influenced by the events of the first game. You'll find that each character has their own quirks and abilities, and some characters are harder to use than others. The levels are hard, if I may say much harder than the levels of Hotline Miami one. There are more weapons, and more unique story elements.

Just play the game, will ya? [Edited below]

Edit: Now that I am no longer sleepy and rather, well...somewhat shocked (in a very, very good way, yet a sad one), I'll now take my time to list my pros and cons. Cons first, pros last. Both for story and gameplay.

Cons -
Playing as Alex and Ash, Ash sometimes tends to be stuck (But even with that being said they were my favourite characters).

While it was expected, we no longer get to choose unique masks, but on a brighter note we do get to select things in certain levels.

Some personal expectancies in the story weren't quite met, then again either I've missed something...Or the end isn't the end.

A rather...Downer conclusion...

Pros -

Gameplay is a lot like in the first game, with twists, as characters have their own unique abilities that make combat with each character different.

The soundtrack. All of it. The menu song is just heart-wretching and tear-jerking, beautifully so, but it wasn't only the menu song that moved me. All songs are either groovy, melodic, or generally badass.

Unique graphical style.

Improved difficulty. Frustratingly fun.

Well done story focusing on multiple characters, each of whom I actually liked except one. To avoid spoiling the story, I won't say who it was.

Pretty chill developers who refused to censor the game for Australia, and who are also pretty chill towards pirating the game. Props to you, lads and lasses!

Hotline Miami 2 is indeed a brutal conclusion, and the execution was great...

On another somewhat spoiler-esque note, I'll openly admit that, as stated, I really wish that the end wasn't the end. The ending wasn't poorly executed, but it seems somewhat anti-climatic.

reviewText:
I have incredibly mixed feeling about HM2 now that I finished it. I still enjoyed the game overall and would recommend it to fans of the original but a lot of the things they changed just don't work that well and slow down the pace of the game, where part of the original game's appeal and what made it successful was how fast it moved.

The outdoor areas seemed to drag for me and often turned into me firing a gun to distract a few enemies at a time and dispose of them before moving onto the next group. They end up being frustrating and tedious which is how I never felt while playing the first game, no matter how many times I had to restart a level, except for the hospital level of course.

I was also disappointed by the story. I thought I would find it more interesting since I enjoyed the few scraps of story in the original game but it never resolves any of the plot points in an interesting way. It just kind of slowed down the game some more.

I don't think it was a bad game. I think I still mostly enjoyed it but I'm probably not going to replay it like I did with the first game.

But at least the soundtrack was still amazing. I don't regret buying the vinyl LP soundtrack for the game at all.

reviewText:
Preface: Played the original on Playstation to Platinum, and on PC (10h so far).

Hotline Miami 2 is a masterclass in tedium, analogous to waiting in line at Tesco.

The maps are overly sized, and if you value your sanity, you're left to wait for the patrol to come to you before you can dispatch them. Of course, you're free to approach them, but their field of view is a lot higher than yours, and it's close to certain that they'll tag you before they become visible.

The fast-paced play of the original is again stifled by an odd choice to move the ending of the brutal finishers to a player-controlled RMB click. I don't know why automatically completing the move has been dropped (Can I change it to automatically detach from what remains of my enemy's body? Let me know).

Weapons, while largely unchanged from its predecessor, come in a state of limbo as to whether your current character can use them, will unload them, or will either completely ignore to pick them up. (Act 2, L1. He failed to pick up butterfly knife?)

I hate that I have to leave a negative review. Seriously, HM is easily one of the greatest indie games of the 2010s, and with the developers stating that this is the last in the series, it's frustrating that it is being left in such a state.

Maybe I do just need to git gud". Or I can just play something else

reviewText:
This sequel and finale to the series definetly did the series justice.

The characters are interesting, the abilities of the characters are varied and fun to play with, the game can be challenging at times, but it is never too impossible.

The art style and lore is great, but the soundtrack is fantastic!

The ending was a bit strange and abrupt, the dog AI needs some work as they sometimes keep spinning in circles for no reason.

But nevertheless, awesome game. If you like to hurt people, this is the game for you. It's going on my top 5.

9/10 (possibly 10/10 when level editor arrives)

reviewText:
I'm split with what to say with this game, so I'll put it into one sentence

Good game, bad sequel

I've gone as far to call HM1 my favourite game of all time, I love the fast and addicting gameplay, as well as the soundtrack

I'm unsure if I can say all of that for this game.

For starters, this game has too many characters to play as, this is bad for 2 reasons:
It removes the feel of one man being able to take down an entire Russian mob on his own, and that with the multiple time lines and characters, its hard to like a character and get used to them, as they're all just killed.

The game did release fairly buggy too, whilst a lot of these things were patched, the game still has many issues, primarily with the enemies

The 2 biggest issues I have with the enemies is the enemies just spinning in circles on their own, or getting stuck on doors and spinning extremely fast. The other issue is that if your being chased by a line of enemies, the enemies at the back of the line can see and shoot you through the enemies in front, but you can't do the same, which leads to many BS deaths.

Many of the levels are just too long as well, the biggest offender to this would be the boat level and the sewer level, both of these levels have a lot of blind firing in them due to long hall ways/open space which even with the shift look are too long, and lead to you being distracted and easily being killed from behind and weaponed enemies in front.

Moving onto the good points, the regardless of the previous issues, the game is still fun and addictive and very fun to play, and the soundtrack is like ear porn. Regardless of its issues it's still a fun game to play, but for fans of the first game, it's not the same experience.

reviewText: Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is the explosive finale to the Hotline Miami series but will it hit the mark or fall flat on it's face ? Hotline Miami 2 is a way bigger sequel and is larger then the first one in almost every aspect. The game takes place Before, between and after the events of Hotline Miami. Showing diffrent perspectives on the murders and what happend after them. I could go in depth with the story but i would spoil an already amazing story. So how is this game ? So far this is my favorite game of 2015 and is my personal pick for GOTY. Even though the game looks the same it's not and actually it's quite diffrent. The game is even harder than 1 and at some times could feel harsh but it never is too unfair that you want to stop playing. Unlike the first game the story takes the stage as the more important factor to the game and it nails it perfectly. Every story you play through is engaging and you want to see how everything wraps up together. The levels are bigger than the ones you see in the first one which could lead to many deaths. The game is also pretty buggy at the moment but like the first one it should be patched this week. The soundtrack which was important in the first one is ten times better in two. The soundtrack will keep you on you're toes the entire time. Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is a thrilling ride which you all should expierence at least once. This game is full of twists and turns along the way. After the ending i sat in my chair because i was speechless how good the game was. Without a doubt get this game right now because it's one of the best games i have ever played. I give Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number a 10/10\n\nFor more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
There’s always a dangerous line to travel when a sequel is made, especially when the previous installments are successful or have a healthy modicum of acceptance from consumers. Straying too far from the original formula can make the sequel feel removed and disjointed from what made the previous game good, and sticking too close to the original can come off as lazy or apathetic. Dennaton certainly did not have an easy job on their hands making a sequel to Hotline Miami, and while the gameplay from the previous game is as strong and snappy as ever, what additions were made end up bloating the new installment while punishing the player for playing wildly.

Oddly the biggest disappointment I have right out of the gate is the story-telling. The first game was quite memorable due to the story, which kind of didn’t really care if you were following along clearly or not. Sure, with enough observation and putting puzzle pieces together you could get some idea, but it never really stopped to explain things, just chugging along to the next scene to give you more violence and combos to build in order to get that high score. In Hotline Miami 2, I can’t help but feel like there was damage control because of that, and now there’s too much story being fed to the player. Many characters are brought in to flesh out the narrative, like the Fans who are following in Jacket’s footsteps, or Evan, the journalist writing about all the mayhem and getting involved in ways he wasn’t hoping for. Yes, this does mean you get a nice break between segments to be in someone else’s shoes and potentially have different playstyles (Evan’s lack of killing, the Fans acting as Jackets’ different masks from the first game), but I can’t shake the weird feeling that between Hotline Miami 1 and 2, it felt like there was an obligation to play catch up and bog down the game with narrative just for the sake of putting some clarity to the mayhem.

The second major disappointment comes from the larger, more densely populated maps the game throws you in. While bigger maps should mean more attack strategies, higher scores and longer combos to chain, we mustn't forget that a single, errant mistake means death and restarting the screen. In the first game, playing like a madman often had the end result of clearing screens by the skin of your teeth, adapting in the middle of a skirmish and having very hectic, though incredibly satisfying victories. A death would cost you very little, and only during the later acts when the maps got larger, and more risky did you have to slow down and plan a bit more thoroughly. The player was nearing the end of the game, so the increase in difficulty was to be expected. In Hotline Miami 2, the difficulty of larger, more involved maps starts far sooner than in the original, and is expected, reckless, wild rampages will be shot down far more swiftly and feel much more painful in the process. It’s not the difficulty of the game or the easy death of your character that’s the issue, it’s that the bigger maps that almost seem to demand that you lure waves of enemies into a bottleneck before you horribly end their lives time and time again, and any improvisation during a frantic deviation from this strategy has a high cost regarding your time and patience. Having to clear a level using turtle tactics and purposeful pacing rather than going bonkers through the place and getting a poor score/rating at the end of it all was a frequent reminder of why the first game was far easier to digest and have bloodier enjoyment of. And doors somehow have gotten worse. WORSE.

The soundtrack for me is the biggest shining point of this sequel, as while the first game had a far more memorable OST that stuck with me afterwards, Hotline Miami 2′s music feels much more solid across the board in out of game listening, but it lacks that memorable punch that the first soundtrack had. To say that the music is the most noteworthy part of the game doesn’t entirely speak poorly of Hotline Miami 2′s gameplay which, excluding the need to take encounters on a lot more slowly than intended, it remains as it was in the first game.

Even if we exclude the reported problems that rose during the Steam launch of Hotline Miami 2 of controller play not functioning, Windows XP support being sketchy and the fact that the godforsaken executable did not work on day one for many consumers, I walk away from the game feeling incredibly disappointed on a personal level, while feeling frustrated on the technical side of things. Yes, it is more Hotline, but the attempts of sticking to the original formula while shoving borderline fanfiction-esque narrative upon me made things more and more difficult to swallow, and the ending itself feels like a gigantic middle finger to the player for going through everything they had to see things through to the end. I can only recommend Hotline Miami 2 to those who greatly enjoyed the first game or those who found the first game much too easy. Too much disappointment has remained on a personal and technical level, and it’s because of this that I must unfortunately say that for anyone else curious about Hotline Miami 2, it’s a pass - The first game is your much better bet.

reviewText: If you are a fan of the first game, like me, this game may as well be a serious let down. I love hotline miami, the way you could tackle the levels in your own style made it an amazing expirience i had yet to feel from a pixelated game. This itteration of the series has many faults, from technical errors to gameplay descisions. The story feels very natural, however that is not where this game lacks. It lacks in the freedom of choice to take on levels the way you see fit, in hotline miami you had several masks to take on levels with which could be found while playing. Wrong Number does not offer this, instead it offers different playable characters each level, such as being character locked into a detective with nothing special about him, making the whole level only a puzzle in which you can solve only in a few ways. Not to mention, the game is also extremely short, im sure there are hidden secrets i have not found yet, but frankly i do not want to find them after what i played through, I do not want a game that tells me what to do to win, i want a game that i can tackle in a multitude of ways. I want to give this game a good review, but it does not deserve one in my opinion. Sorry to the developers, im hoping they can get it together for the third itteration (if one) but if not ill be fine with hotline  miami, the one and only

reviewText: If you liked Hotline Miami 1 for its smooth fast paced melee gameplay and its sandboxy level designs, I can't reccomend this game. The fun of being able to complete levels in a fast and twitchy way racking up combos with your favorite mask is gone. Most levels are either designed with one mask in mind or do not even give you a mask. I found myself often camping corners waiting and luring people towards me away from the open rooms they spawned it. While in the first game I would often run in, knocking out one gunman with a thrown brick and proceeding to bash the others head in with a hammer that was on the ground. To me this game is a downgrade, removing the parts that made the first game amazing and leaving in the mechanics I did not like from the later levels of the first game.\n\nOn a numerical scale I would give this game a 6/10. Although It contains an amazing Soundtrack and fun story, this games gameplay is a severe downgrade from the first. I would recommend getting in on a sale.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number, much like its predecessor, is an ambiguous, interesting, yet very flawed game.
One of the big things that Hotline Miami 2 does that is interesting is that it splits the story up between multiple characters, rather than just 2.
It runs off of a similar system to its predecessor, a top-down view, with heavy focus on twitch reaction times and awareness.
First the pros:
The multiple characters with their intertwining stories are incredibly neat - one of the characters is a writer who does not like to kill, which leads to missions centered around nonlethal takedowns. That was fun and interesring!
The mask mechanic has been ramped up. And by that, I mean, the mask effects ('mask'. Not all the characters wear masks.) are so absolutely diverse, and it's excellent.
The combat, like the first game, is satisfying and fun. The weapons are more diverse, and it's fun.
The cons:
The game is janky as hell in many ways. For one, AI jumps between being hyperaware to the point of being superhuman, and between being so unaware that they must have brain damage. This makes planning ahead very difficult, not fully knowing how quickly the AI will react.
A big issue I had is that, although the doors appear to be wood, thay seem to function as pure durasteel, seeing as they are utterly inpenetrable. This wouldn't be a problem so much if some of the AI (namely the attack dogs) weren't able to attack through doors. This gave me a whole lot of grief and I ended up being frustrated more often than not.
The AI also have hawkeyes, and they'll often bullseye you from the other side of the level. This is alleviated somewhat by the ability to 'aim', which allows you to look farther. Not far enough, though, most of the time.
Also, you don't add pseudo boss fights where you need to run in circles until something happens that allows you to fight the boss some time after running in circle, but you still don't know how, and you die in one hit. THIS IS NOT FUN. This is just frustrating.

In a nutshell, I would say that overall, I enjoyed this game. There's just a lot to be frustrated over. There's a large portion of the game that I still look at and thing: 'Did I have fun?'   I really cannot tell.

It's worth its price though. I'd give it a buy. If you enjoy it, great. If not-... It didn't cost you all that much. If it's on sale, even better!

reviewText: A game that constantly seeks to challenge your inner restricted urges, your oozing compulsion to make this external macrocosm where things tend to collide and at times converge for something new to occur. Very rarely we get a glimpse into the nature of the videotape and what it means to actually insert oneself within this nefarious but somehow fascinating and constantly changing piece of evidence. You can either try to change the landscape of how we perceive things that we daily consume and put a great deal of emphasis on or you can leave it to the regular consumer/customer and take a backseat so that you can watch the world regress in a flash of the universe. By purchasing and playing this game you attain a new sense of relief in things, you get this bright occurence that is quite rare to observe, you get a glimpse into an eye of someone wanting to shake things up, and for this reason alone this game warrants pleasure and pain and enjoyment as well as expansion of ideas known and not known, all of the feelings restricted and bundled up finally resurface once you actually get to complete this game in entirety.

reviewText: I'm going to open up with this; Do not go into Wrong Number expecting more of the original game. Players who were head over heels with Hotline Miami 1 will find themselves having an awkward affair with the sequel. The game sheds a large portion of the beserker rushes in favour of a more tactical, slow approach. Wrong Number has a much greater focus on guns than the first, and you will encounter multiple levels with very little cover, plenty of open space, and a lot of goons with assault rifles and shotguns. The level design deteriorates later in the game focusing on ranged combat and, in my opinion, far too many windows. Let go of the blind instinct-based rushes in the first game. A brain with those strategies hardwired in will suffer in this one, but I still recommend the game, with all its gory violence and glorious songs. Remember, though, to be wary of windows.\n

reviewText:
Successful sequel to Hotline Miami.
The story gets very very interesting when you take your time to place the events in chronological order and understand it.
Gameplay wise, it's the same ol' Hotline Miami, but there are some additions that I like and dislike.

I like that one of the masks lets you  use two people at the same time, however I dislike that you can't control them both individually, even though it'll need a lot of coordination. I also dislike how enemy AI can't get attracted to Alex and attack him.
The fact that you unlock masks doesn't matter as the amount of characters you play just makes the masks you use different every level.

The mouse also gets very wonky, it can get stuck and go offscreen, hard to get used to, same with the character itself, it can go off screen and sometimes not be able to go back.

Overall, with all the problems, it's a 7/10.

reviewText:
Okay, so I've completed the game.
As a sidenote, I've played and understand the first Hotline Miami as well. I have 100% achievement completion.
Sadly, I won't be getting that in Hotline Miami 2.

The map design is horrible. Absolutely horrible. This should be a movie. I was just waiting for the cutscenes. Granted, the game has a few good levels, but they're few and far between. The story is exceptional and connects everything from the first with the second.

Sadly, I recommend this game. I probably shouldn't, but it's worth it for the story and the map editor that is coming later. The map design is horrendous.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing great.

I feared its release because Hotline Miami quickly became one of my favorite games after playing it.  If Hotline II wasn't as good, I would have been really upset.  Alas, my fears were for nought.  This sequel is just as Earth-shattering as its predecessor.

The Hotline series features some of the best rogue-like action in all of gamedom.  The pixel art is top-notch and the atmosphere created by said art perfectly fitting for the ethereal and dizzying plot you are thrown into.  This is another game that will make you sweat, possibly cause your heart to palpitate, and give you the adrenaline rush of a lifetime.  Every victory is hardwon and makes you feel like the biggest, baddest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the entire Universe.  New weapons, fighting styles and masks await you.

Not only are the gameplay and art supreme, but the soundtrack actually features music by really good musicians and drives the game.  The DJs from the original Hotline Miami soundtrack take turns remixing each other's work, so it's not perhaps a 100% original soundtrack, but it's worth picking up all the same.  This series is the first where I've actually listened to the soundtrack outside of playing the game or playing other games.  As someone who is an amateur musician and who grew up around professional musicians, I often find game soundtracks lacking, but this ♥♥♥♥ is good.  These DJs do 80's synth better than the ♥♥♥♥ing 80's.

Also, as a bonus, if you haven't yet purchased the game a level editor that was originally supposed to be released with the game has finally popped its head out of the ground.  I haven't tested it out yet, but the potential to edit levels in a HM game is highly intriguing to me.

Once again, one of my favorite games of all time.

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of the first Hotline Miami,finished it countless times and really enjoyed everything in it. And really,Hotline Miami 2 did not let me down,here is why:
+A lot of ♥♥♥♥ was left unanswered in the first game(wich i think was a fantastic thing),so lots ot theories came up trying to explain the game. And well,in hotline miami 2 you get to know it,things start to make sense and a lot of minor things that are said and shown in the first game have their importance in the sequel(*MINOR SPOILER HERE* For example what was that photo jacket was holding in the end of hotline miami *SPOILER ENDS HERE*). You get to know more about the characters background(the ones from the first game) and also what happened to them. The ending was hard to catch at first,but after you replay some missions and dig up some things everything feels connected.
+The Soundtrack is still great
+It felt confusing at first,but having lots of playable characters was a nice thing for me
-The one bad thing about the game and that has been said by EVERYONE. WHY THE ♥♥♥♥ ARE SOME AREAS SO BIG?  TOO MANY ♥♥♥♥ING WINDOWS! Most of the time you are in the end of a area you get shot by some random ♥♥♥♥ from the other side of the level. You have to camp too much and firearms are way too important in this game. One of the best things from the first game was going around a area kicking the ♥♥♥♥ out of everyone with all kinds of melee weapons while listening to some badass tunes,and in this game this kind of ♥♥♥♥ barely happens.

-Conclusion: It is a great game,brilliant like the first,i dont think i liked it more then the first but i definetely also loved it. Has a big flaw but it aint anything that you cant deal with.

reviewText: A very melancholy and nihilistic game focused on gruesome violence and horrible things happening to horrible people and somehow you still feel some pity… sometimes.  This game is more fractured than the original, frequently jumping between different times, characters, and locations.  The story takes a while to get into, and you need to play the first game to get the full emotional impact, but it is surprisingly good, thought provoking even.  If not very depressing.  Mechanically the game feels smoother for the most part, however I found myself frequently frustrated by enemies miles away killing me, getting stuck on furniture, and dying due to the crosshair jumping around after I killed an enemy it was locked onto.  Some new characters are fun, like the murder swans, but most play like Jacket… however dodge roll is kind of useless, it gets me killed more times than it saved me.  There are some odd level designs, and some levels overstay their welcome (like the boat level), but those minor issues aside, the game is pretty solid and a lot of fun, though it does make you feel a bit bad.  Beat it in 10 hours.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game, man...

tl;dr at the bottom

The Hotline Miami series is definitely one that you need to play in chronological order to fully understand the greatness of it - this game is an excellent, excellent, excellent follow up to the original Hotline Miami. It's just that, though - an excellent follow up. If you're interested in getting into this series, definitely start off with the first game.

I'm someone who actually prefers this game to the original, however. If you played the first game, the levels are more similar to the biker levels after Jacket's story wrapped up than the original Jacket style. If you haven't played the first game, stop reading this review and go play the first game because at this point in time this review is worthless to you.

In short, though - less focus on masks and varied gameplay styles and more focused on characters. It's less open ended as a result of this, and while removing the Jacket style in favor of characters with set abilities for each level is something I'd normally cry heresy over, this game manages to execute it extremely well to the point where I didn't even care that I wasn't given a huge variety of masks to choose from and had a lot of gameplay freedom taken away. This sounds much worse than it is, trust me - this game hits the nail on the head with what it's trying to do and it's excellent as a result.

It also is a lot more difficult than the first game, I think; the levels are larger and there can be a pretty serious loss of progress once you get towards the end and die, as opposed to the original's tendency to have smaller levels. As a result, there is a lot more enemies. There's also less masks, as I noted earlier, and that can create a handicap for those who relied on certain masks in the first game and being able to have more variety.

It's as violent as ever, thankfully. This game pulls no punches in how graphic it is, and it benefits from as much for certain. One of the things I love about both games of this series is that it gives me an outlet to battle stress by allowing me to vent my psychotic urges to just beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of anybody I can. Much blood, very graphic executions (except for evan lol), but I might just give the first game the edge in the gore and violence department if that much is your thing.

As for the story, it pieces a bunch of the events of the first game into context and gives them meaning, as the first game could be pretty incoherent and schizophrenic with the story it tried to tell. It was an effective stylistic choice, for certain, but this game serves as providing context for the events of the first game and it's why I'm telling you to go play the first game if you haven't played it yet. This game expects you to know the first game. Back on topic, though - the story is surprisingly powerful in this game. From memorable characters such as Richter to Beard to the Fans, it manages to show just how ♥♥♥♥ed up everything is in a way that has a lot of powerful moments. I don't want to spoil anything, so I won't go into any plot details, but the story is fantastic and surprisingly gave me the feels on a few occasions.

Lastly, the soundtrack - it's as ♥♥♥♥♥in' as ever. Seriously, the soundtrack is even better than the first game and can hit like a truck. This is seriously one of the greatest soundtracks in any game ever and I can totally get behind the soundtrack itself costing as much as the game - it's actually worth it.

tl;dr - this game expects you to know the first so go play that if you haven't already. If you have, there's an excellent story being told here alongside some absolutely amazing gameplay and one of the greatest soundtracks you'll find anywhere.

10/10, i liked hurting other people

reviewText:
This is a good game. Taken alone, however, it's worth is greatly diminished. A number of things must be considered before you can understand what to appropriately classify this game.

Reasonably, it can be understood that this game will never be able to live up to the expectations set by the first one. The story is too open, the understanding of this story is far too skewed and all over the place, the sound track is lacking in some places where HM had a perfect track record, and the level design is just plain lazy and challenging" in an uncreative way.

I love this game. I feel this way because I played the first one. If I hadn't of played the first one obsessively for the years it was out until I mastered it and then switched over to this game

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of the first Hotline Miami,finished it countless times and really enjoyed everything in it. And really,Hotline Miami 2 did not let me down,here is why:
+A lot of ♥♥♥♥ was left unanswered in the first game(wich i think was a fantastic thing),so lots ot theories came up trying to explain the game. And well,in hotline miami 2 you get to know it,things start to make sense and a lot of minor things that are said and shown in the first game have their importance in the sequel(*MINOR SPOILER HERE* For example what was that photo jacket was holding in the end of hotline miami *SPOILER ENDS HERE*). You get to know more about the characters background(the ones from the first game) and also what happened to them. The ending was hard to catch at first,but after you replay some missions and dig up some things everything feels connected.
+The Soundtrack is still great
+It felt confusing at first,but having lots of playable characters was a nice thing for me
-The one bad thing about the game and that has been said by EVERYONE. WHY THE ♥♥♥♥ ARE SOME AREAS SO BIG?  TOO MANY ♥♥♥♥ING WINDOWS! Most of the time you are in the end of a area you get shot by some random ♥♥♥♥ from the other side of the level. You have to camp too much and firearms are way too important in this game. One of the best things from the first game was going around a area kicking the ♥♥♥♥ out of everyone with all kinds of melee weapons while listening to some badass tunes,and in this game this kind of ♥♥♥♥ barely happens.

-Conclusion: It is a great game,brilliant like the first,i dont think i liked it more then the first but i definetely also loved it. Has a big flaw but it aint anything that you cant deal with.

reviewText: This game... this game is... this game is ♥♥♥♥ING AMAZING! Seriously, best soundtracks I've ever heard and most brilliant storyline I've ever seen! It's a shame that they won't make a third game for this sequel. Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number explains a lotta unexplained stuff in first Hotline Miami. This time you're not playing as Jacket or Biker. You get a chance to talk with the Biker after a scene but only for a little time. We have like 9 or 10 protagonists in Hotline Miami 2 and each has their own story. Some of them connected to Jacket but most of them connected to 50 Blessings. Game mostly explains what happens after the brutal events of Jacket and other masked vigilanties. You even get a chance to play as The Son - head of the Russian Mafia, son of the villain of first Hotline Miami. You also get a chance to play as Manny Pardo which is my favorite character due to his style and brutality. He's a detective and he kills people to get the attention of the media. He also his own detective which makes him a very interesting guy. You all remember that guy who gives us free stuff in first Hotline Miami, right? Well, you get to play as him, too! Long story short, buy this game, you won't regret it. It's one of the masterpieces in the world. Thanks to Dennaton.

reviewText:
*PLEASE READ THE WHOLE REVIEW*

This is worse than HM1, but only because of some issues that can be easily fixed.
+Art style
+Soundtrack
+Game length
+Story
+/-Gameplay (some mechanics were changed and are worse, but it is mostly the same)
-Bugs with A.I. (dogs spinning around, enemies getting stuck in doorways)
-Level design (too many guns and windows which encourage a slow, coward-ish playstyle)
How can Dennaton improve the game:
*Make it so that you can see EVEN further with shift (now it is mostly useless, as most of the time you still can not see ♥♥♥♥ because the levels are so huge)
*Tweak the levels a little (add more melee enemies, spawn weapons on the ground)
*Improve the A.I. (do not make it harder or easier, just fix the enemies being blind or having superhuman reflexes)
*Fix the bugs

Despite these problems, which I am sure that will be fixed, I still love the game and recommend it. 9/10

reviewText: It's like Hotline Miami only there's a lot more of it. The story has you switching between different characters some of which have unique abilities. The game is a bit harder than the first game on the earlier levels. More enemies have guns and the game is just as challenging as ever. However, you wont mind dying over and over again because the soundtrack is awesome. You can twitch shoot your way and go speedrunning through the levels, or you can strategize your attack and ambush enemies as you move room to room. You will probably end up having to play both ways regardless. If you've played the first game you are going to like this. If you haven't played the first game read up on it, and be prepared for a challenge.

reviewText:
There is something about this game that kind of puts you in a zen. You can clearly tell there is some deeper subplot going on, but it feels like a fever dream. In that regard, it's pretty interesting because you are constantly in this surreal stasis state of wtf and when you have answers, more questions arise. It is both a direct continuation from the first one, but also a prequel to. The gameplay is fairly similar to the first game. The big difference is you don't really have full control over the entire roster of masks. It's usually selecting from about 4 per character or mission. I know a lot of people will have issues with it, but I liked the reasoning behind it. It allowed things to be fresh, even if this DOES mean you don't get as much freedom in gameplay per mission as you used to.

I completed the game. I have no idea what to think as far as the story goes. I find the best thing to do (for my sanity) is to NOT think about it. Maybe come back to it again, pay more attention to the dialogue and whatnot. But knowing the developer, maybe it is as simple as the game doesn't HAVE a point really.

I am going to recommend this if you are a fan of the first game. It's more of the same, less of the freedom of gameplay, but a longer experience. Also harder.

reviewText:
Linux input issues are now fixed for me. So finally I can recommend this game! The Linux port seems to be well done so far, kudos to Abstraction Games. It runs reasonable on my ancient laptop with Nvidia propietary driver, with OpenGL 2.1.2 (you don't neccessarily need OpenGL 3.2, however I play windowed mode in 1024x768 or something on my wooden PC.)

About the game itself I agree with most positive reviews. The game's pacing is different than the first game, but I like it, because I wanted more than a few new maps/levels for the first game. ...and dat soundtrack! (comes in mp3 and flac and is two times larger than the game itself.)

Only thing missing is a non-binary text config file like hotline.cfg for HLM1, e.g. for more custom windowed resolution modes. Devs saying this will come with a future patch, so far the file window.dat is binary. Yeah, I played 50 hours of HLM1 in 640x480 window with black borders and I enjoyed it.

And a DLC/checkbox in the >properties tab (Steam library) would be nice, to disable the Soundtrack's download temporarily, if you have it already elsewhere and don't want to re-download the 2GB again and again.

reviewText:
There's no doubt Hotline Miami was and still is one of the best games I ever played, that's a fact.
But I never thought that a sequel could actually surpass it and despite my disbelief, Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is an improvement on what was already a tremendous game.
The gameplay is better in my opinion, the story is more engaging and the soundtrack is just as amazing as Hotline Miami's soundtrack.
Like Hotline Miami, Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number it's a highly addictive game that will keep you busy and provide plenty of fun.
This is a game I highly recommend, it's just great in every possible way.

reviewText:
There is something about this game that kind of puts you in a zen. You can clearly tell there is some deeper subplot going on, but it feels like a fever dream. In that regard, it's pretty interesting because you are constantly in this surreal stasis state of wtf and when you have answers, more questions arise. It is both a direct continuation from the first one, but also a prequel to. The gameplay is fairly similar to the first game. The big difference is you don't really have full control over the entire roster of masks. It's usually selecting from about 4 per character or mission. I know a lot of people will have issues with it, but I liked the reasoning behind it. It allowed things to be fresh, even if this DOES mean you don't get as much freedom in gameplay per mission as you used to.

I completed the game. I have no idea what to think as far as the story goes. I find the best thing to do (for my sanity) is to NOT think about it. Maybe come back to it again, pay more attention to the dialogue and whatnot. But knowing the developer, maybe it is as simple as the game doesn't HAVE a point really.

I am going to recommend this if you are a fan of the first game. It's more of the same, less of the freedom of gameplay, but a longer experience. Also harder.

reviewText:
A true masterpiece. Still some big disadvantages are:
- Inability to see the whole map of a level, resulting in enemies killing you without even seeing them.
- The 2 swans won't always follow each other closely, resulting in the chainsaw swan moving without the other swan supporting her.
- Beard, who is the soldier, can't pick up new weapons, leaving him almost undefended whenever he has no ammo left (he still has his knife, but can't do anything against bullets or the big guys).
Other than that, it's a great game, with a lot of violence and some black humor too. It is very hard to complete, resulting in countless deaths before successfully finishing it - but that's a good thing. The music is great and the storyline is also great. Good job, developers. :)

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 has put me in an odd predicament for a review.

If you played the original as a stealthy player--like me--then you'll find the game unforgivably broken due to the original's problems becoming worse. Also, if you liked the extremely vague plot with no purpose in the end, then you might find the sequel's" context to get in the way.

On the other hand
date: I inevitably came to love the game when I gave up my old style. I found replaying old levels like Rambo (though cautious) more enjoyable
recommended: and it helped me finish the rest of the game. As for the story
hoursPlayed: I couldn't understand the first game's plot besides its nihilistic message about game narratives when it comes to the mechanics. So having more context and characters was a bonus.\n\nI guess the easiest way to recommend this title is if you can appreciate the changes made from HLM1
voteText: then you'll love HLM2. If you prefer the classic's style of narrative and gameplay
helpfulPercent:
then you probably should stay with the original.

Still An Eyestrain
The same problems with lacking options for visuals are apparent in the sequel.

So if bright lights
votesHelpful: motion-swaying and changing colors in the background bother you
votesTotal: then I don't think this series is one you should play. And if you thought the camera-swaying was bad in the original
votesFunny: then you have not used a sniper-rifle in HLM2. It's vomit-inducing.\n\nHowever
commentsCount: the developers did add rebindable keys for all characters' actions--except for the dodge-roll which is mapped to the execute button--so it's a step-up from the original. Though I'm surprised there aren't more PC pitchforks raised at this series.\n\n(There's also a "graphic content" setting that disables a two-second ♥♥♥♥ scene at the start. I don't care that the content is in the game nor the setting to turn it off. My question is what was the point of adding that to the game--or the character--because it doesn't feel relevant to the rest of the narrative. Nor is there any visual penetration to make it that graphic. In the end
column16:
it just comes across as needlessly edgy.)

Smooth Consistency from Start to End
The best change from its predecessor is that the whole game now plays like a top-down "tactical" murder-puzzle shooter. There are three basic enemy types--two from the first title and a new one that is immune to bullets--and there's a better focus on creating variety throughout the game with a smaller number of "masks"/playable characters.

Gone is the curve-balling car that spawns enemies
column17: the unkillable police-forces ambushing you with sniper-rifles aimed at the windows
column18: and the god-awful bosses that break the rules of the HLM1. (There is only one boss-level in HLM2 with several bosses
column19: and they follow the same rules like other enemies.) Now we have a game that has consistent challenge.\n\nNow we get 24/25  similar levels that can last anywhere from under a minute to 15+ minutes. For the average person
column20: there is probably 7+ hours of content
column21: minimum
column22: which is more than replaying HLM1 three-times. This is excluding the "Hard" mode
column23: which not only flips the levels upside down but adds more enemies and takes away the aim-lock button.\n\nSo if the game is more of HLM1
column24:
then why does it also feel like a step-back from the previous game?

Being Literally Thrown with the Rule-Book
The main source of complaint is how HLM2 has taken away your options for how you play. As previously mentioned
column25: you cannot get through this game playing conservatively all the time.\n\nThis problem comes from several sources: Having to play 10 playable characters--but not all are always available-- having three distinct "styles" of play
column26: the nurfing of melee weapons
column27: and the rules for some characters being thrown like a book to your face.\n\nThe reason for having so many characters is because of how the narrative is told in HLM2. Because the first game wasn't confusing enough
column28: the sequel is a side-story
column29: a prequel and a conclusion all in one. Changing from from one scene to the next randomly also alters the way you can play.\n\nSome characters you'll play have nothing special about them other than limitations. For example
column30: the soldier character can only use one gun that he equips and he must find specific ammo boxes to get more. Or there's the news reporter who refuses to use guns unless you execute someone. These limitations are quite annoying when the game plays consistently throughout the whole game
column31: forcing you to change your playstyle because the developers made it that way.\n\nWhen you do have options
column32: such as when you're playing as the Fans
column34: they all boil down to No Weapons (Fists only)
column35: start off with guns (or a nailgun)
column36: or you get some quirk that works with only one character. For example
column37: there are these twins James & Ash that can be played simaltaneously as a glass-cannon of destruction.\n\nAll together
column38: these changes go against a lot of what was appealing of the original. Masks gave you small bonuses but didn't limit your playstyle. Some even offered a new challenge. Best of all
column39: these masks were available from beginning to end
column40: excluding the hospital scene. That was enough to offer replayability
column41: and the point is none of it was forced on you.\n\nNow whether these changes were made to make tighter levels and/or to tailor them for specific playstyles
column42:
the result is that the whole game can feel abrupt with its difficulty and give less of a reason to replay every level.

Sins of the Father Burdened to the Son
Perhaps the worst change is how the new level design has made the original's problems worse. AI behavior is finicky at best
column43: unfair at worst; enemies will shoot you beyond your line of sight all the time; and choosing the right weapon in the middle of the moment can get you killed.\n\nUnfortunately
column44: like what you'd expect from sequels
column45: HLM2 goes for the approach that bigger is always better. Instead of adding more floors/checkpionts in-between these each level
column46: the game goes for making huge environments while using the same checkpoint system.\n\nThe larger environments simply do not work with the the enemy AI. This problem isn't sucking at the game or the trial-and-error gameplay of HLM1. Mooks can spot you a mile away from windows at an angle or two screens away
column47: some of which will require a specific tactic to kill.\n\nThis problem will lead to needless deaths
column48: which far outways the abuse if you could see enemies all the time. And because the AI can sometimes be unpredictable
column49:
your"solution" can sometimes feel unsatisfying or pure luck.

More Cryptic than the Wasteland
As for the story of HLM2... I like it
column50: especially how it doesn't ruin the story for HLM1. The plot is ultimately the same result as the first game
column51: a tale about nothing learned (in-game). However
column52: now you have actual characters developed instead of characterizations being hinted at or unexplained.\n\nThe story will still make no sense your first playing--especially if you have not finished the first game or read the comic--because of how unorderly the narrative is told. It's a story that you'll piece together clues and dates either by noting them down yourself or by looking up videos on YouTube.  What I can say is that the narrative gives more substance to characters like Beard/Register-Man
column53: Jacket (and Richard?) and the 50 Blessings.\n\nThe narrative could be clearer if there was a name listed to every face. You'll have to remember details like that
column54: and note weird lines in relation to something maybe an hour later. And you'll probably still end up with more questions than answers--but the story is actually very interesting
column55: and it could still be interpretted from various angles.\n\nPerhaps Not the Best Sequel
column56: Though Still Good\nAlthough I am not a fan of the series
column57: I'm glad I finished HLM2. It's the apex of what made the original so good yet also bad."

reviewText: Honestly, compared to it's predecessor, Hotline Miami 2 keeps a lot of the same elements, such as the dynamic and awesome OST, the visuals, and basic gameplay elements. The story is in vein of the last game, however, this game still distinguishes itself. The gameplay difficulty has a singificant rampup from the previous, so even the most hardened players will have some challenge in mastering this game, and certain levels will definitely put a grip on your testicles (or ovaries, in case I'm being unfair). New powers such as a roll and a mask that creates 2 players allows you to change up the flow of the game. The OST is also more intense and even arguably better than the original Hotline Miami, which suits the cranking up the intensity of the game. If you loved Hotline Miami 1, this game will be everything you hoped for and more. Features that I have not yet even used like the level editior are sure to add to the replay value of the game too.\n\nIf you are deciding between the 2 games now, I'd say go for Hotline Miami 1 then get Hotline Miami 2 later, due to the fact that Hotline Miami is a tad easier and helps set up the mood for the sequel. I will probably update this review when I progress farther in the game (finished the first 2 axts so far).

reviewText:
WARNING : This game will make you hate dogs , fat people , samurais and windows .

I said Hotline Miami was a piece of art .

And holy ♥♥♥♥ , Hotline Miami 2 was a blast as well .

Let's start with the most essential point :

GAMEPLAY
Basically the same mechanics as the first episode , mostly .
The difference comes from the variety of characters you have . Among them : A soldier who chooses a main weapon between five ; the fans , who each have a unique skill (which are all useful as long as you're not awful in this game . Yeah , sorry , fan haters) ...
One interesting addition is the writer , with his non-lethal style , where you only have to knock off the ennemies , either with bare hands or with melee swing . Picking up ennemy guns will make the character empty the weapon , leaving it unusable so no ennemy can pick it up .
As before , you have the choice between melee and weapons , BUT some ennemies will require you to switch of style . Remember those fat guys only vulnerable to bullets ? Now there is -in extremely rare occasions though- ennemies who only dies from melee attacks , somehow dodging bullets . The lovely dogs are still here too . The devs knew you wanted them . One issue with the melee system , however , is the executions . They take quite much more time than in the previous game , and supposing you don't finish an ennemy the moment after you killed another , your combo will be broken , so you better be sure all your swings are lethal and that you don't abuse doors too much .
But going fully melee isn't recommended anyway , giving the enormous floors . You WILL have to use guns sometime .  Remember the Assault level in the first game ? Well there are several levels this big in HM2 . Full of windows that allows the ennemies to see you and shoot you dead before you can say FU** .
Which brings another point : The difficulty .
So far , I've only cleared the game on Normal difficulty . And god , it makes HM1 look like a tutorial episode .
This game is pure Trial & Error . You're going to need skill , level knowledge and both patience and nerves to get through the game . Because holy ♥♥♥♥ , Hotline Miami 2 does NOT fogive mistakes . But that's part of the game . The feeling of satisfaction after completing a level is that great .
So , maybe there are different mechanics , but that's part of the work ! When you want a sequel , you want something different , not just a refresh , right ? It's not that the level design is poor . It's purposely made to make you try again and again , until you can clear the perfect run .
Especially if you go for the A+/S rank in each level .



SCENARIO
I don't know where to begin . It's both satisfying and disapointing . Just by the way it ended .
It's not a focus about one character we have , but around many , quite like the everyday life of an apocalyptic Miami threatened by the conflict between 50 blessings and the Russian mafia , after the traumatism caused by Jacket's actions , that more or less started it all . The storyline happens to be way more tragic than the first episode (Just look at the contrast between HM1 and HM2's menu theme) and  DO NOT ATTACH TO CHARACTERS . You're warned .  .
There is a lot of new characters and story arcs , which or all more or less connected , and all related to Jacket in some way . The latter is not playable , but you're going to hear about him .
The backstory is complete , mostly with little elements this and there (the dates and the journals) that might confuse the player who didn't look for them before the ending .
Last point for the scenario part :
The ending was pretty disapointing , particularly because it happens right after a very well-thought finale . I mean , come on , there was better than just that .
Well at least they said the conclusion would be brutal and they didn't lie . And the fake teaser at the end proved the ending . But it's just ... mean .



SOUNDTRACK

Holy mother of Jesus . I didn't know till there that ears could have an erection . It's no less than 49 tracks in there , for the pure pleasure of your ears , and each level plays a different one , unlike the first Hotline Miami . 30 artists joined this massive ear candy made of electro , with some veterans of the first such as M|O|O|N , Jasper Byrne , Perturbator and El Huervo . You'd guess , as I'm writing all of this , I'm still listening to the OST . I don't really have words for it , they wouldn't be able to represent the greatness of those sounds .



I do believe the main points have all been exposed . There are a few cons to the game though - even though minor ones. Some bugs involving doors , where some ennemies will happen to get stuck and have ... what seems to be a seizure , I don't know . There has been report of dogs going through walls , but it didn't happened to me .  however the unarmed prisonners managed to jump on me , completely ignoring the doors , quite a lot of time . Truely irritating considering this level is already hell .
The IA is still like before , with some ennemies stopping to chase you after a certain point  well god thanks that allows the player to breath sometimes  .


Overall , Hotline Miami 2 is an over-the-top game , and strongly recommended for those who loved Hotline Miami 1 . Why not to newbies ? Because they should first play Hotline Miami 1 , so they can understand the context , and be trained for what is going to be a hard , hard trip .
Yes , there were some changes , without completely metamorphozing the game mechanics , but that's what make it a whole new episode rather than an extension . There were answers , there was a completion and explanation to HM1's events , there was a solid gameplay , an insane difficulty and a lot of pixelated blood : All the elements that makes a Hotline Miami .

reviewText:
Below you'll find a written and video impression on the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SefnwJ_OKOI

Before I start I want to mention that I've never played the first Hotline Miami, so this impression will be from some one who's new to the series, and have judged it under the game's own merit.

Hotline Miami 2 is a top-down perspective action game. If you've played the classic GTAs, you'll be quite familiar with this. Unlike GTA, the game isn't so much open world as it is mission to mission. You'll be brutally gunning down or beating up your enemies. But it's not quite as simple as holding down a trigger and win. The game is challenging where all it takes is one shot to end your game.

Hotline Miami's visual is of some of the best I've seen in pixel art. It's similar to what you might of seen from the 16 bit era, but refined to great detail. The game is brutal, violent, and gory, and it takes a lot of skill to represent that degree of grotesque in 16 bits, as the resolution doesn't leave the artist much room for error. The visuals are vibrant and all cohesively themed in an 80s retro style. It's gorgeous! The audio is of an equal quality with one of the best OST in recent memory.

Though a game like this, that feel quite arcady, can often get away with little to no story. Hotline Miami 2 takes the high road and offers an engrossing narrative that goes much deeper than a simple crime drama. With out spoilers, it goes into the delusional, and I'd compare it to the psychological thriller genre. But do be aware, it also explores some extremely dark and adult themes. This is not a game for children or those who are easily offended.

There's much to love about Hotline Miami 2, but it doesn't get away with out flaws that's worth pointing out. The game does have some bugs, not many, but some and when they appear, they're noticeable. Also the enemy AI, though passable, could be improved on, as they're not always reacting realistically.

Overall, Hotline Miami 2 is a great game that's worth every penny it's asking for. It's challenging, looks and sounds amazing, and brutally honest in it's story telling. I can not recommend this any more!

Pros:
- Great visuals and audio
- Challenging and skillful gameplay
- Engrossing story
- Varied player classes to mix things up
- Addictive and satisfying

Cons
- Some bugs
- AI can react unrealistically at times

reviewText:
SIKE, THAT’S THE WRONG NUMBER

Alright, now that I’ve referenced the meme everybody else who’s played this game has, it’s time for me to ramble about a game that I love. Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is the second title in the Hotline Miami series, and it is hella tight.

It’s a top down kill ‘em up where you enter a building, kill everybody, then leave. What makes it “unique” is how every enemy dies in one hit, as does yourself. However, dying in Hotline Miami isn’t something to be afraid of as you can just hit that R button to retry in an instant.

Because of the whole “nobody has any health” thing, it makes the whole game fast paced. Each moment leads into the next on what you’re going to have to do to make everybody but yourself die, planning out each step right in the moment. It’s almost a puzzle game with top-down shooter elements.

The story itself is actually really well written and aligns very nicely with HM1. It’s told in a nonlinear fashion similar to that of Tarantino’s Pulp Fiction and Vonnegut’s Slaughterhouse Five. And for people who don’t really care for it, it’s easy to just skim over it and get right back into the game.

The hard mode in the game is actually a real “hard mode”, where the enemies are smarter and the levels are altered just right to make them brutal compared to their normal mode counterparts.

However, there are a few issues that hard mode highlights in the game. This review is may be a thumbs up, but I’m going to go over what this game got wrong because that’s easier to do than what the game got right.

The first thing I noticed when playing this game was its slower than the original. At first I thought it was just the slower executions, leaving you vulnerable for longer periods of time when dealing with downed enemies, but it was more than that.

This game features a great deal more of open areas than its predecessor did, leaving you in a lot of situations where you just get shot by enemies that are off the screen as they can see farther than you can. This makes the game a bit more cautious, and as a result making it slower. Walking around in these big open spaces is a lot scarier than it was in HM1, rather than blazing your way through tightly made levels like in the first.

Also, with bigger rooms comes greater numbers of enemies. A lot of the difficulty in this game comes from just packing the level full of enemies for you to deal with. This combined with the larger areas makes it pretty scary to walk around in open hallways.

Not to mention the high number of windows as well. Windows in this game are basically just walls that can be seen through, as well as shot through. With so little walls to hide behind, you’re just begging to be shot in these levels.

There’s also a lot more gunplay rather than melee. With open areas with lots of enemies who also have guns that can see you through most of the level, there’s pretty much nothing you can use but guns. Especially with the big guys that come at you that can only be killed by bullet. Sure there’s the melee enemies that are able to dodge bullets, but those are used to sparingly compared to the big guys and really tips the scale to mostly using guns rather than melee, which is really what set the pace for HM1.

This kind of level design in the game slowed it down to just hiding behind corners with a machine gun in hand, plowing down all the idiot AIs that come around to add themselves to the massive pile of bodies.

Another separate issue, which wasn’t a big problem for me as I never really played with masks in HM1, but there was way less mask variety in this game than in the last. Since you played as characters rather than just Jacket with all this masks (the main character in HM1), you had way less choice in what specialties you had when entering a level. I’m sure for a lot of people this was a heavy hitter, but I personally didn’t mind.

The game’s difficulty is on a whole new level than what HM1 was. HM1’s difficulty is very gradual throughout the entire game, going through the entire spectrum of easy to hard, but this game starts off difficulty wise a little more than halfway through HM1’s difficulty, and it’s likely due to those slowing level design choices. I didn’t find that too particularly bad since I played the crap outta HM1, but for any newcomers it could be off putting.

A smaller gripe would be that the soundtrack didn’t really do it for me. HM1 had a lot of songs that stuck with me as favorites which led me to actually buy to music to listen to on the go, but none of the songs really stuck out for me in HM2 for listening to outside of the game. After my first playthrough of the story I muted the music and listened to my own stuff, HM1 soundtrack included.

Aside from that, the game is amazing. Just by simply being another Hotline Miami game, it more than enough makes up for the poor design choices. If I were to give the game a letter grade, I’d give it an A-. Enough for me to dedicate way too much time into score/time attacking, not to mention the level editor that’s to come out soon which I’ll probably play for only a few hundred hours.

Should you buy the game? If you’re new to the series I’d suggest starting out with the first game, really just because it’s easier and it introduces you to the Hotline Miami world. HM2 started off as a mod for HM1, later made into a standalone experience, so it was made from the ground up to be played by people who’ve already dipped their toes into the series. If you’ve already played HM1 and liked it, great! You’re going to love HM2, as it’s really just an expansion on what HM1 was.

tl;dr:

It’s Hotline Miami, just with more Hotline Miami. If you liked the first one, you’ll likely be a fan of Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number.
