reviewText:
Alright, pro's and con's outt'a the way real quick.

+ Wonderful soundtrack, my goodness.
+ Improved engine and art.
+ Underrated story, with a lot of key elements for the Hotline Miami universe.
+ Neat environments and unique characters.
+ A pacifist character!!!
+ Not gonna lie, I really dig the ' flipped level ' aspect of Hard Mode.
+/- Not really a whole lott'a options for masks, and ' masks '. Some characters don't even have 'em.
- Adding onto that, restrictive gameplay. Late game is ranged central. Melee may as well not exist from Act 4 and upwards. Remember that pacifist character I mentioned? In order to beat a Hard Mode level as him, you have to go against that mechanic.
- Atrocious AI
- Windows are no ones enemy, it's how they're centered around almost all the ' difficult ' aspects of this games challenging demeanor that makes them such a toxic mechanic.
- Doors are practically a bug altogether.

Do I recommend this game to people who like/are interested in Hotline Miami, and wanna get more into it story AND gameplay wise? Yeah, man.

Do I recommend this game to people who want a similar experience to Hotline Miami 1? Who want to ♥♥♥♥♥ it out, get all their achievements and do everything there is to do? No. Get it while it's on sale or something.

Starting off, I have Achievement ♥♥♥♥♥'d both games. I've done all there is to do, and I've seen it all. I've sat for hours on end, getting my A+'s. I've grinded the kills for Genocide. I've felt the relief of walking into that golden, rainbow pathed gate at the end of Hard Mode Apocalypse. And I wish I could say I regret all of it, because the more time I put into this game, the more I hated it.

Before Act 3, the game actually has great level design. Moving Up is one of my personal favorites, and there isn't really any other level like it. There seems to be an ebb and flow to all of it, until you hit Dead Ahead. This is where you're introduced to the sloppily thought out room design, annoying enemy rotations, frustrating window placement and clunky AI.

Yes, it's kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to constantly compare the sequel to it's shorter predecessor, but it's kind of important to my reasoning. Hotline Miami 1 was short and sweet. The difficulty left you blaming yourself, and it felt good to learn from your mistakes. You could rush in, and be done in no time at all-- Because you learned the area, you got comfortable with your actions, and learned from your previous ones. Hotline Miami 2 was an RNG-based bait fest, filled with intentionally placed windows that completely throw you off your groove and result in yet another frustratin off-screen or sudden death.

The magic of Hotline Miami 1 was how much it could afflict a player within it's short, action-packed levels. Hotline Miami 2 just wants to see how long it can drag its fingernails across the chalkboard of a droned out, lengthy level filled with lengthy boards that want you to play by it's rules. Every level in the sequel is like a puzzle that you can only solve one way, and one way only-- Through means of large enemies, dogs, unique enemies and windows. This becomes very apparent in Hard Mode.

Again, this is a good game. It's just... kind'a lazily made. I doubt I'll return to it for level editor, as I've had my fair enough share of blood and neon. I'm not gonna give it a rating, because it's sorta different for everyone. I'll repeat, if you want a new experience and are overall new to Hotline Miami, go for it. If you're a veteran who craves more, wait for the fanmade mods Midnight Animal and Hotline Miami:Redial to quench your thirst for combo's and anger.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami holds an extremely special place in my heart. It is the first game that compelled me to tell others how fantastic it is, and the reason I started my Lets Play channel. In the past year, some clever marketing by Devolver Digital has revved up the anticipation for Hotline Miami 2 beyond belief. It went from a nicely polished but largely unknown gorefest to a game nearing “mainstream” success while retaining the edge that is quite literally shaping the series. The game wasn’t just carried by marketing of course, the slick controls serve the top-down shooter/stealth/brawler hybrid extremely well. As I danced my way through the stages, I found myself painting like Pollock, on every inch of screen available. Punch a guy in the head, use his gun until it’s spent, fling said gun through a window and kill another dude with it. Glorious. Dance the dance of death with me while I dig a little deeper into Hotline Miami 2.

The best part about both games is undoubtedly the music. I could write for days on how well the pulsing synth and kicking bass positively accentuates the glorious neon frenzy that is unfolding on the screen. Aside from fantastic electro, Hotline Miami 2 features a number of ambient tracks during the dialogue scenes. The ambient music is generally rather eerie, and while I don’t particularly enjoy them as much as some of the more banging tracks, they do serve the aesthetic of a mask-wearing psychopath extremely well. The level of detail in this game is as impressive as ever too. My mind was absolutely blown when I walked by a rack of clothing and it spun as I brushed by it. It doesn’t affect anything about the gameplay, it’s purely meant to immerse you deeper and such small details carry the game a very long way in that regard.

The original Hotline Miami offered masks which had a variety of effects from augmenting your walking speed to spawning you with a weapon. Hotline Miami 2 takes this mechanic to a whole new extreme with a massive load of new masks and abilities. Some do seem a bit gimmicky, such the twin swans who operate as a unit, but overall the slew of new masks to pick from is extremely satisfying. Some masks are inherently better than others, but that was also true in the original game. Then again, what is inherently better for a character who enjoys brawling might not suit a player who prefers an old-fashioned shooting rampage. This freedom is what defined the original Hotline Miami, and unfortunately some of that was stripped away in the sequel. When playing as the swans you aren’t able to pick up any new weapons. Ammo can only be found in specified crates, and this castrates much of the freedom the original offered.

While the gimmicks involved with a few of the masks seems to be a poor choice, there is very little else to nitpick about this game. Some of the sound effects are a bit generic or repetitive, and the fun factor is knocked down a bit due to the frustrating difficulty. Overall Hotline Miami 2 is a blast to play and will keep me coming back to try and top the global scoreboard for a long time to come. The actual gameplay feels a lot less luck-based than the original installment. The storyline is also much more gripping this time around, though it does Tarantino around an awful lot. There is some controversy over a ♥♥♥♥ scene that appears in the game, but after stomping a series of five bad guy’s heads like grapes in an old I Love Lucy episode, I didn’t find myself overly phased by it. The entire game is a trip, and one totally worth experience. Just be sure to hide it from your kids.

Gameplay:

Controls- 9/10
Fun Factor- 8/10
Difficulty- 10/10
Replayability- 10/10
Innovation- 9/10

Aesthetic:

Graphics- 9/10
Music- 10/10
Sound FX- 7/10
Story/Lore- 9/10
Level Design- 4/10

Final Score: 85/100 for music, gameplay, and replayability.
Summary: Magical musical psychopathic gorefest.

reviewText:
This game is PURE TRASH; i've played and completed HM1 with extreme joy,but this one...well.

Why you shouldn't buy that :

1) A key ability here is to be able to move with precision and rapidity . You'll be prevented to do that here as the game is heavily bugged and very often you'll get stuck in doors and corners,causing you an insta-death by enemies' hands.

2) The game came up TOO WAY early because of Payday2 Hype Train and MANY MANY bugs still haven't been fixed; the game itself crashed for no reason and came out without any achievements; also...in the first 3 days HM2 had like 15 updates used to fix major issues ---> BAD PARENTING FROM DEVELOPERS

3) The game should have been released with the level editor included. I don't see anything here.

4) Controls are ♥♥♥♥ed up as they're woody and slow; i've already mentioned that you'll often get stuck into doors or small wall holes...but even if you don't get stuck...you'll loose 1-2 seconds everytime just to get into rooms just because the game itself doesn't help your charachter into passing into the right path.

5) The story ruins the game mechanics ; the plot is not showed in a chronological order and you'll have to switch from different charachters from a different time window everytime. On the long period can be QUITE puzzling; i had to check a guide to understand the whole story of HM1 and HM2.

6) Masks and Masks' Skills : they're quite terrible and moronic. Just few examples:

a : chainsaw brothers : one brother has a chainsaw ( OP as F**K) and the other one holds a gun...problem is...aiming with the other brother is a pain in the ♥♥♥!!! Loosing time aiming will lead you to death most of the time

b : Mafia Boss' Son  abilities : they just copy-pasted other abilities that the previous charachters had. Devs were too lazy to come up with something better / more creative

c : Soldier : he can start with 40 ammo rounds,but after he picks ammo from ammo crates after u've ran out of them...his ammo capacity will be halved. W-H-Y? That makes no sense.

7) Enemies : no innovations from the previous one,except for the crazy prisoners.

8) Bugged enemies : sometimes they won't charge you when you're next to them,sometimes they will chase you to the South Pole. You're able to kill enemies from closed doors,windows and WALLS punching them. YEAH .

9) Weapons : the numeber of melee and long range weapons that tou can use has been dramatically decreased,lowering levels' variety. You'll be able to use 3-4 melee weapons only.

10)  Masks :

Hotline Miami 1 : 27 masks
Hotline Miami 2 : 9  masks

11)  Achievement Hunting : as an achievement hunter i think that putting into this game  Kill 50.000 enemies " objective was totally insane. Skill has to be awarded
date: not humiliating grinding .\n\n12) Bosses : forget the fire-van from hotline miami 1
recommended:
forget the biker and all those crazy henchmen. Only one easy boss here.

13) Hard Mode : see it by yourself.

14) Level Design :

HM1 :  small rooms and good levels where you could try and have a little experimentation
HM2 : HUGE LEVELS with windows everywhere ---> rat race with a single-possible way to be played.

Hotline Miami 2 is a H-U-G-E failure."

reviewText:
-Digital Special Edition review-

It has the things that made the first Hotline Miami great:
+Soundtrack is the best .
+The gameplay is fast-paced and difficult.
+The characters have unique abilities that change the way you play.
+The animation has improved for the most part (a rolling head when you decapitated a thug).

The bad part?
-Some few minor bugs and few levels are too big and open.
-Sometimes have random difficulty spikes instead of the game being gradually more difficult as you progress.
-Story is a bit slow-paced.


Well worth buying the special digital edition to play as Jacket in Payday 2.

reviewText:
One of the first things I noticed about Hotline Miami 2 was that its soundtrack felt slower to me, more cinematic and larger in scope. I think that best encapsulates HLM2: larger in scope. A lot about this game won't make sense on your first play through, you will curse frequently and the playstyle you were used to is no longer effective in this game. Still, this game builds on what made the first one great and offers a ton more replayability for those who want it.

Moving on to level design, because this is a controversial talking point for this game, I am ambivalent. Hotline 1 feels claustrophobic compared to this game. There is a lot more space to run and maneuver, which becomes important the more that gunplay gets involved. Because practically every enemy has guns, levels are no longer small hallways. There is a lot more happening in the background now too. You'll notice it most in the second scene, but it's present all over the game. Set pieces that tip over or rotate as you move past them. You'll also notice A TON OF WINDOWS have now been added to the game. I personally found some levels to be extremely frustrating, but I also learned more about how the game works (like using windows to my advantage). As someone who appreciates a game that teaches players, I ultimately enjoyed this aspect.

They've stopped that annoying camera bobbing thing that made 1 feel like it was floating in a pool of water, but they didn't pull the camera back. Because so many enemies with guns appear off screen, you will frequently die from bullets shot by guns you can't see. That means mastering, or becoming familiar with, shift looking is crucial. Failure to shift look will extend your play time by several excruciating hours. Stop resisting shift look because you can snipe with pistols from across the map.

This is a game built for perfectionists and speedrunners. That unforgiving difficulty is why NES games like Ninja Gaiden live on in our hearts. It's not about finishing the level, anyone can do that with a simple game of peek-a-boo as has been pointed out on these forums. It's about discovering methods to lure and murder in groups. Combos are so much more effective (and harder to get) in this game, and boldness and flexibility scores actually matter. This game, when played at a high level, is all about speed and flexibility. You can dodge bullets now, something that was virtually impossible in part one.

I have come to the realization that the story is like an homage to Drive. If you've ever seen that movie, it's easy to find yourself left with a lot of questions about the characters you just met. Much like in HLM1, where the world is not quite what it seems. For instance, the community has yet to come to a consensus on how much of HLM1 happened in Jacket's real life and how much was a coma dream. There are two stories happening here: what you actually see and how it fits into the scope of the Hotline Miami timeline. The latter is what makes the story rewarding, because the former is quite jumbled and in some cases very abrupt.

Those who want to replay a game and learn it will find the experience of Hotline Miami 2 to be a frustrating climb to a satisfying top. Those expecting a fun and twitchy murder simulator that lasts for a few hours might find themselves disappointed by this experience.

Ask yourself which of these gamers you are before you buy this game.

[[*Edit: A note on hard mode. I thought it was too hard, like suck the fun out of the game hard. I'll probably finish it because I'm kind of a super fan of this game, but I am not enjoying that part at all.]]

reviewText:
The first half of this review contains no spoilers the second will, I will warn you when the spoiler part starts.
So firstly my thoughts: I first bought and played Hotline Miami a couple months ago and completely fell in love with it, the graphics were perfect, the music a big bonus, the controls were simple for anyone to learn it and the difficulty hard like it should be and with Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number they get all this right again and improved on the story aspect making it 10 times as good as the first in my mind, the new weapons blend in nicely, but I normally used the original shotgun when I could. This game reminded me of the biker missions in the way that every character is different in some way, e.g. the cop seemed more like Jacket, but his friend who I nicked name the pacifist only used blunt weapons to knock out opponents which made fighting anyone with a gun a problem (My least favourite moments). The difficulty has increased for sure in this game, in the first game I made it through levels dying once or twice and in the first level I died over and over reminding me of playing some of the last levels in the Jacket missions for the first time. I loved all the missions with Tony and the mask gang they were very fun with all the different masks, my favourite being the twins.
Now spoilers ahead since this is the part where I review the story.
On a story stand point this game is great, it tells a detailed story from many characters, but sometimes I wanted to learn more about certain characters like what happened to Jacket, I understand he went to jail and all but maybe a bit more information would have been nice. Other than that I quite liked it, the writer was found out more about the guy you kill as Jacket in the mission assault and I like that we see the stories of the different people from the original game, like the guy who you see in a couple of places in the Jacket story and how he was in Afghanistan, or that one fat guy you see shaving his head in the bathroom in one of the times you go into the bar in the first game. The amount of unexpected things in this game were crazy, one of my favourite missions has to be the final one Apocalypse was very fun and showed the head of the Russian mod killing all of the mask gang, I did like how they showed the different abilities they had, like with the twins, one head moved towards you attacking you with the chainsaw but looking like a head, the other trying to stay away shooting at you. The ending was perfect for this game, with the nukes going off and everyone dying, or did they because the final thing that happens which sort of annoyed me was the sneaky little thing they did hinting at a third game by putting you in the title screen of Hotline Miami 3 and then a couple seconds later rewinding and going back to Hotline Miami 2 title screen which I also found entertaining.
So what I thought, with everything said above I will give this game a 9/10 this game did very well to show what it wanted to show, but I just wanted more story about Jacket, other than that the story had some faults killing off a lot of characters before we learnt more about why they do what they did and I found that a bit sad.

reviewText: Unless you are a god at the game (speedrunner, cocaine addict, etc.), Hotline Miami 2 becomes a lure the guy towards you because he is off-screen and if you try to Rambo your way through the level you will get shot from angles you couldn't rationally predict
date:
simulator.

I still liked it, but not for the same reasons I liked Hotline Miami 1. It's almost like the developers said, “The sequel should be bigger and better, like Hotline Miami 1 with more variety and complexity.” While they delivered on that idea through the plot, music, and characters, they failed to provide really concise level design.
Levels were smaller in Hotline Miami 1 so that you could predict what would happen with any given action. This made the one-hit-kill-one-hit-death gimmick work, because instead of having a health advantage over your enemies, you had a “situational awareness” advantage.
This advantage is drastically affected by the size and scope of Hotline Miami 2’s levels. Levels are much larger compared to Hotline Miami 1. In Hotline Miami 1 there were more situations where if you came out of cover, an enemy would mostly likely see you, but since the levels were more compact, you always knew that they would see you. In Hotline Miami 2, however, determining whether or not the enemy sees you is more dependent on how long their line-of-sight is. This is accentuated by the fact that enemies tend to come rushing from off-screen before you get your bearings.
The majority of levels in Hotline Miami 2 play like the “Exposed” stage in Hotline Miami 1. Big, open, and a bit unmanageable.

Despite this, Hotline Miami 2 is a good experience and you should get it. Buy it for the campaign and stay for the level editor.

reviewText:
This game wlil be enjoyable for anyone who has played its predecessor and found it to their liking. Hotline Miami 2 features longer levels and a greater focus on narrative, allowing the game's normal run of 26 levels to feel quite meaty. Take caution, however; the sequel will force you to adapt to new gameplay styles and situatiuons as the story jumps back and forth like children playing hopscotch. You may be comfortable playing Corey or Detective Pardo in the first two levels, only to find that Jake has a minuscule reach with his fists.

The biggest detraction to gamelay is the combination of oversized maps, long hallways, and the increased tendency of your enemies to be packing firearms. By themselves, these three points aren't enough to be a problem; together, they combine to make some of the levels ridiculously difficult. Some other nuances of level design are questionable, such as the cargo hold of the ship with a door that can hinder your own gunfire. I also thought that locating the ammo boxes in the Hawaii missions to be a chore, especially when you must take down heavy enemy soldiers with your gun as opposed to the knife.

If you can swallow the pill of artificial difficulty that pervades some of the later stages, Hotline Miami 2 is a musical and visual treat that is to be savored. It successfully captures the elements of the first game without being a direct rehash.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2. Where do I start?

It's different than the first one. Very different. For starters, you don't control just one guy. There are different guys with different abilities. And I don't mean masks like in the first game. Sure, there are different masks still, but you have a set of different people that have different abilities. Some of them can't pick up weapons other than what they already have. Some of them can only use certain weapons.

The retro style of the graphics and soundtrack really give the game a nostalgic feel. While on the topic, the soundtrack is even better than in the first game, and that's saying something.

The gory kills are just as awesome as ever, perhaps even better. Chainsaw execution, oh my.

All together blends into a game that is even better than its predecessor, and the story is engaging. You won't want to skip the dialogue, even if you have the option.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game.
It's much longer than the first game, and there's a lot more of a variety in the levels, mask abilities and characters you can play as.

The soundtrack is AMAZING, by the way. It has more tracks than the first game did by a long shot, and to top it all off they're all just as good. I'll probably end up buying it soon.

One of the replayability factors for this one comes from Hard Mode, which unlocks when you complete the normal mode of the game. It makes EVERYTHING worse. The enemies have better aim, reaction time, there are more of the 'big' enemies that you have to shoot in order to kill.

Another thing that makes hardmode harder is that when you hold shift to look further, you have to aim in the opposite direction, so you can't use it to easily shoot people who are off-screen. Oh, no lock-on either. Did I mention no lock-on?

Overall I'd definitely recommend buying this game if you enjoyed the first one or if you're looking for a challenge. It's got hours of content, and some nice achievements in it too. 9/10 from me, and when the level editor comes out, it'll be a 10.

reviewText:
I just replayed half of the first HM after finishing HM2, and I can't agree with the general sentiment that the first one was superior.
Sure you don't get the element of surprise, and the story didn't impact me as much and felt a little bit forced.
But in terms of gameplay, and that is the main attraction of this game, it's a huge improvement.
The game goes a little faster, it's more responsive, there's less little bugs (still some, and it's annoying) and I like the fact that you have to get weapons from your ennemies instead of having them just lying on the ground.
There might be slightly less ways to kill/finish ennemies, but new fighting style like with the Dallas mask or the Swan Twins largely makes up for it.
The gameplay is just more fun, fluid, while challenging as well.
The soundtrack might be slightly less catchy, but there's still a couple of memorable tracks, like during the tower mission where you play all four fans consecutively or the prison escape.
9/10

reviewText: I've been playing this game for a while now and have loved it ever since I started playing it. It's definitely an upgrade from the first game and does mostly everything better than the first. The game does indeed have its flaws though. The levels can be very large at times and if you're not careful you'll find yourself getting shot from off-screen. If you haven't played the first game then you'll probably be confused about a lot of things when it comes to the story. As for the pros, the story is smartly written and reminds me of the movie Pulp Fiction. The soundtrack is one of the best I've heard in a videogame for a while. Of course I'm biased since I've loved both installments of the series but if you haven't played this game or its predecessor, you should definitely play them at the very least.

reviewText:
So, I just marathoned both HM1 and 2 (as I was late to the party with 1, got intrigued by it through Payday 2 blah blah...). Anyway, after beating both and sitting on my thoughts, I felt that I had to review them. Particularly this one.

Hotline Miami 2 is trying to both emulate Hotline Miami 1's successes while trying to be its own separate beast. Key word there is trying.

Gameplay
First and foremost
date: Hotline Miami is known for unapologetic
recommended:
hyper violence. The first was fast-paced and thrill seeking. The second... not so much.

Levels

As many of the reviews hovering around have mentioned
hoursPlayed: the levels are huge in comparison to HM1. The sheer size of many maps is probably an attempt to make the stakes that much higher than 1's. Throw in about triple the amount of gunners

reviewText:
I just replayed half of the first HM after finishing HM2, and I can't agree with the general sentiment that the first one was superior.
Sure you don't get the element of surprise, and the story didn't impact me as much and felt a little bit forced.
But in terms of gameplay, and that is the main attraction of this game, it's a huge improvement.
The game goes a little faster, it's more responsive, there's less little bugs (still some, and it's annoying) and I like the fact that you have to get weapons from your ennemies instead of having them just lying on the ground.
There might be slightly less ways to kill/finish ennemies, but new fighting style like with the Dallas mask or the Swan Twins largely makes up for it.
The gameplay is just more fun, fluid, while challenging as well.
The soundtrack might be slightly less catchy, but there's still a couple of memorable tracks, like during the tower mission where you play all four fans consecutively or the prison escape.
9/10

reviewText:
This game did what Hotline Miami does best, and that is the non-stop high-risk gameplay.

Except the level design in this game was pretty bad.
WAY TOO many long corridors and wide-open rooms with barely any cover from goons with guns.
Lots of windows to compliment this as well.
Not to mention your line of sight is way too short to see guys with guns from halfway across the map that can snipe you off in an instant.
I think the devs wanted the player to take advantage of your high-mobility, but it just led to constant frustration.

However, I did enjoy the variety of the characters you can play as.
Overall game design was fantastic set with yet again, an absolutely incredible soundtrack.

If you're a hardcore hotline miami fan, the game is a must-buy.
Just be prepared to take a lot of major risks to fit the extremely frustrating level design.

reviewText:
Better gameplay with a large cast of characters who play different from each other. Better music by far, 50 tracks of non stop rad music. Better variety in enviroments, most areas in the game look completely different than the previous.

Now here's the big issue, the story is absolutely convulted. On purpose i'm sure but the story features a playable cast of characters who well.. they're just pointlessly there. You play as multiple characters who have no impact in the grand scheme of things so what's the point of them existing besides filler? Another issue is that the enemies lack in variety, you're still fighting the same 3 types just with slight differences depending on what part of the story you're on that don't make a huge impact on your gameplay strategies. Also I feel that while the game has a pretty decent amount of length for this type of genre. But that's also kind of a bad thing, the gameplay can be quite repetitive after long periods of time. This game was clearly made for you to just rush through it in 1 long sitting but 3/4ths of the way through you're basically just forcing yourself to advance the story.

Is the game better than the first? Absolutely. Does it have a ton of problems? Absolutely. But it's still a great game and easily worth playing if you enjoyed the first.

reviewText: A game about the epic struggle between a baseball bat and a skull.\nHotline Miami 2 takes everything about the first game and kicks it up a notch, the levels are bigger, there's more story, and there's more blood to spill. The premise is simple, you're put into an area and your job is to make sure nobody in that area is still alive when you're done with them. There's a little less replayability in the levels because many of them lack masks, but the levels are more tightly designed than Hotline Miami's. The gameplay is fast and satisfying, the music is loud and chaotic, and the visual are polished to mirror shine. If you liked Hotline Miami, you'll like this. If you haven't played Hotline Miami play it first, not only is it cheaper but you'll need to have played it to understand what the game's strory is about.

reviewText:
I like this game! It's basically the first game, again but with a lot more characters, a more screwed up story and twice the rage. This time though, you will need to use guns, no questions asked.

PROS
-Gameplay in general is still great, with the intense music adding on
-Soundtrack is amazing, I personally think it's even better than the first (while maybe not as memorable, it really made me feel chills at certain parts)
-Graphics are rad, slightly less ugly than the first and still a gory masterpiece through and through.
-Story. It is way more prominent (and convoluted) than the first one. Gives a lot of back, front, and side stories to the first game.
-Wayyyyy more characters, and more ways to play. Twin Swans with a gun and a chainsaw, a writer who refuses to kill or use guns, the son of a russian mob boss, and a soldier with a resupplying gun and combat knife are just a few of the playable characters. This game will force you to switch it up a lot, so be wary.
CONS
-Mainly the increase of gun reliance and windows here. Far too much hide and seek with enemies, and bullets from across the now huge maps can kill you from somewhere you can't even see.
-The gameplay is not as smooth and flowy as the first, something I really don't like. Sometimes this can be negated I find with the Tony mask, which is my favourite mask in both games. It gives you a lot of stopping power, even against those big goons.

Overall, this is a great game much like the first. I would give it an 8.8/10.





11/10 would GOTTA GET A GRIP again.

reviewText:
It's exactly the kind of sequel you would expect after playing the first one.
Surreal atmosphere, outstanding soundtrack, gory gameplay. But i dont think its the masterpiece one would've hoped for. The story lacks highlights and is hard to follow, since there are quite a few characters/story lines and leaps in time back and forth. And there is a lot more dialogue compared to the original. This is of course related to the longer playtime in general, i think its safe to say its about twice the content of the original. There are hups maps with multiple floors in over 20 levels (i needed 7 hours for a complete playthrough, but i skipped a lot of dialogue).

And you will die thousands of times, since this part is heavily focused on gunplay and if you dont freelook all the time you will get sniped from the edge of the screen. Higher difficulty comes from special enemies with either bullet or melee imunity aswell, overall it feels like you have to play more strategic and cant just rush in and expect to kill everything if you have fast reflexes.
I didnt like the high amount of gunfights because they tend to become really frustrating and take the flow - who defines in my opinion the awesomeness of this franchise - out of the game. A great addition from my perspective are the different playable characters (sometimes fixed, sometimes you are able to choose) with different abilities (e.g. akimbo smgs, killing punches, gun&knife).
Some other weak points are: bossfights with little feedback on what to do to kill the boss, also quite a few glitches and bugs.
But dont get me wrong, i fully recommend buying it, i had a good time playing it and its definitely worth the price.

reviewText:
This game.
It's much longer than the first game, and there's a lot more of a variety in the levels, mask abilities and characters you can play as.

The soundtrack is AMAZING, by the way. It has more tracks than the first game did by a long shot, and to top it all off they're all just as good. I'll probably end up buying it soon.

One of the replayability factors for this one comes from Hard Mode, which unlocks when you complete the normal mode of the game. It makes EVERYTHING worse. The enemies have better aim, reaction time, there are more of the 'big' enemies that you have to shoot in order to kill.

Another thing that makes hardmode harder is that when you hold shift to look further, you have to aim in the opposite direction, so you can't use it to easily shoot people who are off-screen. Oh, no lock-on either. Did I mention no lock-on?

Overall I'd definitely recommend buying this game if you enjoyed the first one or if you're looking for a challenge. It's got hours of content, and some nice achievements in it too. 9/10 from me, and when the level editor comes out, it'll be a 10.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 was an unexpected sequel to an already great game. However, while it does much right it does have a few things that aren't so great.

Story: Hotline Miami 2 is a much more story driven game than the original which isn't a bad thing. The Story takes place directly after the Original spanning over multiple characters. The story follows Martin Brown, The Fans, Detective Manny Pardo, Evan, Jake, The Son, The Soldier, Richter, and even a Henchman. Each have different motivations and Plots based around the Protagonist from Hotline Miami or Fifty Blessings organization from the original. In the end it does a nice job of wrapping up the events of the first game.

The Ending:  The ending was fairly disappointing and without foreknowledge made no sense. In the end everyone ends up dead whether through suicide or the blast of a nuclear bomb, everyone dies in the end. Hard mode does tack on a nice poem in the credits but, it's still lackluster.

Gameplay: Hotline Miami 2 sticks to the run and gun style play of the original but with more of a focus on guns. With each of the playable characters you're given a different play style ranging from Corey's dodge roll, Tony's restriction to melee only, or the Pacifist style of Evan. This game like the original  keeps you on your toes and thinking almost constantly.

Graphics & Sound: There's not much to say for graphics as it sticks to the style of the original. The environments still feel fresh and interesting even after playing through the game a few times. Once again, the soundtrack is phenomenal with tracks that really set the mood and will keep you hooked for the entire duration of the game. I can't recommend this game's soundtrack enough.

Hard Mode: I mentioned Hard Mode earlier so I might as well touch on it. Hard Mode is unlocked after beating the game and it removes the lock-on feature, mirrors the stages, adds more windows, there's less doors, adds more of the tougher enemies, and dropping a weapons makes it lose half it's ammo. While this might seem fair by the end it will leave you frustrated and feeling cheated. In my experience I had to restart a few levels just because I had the wrong weapon. Hard Mode almost forces you into a slow and steady approach rather than run and gun.

TLDR: 9/10 The games great overall and I recommend it to anyone who was a fan of the original.

The gameplay is smooth/fast with an overall good feeling, the music is absolutely the best soundtrack I've ever heard from any game (yes, it even beat Kingdom Hearts in my opinion), the look and feel of the game is really cool. reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is a GOOD game, but not a GOOD sequel for Hotline Miami games. The ideas that made HM1 so satisfying are contradicted in HM2.

HM1 is a fast paced, beat-em up from enemy to enemy, where YOU change your plan if it does not work from level to level. I fell in love with this playstyle and still play HM1 to this day.

HM2 just went against all that HM1 built on, which is a real bummer.

1. The game and character design doesn't let YOU change your plan to beat a level, THE GAME CHANGES YOUR PLAN FOR YOU. The new characters are cool additions because each one carries a backstory, but in-game each one forces you to change and the A-Ha" moment you get when you find a nice route through a level is ruined becaause you didn't find it
date: the game forced you to find it.\n\n2. The game feels generally slower and I felt less like a badass. With all the increased enemies in each level
recommended: I felt like I was played a cover shooter more than a "run through a house and be a walking death machine". Not to mention that when you knock over an enemy the ground pounding takes FOREVER. It is signifigantly slower than that of HM1 and it led me to so many deaths. This is especially true in the Hawaii levels because when you run out of ammo

While the game is not nearly as good as the original, it still is worth a buy, at the very least when it's on sale.

As for improvements, it's sort of hit or miss. The levels are larger and differ more from eachother, but it often feels like you're being shot from something you couldn't see coming and there's not much room for changing up how you tackle each individual level. There's more masks, but they're assigned to specific characters so in the end there's less variety on a level by level basis, but more variety on the whole.
Specfic characters requiring slightly different tactics is cool, but usually it's in the form limiting you, rather than adding to your arsenal of options.

reviewText:
One of the first things I noticed about Hotline Miami 2 was that its soundtrack felt slower to me, more cinematic and larger in scope. I think that best encapsulates HLM2: larger in scope. A lot about this game won't make sense on your first play through, you will curse frequently and the playstyle you were used to is no longer effective in this game. Still, this game builds on what made the first one great and offers a ton more replayability for those who want it.

Moving on to level design, because this is a controversial talking point for this game, I am ambivalent. Hotline 1 feels claustrophobic compared to this game. There is a lot more space to run and maneuver, which becomes important the more that gunplay gets involved. Because practically every enemy has guns, levels are no longer small hallways. There is a lot more happening in the background now too. You'll notice it most in the second scene, but it's present all over the game. Set pieces that tip over or rotate as you move past them. You'll also notice A TON OF WINDOWS have now been added to the game. I personally found some levels to be extremely frustrating, but I also learned more about how the game works (like using windows to my advantage). As someone who appreciates a game that teaches players, I ultimately enjoyed this aspect.

They've stopped that annoying camera bobbing thing that made 1 feel like it was floating in a pool of water, but they didn't pull the camera back. Because so many enemies with guns appear off screen, you will frequently die from bullets shot by guns you can't see. That means mastering, or becoming familiar with, shift looking is crucial. Failure to shift look will extend your play time by several excruciating hours. Stop resisting shift look because you can snipe with pistols from across the map.

This is a game built for perfectionists and speedrunners. That unforgiving difficulty is why NES games like Ninja Gaiden live on in our hearts. It's not about finishing the level, anyone can do that with a simple game of peek-a-boo as has been pointed out on these forums. It's about discovering methods to lure and murder in groups. Combos are so much more effective (and harder to get) in this game, and boldness and flexibility scores actually matter. This game, when played at a high level, is all about speed and flexibility. You can dodge bullets now, something that was virtually impossible in part one.

I have come to the realization that the story is like an homage to Drive. If you've ever seen that movie, it's easy to find yourself left with a lot of questions about the characters you just met. Much like in HLM1, where the world is not quite what it seems. For instance, the community has yet to come to a consensus on how much of HLM1 happened in Jacket's real life and how much was a coma dream. There are two stories happening here: what you actually see and how it fits into the scope of the Hotline Miami timeline. The latter is what makes the story rewarding, because the former is quite jumbled and in some cases very abrupt.

Those who want to replay a game and learn it will find the experience of Hotline Miami 2 to be a frustrating climb to a satisfying top. Those expecting a fun and twitchy murder simulator that lasts for a few hours might find themselves disappointed by this experience.

Ask yourself which of these gamers you are before you buy this game.

[[*Edit: A note on hard mode. I thought it was too hard, like suck the fun out of the game hard. I'll probably finish it because I'm kind of a super fan of this game, but I am not enjoying that part at all.]]

reviewerDisplayName: W A H N S I N N
reviewText:
I've come to believe that 'Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number' might just be the best game ever created. Many ascribe that title to the likes of 'The Legend Of Zelda: Ocarina Of Time', 'Batman Arkham City' or even 'The World Ends With You', however, those aren't nearly as astonishing as Wrong Number. Any major publisher can throw a pile of money at a development team, cater to the masses and market the hell out of it but to create something like Hotline Miami, even the first one, it takes true artists. When the latter released in 2012 Jonatan Söderström and Dennis Wedin created something completely unique and their own. No compromises were made to appeal to a wider crowd and everything in the game served a purpose and not just because it looked 'cool'.

When you would be asking yourself why you have to mash the A button to open up a ventilation shaft in Arkham City (when we clearly agreed that this was shitty busywork which adds NOTHING to the experience of any work of art a decade ago), no one would ask a similar question when it comes to Hotline Miami. In a sense, Hotline Miami can be seen as a 'Gesamtkunstwerk', all of the elements (story, graphics, gameplay, soundtrack) strive for a greater goal than the sums of their parts. Without the story it could be written off as just another mass murder simulator, without the graphics and their effects it wouldn't have the same kind of feeling, the pixilated violence contributing a special bit (ha) overshadowing any childish bloodfest in 'Grand Theft Auto' or 'Metal Gear Solid', without the gameplay you wouldn't have the interactivity and immersion the story so desperately needs and without the soundtrack you wouldn't feel you heart pumping at every beat, wanting you to go on.

If the first game had already established the perfect formula, then why do we need a sequel? Because Hotline Miami had one major problem: It was only 2 hours long, when players were hardly fully satisfied (in fact it has been scientifically proven that it can take a lifetime of playing Hotline Miami for it to get boring) so the sequel made sure to include at least 7 hours of playtime, unlocking a hard mode for additional 15 afterwards. In addition, even though the first one had a near flawless story, OST and presentation, that didn't mean they couldn't be improved, so they turned them up to 11. All these improvements aside, Hotline Miami 2 also did a thing almost every other sequel is afraid to do (see Zelda for example): It picked the difficulty up right where the first one left off. With no thought spent on filthy 'newcomers' to the series feeling left out, Dennaton created exactly what they and their fans wanted and as most series should do, told everyone to play the first one or get fucked. It's just a shame that Deus Ex exists.

reviewText:
This reveiw will be split into three sections.
1- GAMEPLAY
2- SOUNDTRACK
3- STORY

GAMEPLAY
Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is a good game for anyone wanting a challenge, or a way to releive stress. Just got back from a 3 hour line at the DMV only to be turned away due to closing time? What is a better stress releivering stress than knocking a man unconscious with a lead pipe being thrown at his head, only to then chop is head in perfect halves with a fireaxe? Think of a better stress re- you can't. It is sort of a rage game, you could call it, due to the one-hit-deaths. And dogs. Dont forget about glass, either. And you just cant forget about the fat man.  I wish I had a Fat Man of my own on some of these levels... All in all, great fun. Also bear mask named Mark. (ALSO TRIGGER WARNING) also ♥♥♥♥. cant forget the ♥♥♥♥, sorry australia

SOUNDTRACK
It's perfect. Not much else to say, about 3 to 4 hours of great music. That's what these games are known for. The soundtrack.

STORY
Uh.. Well.. I dont know what to say. I havent FULLY beaten the game, but I'm loving it so far. One minute you can be pulling off a bank heist, and the next you can be having flashbacks of your dad telling you hes there and your not be he isnt and you are but not and is and Inception stuff but he's Jacket, and all kinds of stuff and halucinations and all kinds of creepy things.

I don't see myself replaying this much because of the aforementioned design choices but it was a good experience overall.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is a top-down high octane action game created by Devolver Digital. The game features multiple protagonists and is the sequel to the incredible Hotline Miami.

8/10Recommended Purchase
If you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up!

Pros
+Gameplay
This is one hell of a fast paced game. You pick up various weapons as you go and proceed to smash,stab,or shoot all of your endless enemies. The game is fairly long and is very VERY difficult. You may even get to the point where you think the game is all artificial difficulty. You could not be more wrong. The game is incredibly challenging but combined with the great soundtrack it makes for some awesome fast paced murder sprees.

+Soundtrack
This soundtrack,while in my opinion being nowhere near as good as the first one, is still absolutely stellar. In the soundtrack we see a return from artists such as M|O|O|N and Perturbator. This soundtrack isn't as good as the first but damn it makes for some great moments.

+Story
This one is interesting. The story is complete and total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and I understand NONE of it. Thought it sure as hell pulled me in and now I cant help but wanting more explanation and lore behind this. It may not be the best but I sure as hell looked forward to learning more and more.

Cons:
-Maps
Alright so this game introduces very very big maps compared to the original. There were chapters of the first game that were about the size of a single floor in this one. The maps ♥♥♥♥ with the gameplay in such a way that you may be murdering mobsters one moment and then having to sit there and scout the next zone the next. All that just to make sure that you dont get shot through a random ♥♥♥ window when you cant even see your enemy.

-Characters
So in Hotline Miami you played as one guy with a lot of masks to differentiate things. In Hotline 2 you play as like 8 characters who each have a few masks each. This is just stupid. Why change that? I assume its for story but even still.

As you can probably see the pros far out weigh the cons on this game so pick it up ASAP. This may not be the Hotline Miami sequel I was looking for but ill be damned if it doesn't come close.

If you found this review helpful or entertaining then feel free to join my Steam Curator Group at  Mudkips Gaming

reviewText: In the time I've played HM2, I have been brutally murdered in multiple ways. These include (but is not limited to) getting my head dented in with a baseball bat, getting ravaged by several attack dogs, sent to a hospital, then dying from losing all my stomach acid, getting punched down by a fat guy simply because I don't understand the door mechanics, allowing an insane inmate to introduce my brain to the cold, hard ground, and I've had an intimate relationship with a gun. And that's just in the game. I wouldn't be surprised if I snapped a vocal chord trying to run away from a fat guy, who for some reason, only dies to bullets. Also, every now and then, I take a break from gaming, mostly because I want to rest my eyes. HM2 makes me rest because if I continued playing, an unexplainable hole will form in my computer's moniter, likely in the shape of my fist.\n\nIn short, you'll die. A lot. Still a virgin? Well, you're going to make sweet, ferocious love to your R" key."

reviewText:
I think Hotline Miami 2 is the best game of the year so far. And I dont think much will change that.

The gameplay is like the same in Hotline Miami 1 but it's in the right way. And we all know how amazing the gameplay in HM1 is. I feel like you need to play a little bit less aggresive though, probably cause of the level design.

The music is even better than the first one, and I seriously think this is the best music I have ever heard in a video game before. It's insane and fits the game so well.

The graphics..Well, not so much to say about it. I like it though.

You will see alot of glitches with the walls but it's nothing big. Only things like bodies and blood going through them.

This game can be frustrating sometimes cause of the level design, the levels are pretty big. And in a game where you can die by one bullet. That's not so good.

One of the biggest feautres I would want for this game is a replay thing, cause sometimes you just go ''how the hell did I even manage to do that?'' And you want to check it out again in slow motion and stuff. But you cant unless you recorded it.

The story got a little bit more intrestring for me. Since it has alot of more playable characters. I disliked the ending though.

There's also a level editor coming out soon.

Pros: Outstanding music
Amazing gameplay
Level editor
Good Story

Cons:Frustating levels
Some glitches

9/10

reviewText:
Finished the first game to 100% completion, every achievement. The first game is a masterpiece, an amazing piece of gaming history. I thought no game could ever compare to the original Hotline: Miami.

I was wrong.

Gameplay- 9/10
Extremely satisfying and gorey gameplay. Very similar to the first game, but with an abundance of new mechanics and gameplay styles available to you. It's hard as nails, but everytime you die, you don't feel as if the game cheaped you out, deaths always feel fair. And hey, you can respawn instantly by pressing 'R', anyways.

Story- 10/10
Absolutely brilliant. Twisy, Curvy, and leaves a lot of questions remaining. Won't go into it any further than this, not risking spoiling any of the many great moments in this game.

Soundtrack- 11/10
The music is like Bon Jovi, Daft Punk, and a Keytar had a baby with Skrillex. It is Glorious. Fits the game perfectly

Final Rating:
1985/10

reviewText: I liked the music, and I really liked the look. Some of the maps suffered from things like enemies being able to shoot from outside of the field of vision, which made finishing levels in a single run nearly impossible, and resulted in a LOT of trial by memorization.\n\nI had fun with this game - in short sessions. There was a point where I was wondering if there was going to be an end
date:
and the actual finale came WAY after that point - so I wouldn't recommend playing this in marathon sessions. If you like pixelated gore and occasional (i.e. you get lucky) runs that have a faux 8/16-bit John Woo meets Sam Peckinpah guns n' blood fest, then this game is for you. The story itself is very loosely implied (it ranks somewhere just above the plot to the original Centipede arcade game), so just use those intermissions to un-cramp your thumbs and wipe the sweat off your palms.

Fun? Yes.
Would I play it more than once? No.

reviewText:
I personally think that Hotline Miami 2 is fun and thrilling by video game standards, but not by Hotline Miami 1 standards.  The game is far more story driven than the first, and though it is an interesting-if trippy-story, it can be annoying the have to connect the dots yourself and remember who characters were that you stopped playing an hour ago after wasting time on a hard level.  Also, for those who want to know, here is a breakdown of how you will die in this game:

90% due to enemies offscreen
6% due to glitches
4% due to legitimate screw ups you could have avoided

The gigantic level design of this game is what separates it from the last as it allows for enemies with laser accuracy to shoot you from across the map without you being able to see them.  This can become incredibly frustrating for many and the main reason I powered through this game is because I loved the first one.  Needless to say, I will never bother completing hard mode in this game.

Even with these problems it is still a fun game with some extremely exciting and fun moments. It's just not as fair as the first game was and I could never move as fast or recklessly as I could in the first.

Soundtrack was awesome though, as everyone else who played the game has already said

The real star of the show, in my opinion, is the awesome soundtrack which makes every level fun for at least a little while.  The story is bonkers and the last mission is nuts.  I enjoyed my time with the game and would recommend it with the caveats I listed above.

reviewText:
I have to admit, Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is a step down from it's predecessor in terms of it's gameplay. The original Hotline Miami boasts high octane-filled close quarters combat, filled with as much gratuitous violence it's retro 16bit inspired top-down graphics can handle, with psychedelic visuals and a permadeath-lite feature that's bound to keep you on the edge of your seat, with different masks to cater to different playthroughs, giving the short 3-4 hour game much replayability.

And then HM2:WN essentially removed all of this. The masks are replaced with level-specific characters, which, instead of offering minor perks to nudge the player, straight up shoves the player into adopting certain playstyles. The close quarters combat the original used to have becomes long hallways with bullets coming at you off-screen. Granted, the game is still pretty fun, but in comparison to the absolutely fantastic Hotline Miami, isn't really saying a lot.

At this point of my review, you might be wondering why do I recommend this game? Well, because of the story. Well the first game's abstract story was essentially a great statement on violence in video games, complete with surrealistic elements, HM2:WN has a coherent, maybe even movie-worthy story that overshadows it's predecessor in terms of both scale and content, but also boasts well-developed characters with personality, juxtaposing the repetitive and ridiculously violent gameplay.

At the end of the day, the pros of HM2:WN's story is enough to outweigh the cons of it's gameplay. But you don't really play games for their plot do you? So what I'm trying to say is, if you're the kind of person who actually cares about the story when you play video games, this is a must-get. But if you're just looking for something to blow off some steam with after a long day's work, this is probably not the game for you.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2 is the the sequel to the famous top down shooter Hotline Miami. There was alot of hype to this game. And when it came out... it was a mixed bag for some people. Some people loved it, some people hated it. But now that the level editor (Beta) has come out, I feel like it's time to give a PROPER review for this game.
Hotline Miami 2 uses the same formula of gameplay that the original did. But the biggest change in gameplay has to come from the levels it creates.
The levels are either a pro or a con. The levels, instead of being not so spread out, being close together, and each room having a considerable amount of enemies and weapons to defend yourself with. But instead, Hotline Miami 2. has VERY spread out levels, alot of glass, and tons and tons of enemies. I for one like it. I don't like the glass, (To be honest, nobody does.) and way too many armed enemies. But that's okay.
The gameplay as I said before stays the same, but they find ways to shake it up a bit for a few levels.
The story becomes a major part of the game, unlike the original that focused on violence and gore. And it takes a rather interesting turn aswell. They introduce tons of new characters.
-The Fans
-The Writer
-The Cop
-The Cobra
-The Rat
-The Soldier
-The Son
And a list of side characters too. It introduces them in a non-linear way, switching to the 80's in a very well, 80's way. It switches up the story.
Remember those little plot twists at the end of a few levels in Hotline Miami 1? Like the S.W.A.T team invading the place you were sent to. Or having to kill Hobo in Metro? Well, not many of those are present. Sure, you have the occasional character(s) death, and sometimes some twists, but not many gameplay plot twists. Could use more of those.
The main campaign is good in itself, but slightly disappointing in a few ways.
The AI in the game is a pro and a con. They give you a good ol' challenge, yet it feels like aimbot. With the inclusion of off-screen deaths, it will screw up your run badly. Yet it feels fair, but still feels unfair, however that may feel '-_-'
So finally, the level editor. It's still in Beta at the moment, but it works. It's very glitchy. It tends to crash alot, so save often. Other than that it's a level editor! It works! It's good! A workshop has yet to be included.
---------------------
So IS HM2 better that HM1?  I will answer that question with a Yes".
The game also forces you to get better at shooting. Remember that.
So yes
date: I recommend this game as an immediate purchase for fans of the first game
recommended: or people who just want more Hotline Miami.\nIt's good. That's all there is to say."

reviewText:
One thing to note is that my massive playtime came from achievement whoring. If you don’t care about getting achievements, and just play the game for the story, I can see this being around 10 hours or so. (Regardless of the length, it’s still a worthy purchase.)

Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is interesting. Compared with the first game, there are many notable improvements such as storytelling, soundtrack and presentation. However, it takes a couple steps back in gameplay, which sucks because well...the fast paced gameplay makes up 90% of the game. I found myself dying waaaay too many times from enemies off screen, or random enemy movements. I thought the first game had wonky A.I. here and there, but not as bad as this game. One of the things that made the first game great was the ability to learn levels, and maneuver them to your bidding. What helped in that too was the fact that you had such an array of masks to choose from for every single level. In the sequel, you are severely limited to gameplay styles. I think it’s a clear example of how a hard game shouldn’t be frustrating, it should encourage the player to think, adapt and overcome the difficulty.

All that being said, the story in this game is ♥♥♥♥ing insane and will make you want to keep playing. The diverse array of characters, themes, and shifts in storytelling make for one of the most unique story experiences I've had in a long time. The expanded soundtrack is also fantastic. In the first game, several tracks were repeated for multiple levels. Not that there was a problem with that as the original soundtrack was incredible, (and I would say overall was more cohesive than Wrong Number's soundtrack) but it's really nice and fresh to have individual songs back every level in the game. It makes certain levels really memorable.

Unless you try for all achievements and A+ like me, then you really shouldn't have a problem progressing level to level, as it's only reeaally when you challenge yourself to get a high score that the flaws in gameplay show. But that being said, even taking my time on some levels in hard mode made me want to bash my head against a wall. Overall, I'd give it a flat 8.0/10. The level design in the original is leagues better, however I think Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is still a great game, and a worthy sequel, even if the progression and tediousness in the gameplay becomes apparent.

reviewText:
This reveiw will be split into three sections.
1- GAMEPLAY
2- SOUNDTRACK
3- STORY

GAMEPLAY
Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is a good game for anyone wanting a challenge, or a way to releive stress. Just got back from a 3 hour line at the DMV only to be turned away due to closing time? What is a better stress releivering stress than knocking a man unconscious with a lead pipe being thrown at his head, only to then chop is head in perfect halves with a fireaxe? Think of a better stress re- you can't. It is sort of a rage game, you could call it, due to the one-hit-deaths. And dogs. Dont forget about glass, either. And you just cant forget about the fat man.  I wish I had a Fat Man of my own on some of these levels... All in all, great fun. Also bear mask named Mark. (ALSO TRIGGER WARNING) also ♥♥♥♥. cant forget the ♥♥♥♥, sorry australia

SOUNDTRACK
It's perfect. Not much else to say, about 3 to 4 hours of great music. That's what these games are known for. The soundtrack.

STORY
Uh.. Well.. I dont know what to say. I havent FULLY beaten the game, but I'm loving it so far. One minute you can be pulling off a bank heist, and the next you can be having flashbacks of your dad telling you hes there and your not be he isnt and you are but not and is and Inception stuff but he's Jacket, and all kinds of stuff and halucinations and all kinds of creepy things.

tl;dr
buy it.
just buy it.
buy it.

buy iiiittttt.........

reviewText:
Meh. It's okay I guess. I recommend getting the first one instead.

The Good:
1. The music is like the first one, stellar and simply awesome.
2. Combat system is fast paced and bloody brilliant.

The Bad:
1. The level design is horrible. You'll be shot by a random dude who you can't even see. The maps are way too big, or at least there are too many open fields which are simply lethal for someone who has a limited view.
2. It's sometimes buggy (looking at you teleporting dogs and see-through doors <.<).

The 'meh':
1. The new characters are a bit, ehm how should I put this? ehm,...well they're s(h)it. Some characters are simply useless. One guy who you play as is a 'pacifist'. Although you can pick up guns after forcing him to kill a couple of guys, you usually get shot a million times trying to do so.
2. The combat relies heavily on guns. The only way you'll get to kill someone is by baiting them to come to you. It's simply bland and it's missing the rushing in and killing part.

The first one's a lot better if you ask me.
I recommend waiting until it's on sale or something.

2.5/5 would meh again.

reviewText:
TL;DR

Overall - 9.5/10

Graphics - 10/10 Fell in love with the original, and nothing has changed.
Gameplay - 9/10 Some elements appear to be part of the floor, but are actually things you can get stuck against
Soundtrack - 10/10 Only adds to the feel of going on killing sprees, the synths and deep beat make you feel as if you're tripping the entire time
Story - 8/10 While confusing at first and seemingly fragmented everything comes to a conclusion at the end. Could be bumped up to a 9/10 due to the slight changes in story if playing on hard mode after completing the first run.
Level Design - 8/10 For the most part exceptional, though in some sections it is nearly impossible to clear the entire floor in one combo due to distances between enemies.


Probably a perfect sequel to the original Hotline Miami. The game flicks between flashbacks and present day for multiple characters. With different characters and different time periods the challenges change, in some cases only having access to a single gun chosen at the beginning of the level and an army knife, where you must look for the very rare ammo dumps if you do run out of bullets. In other cases you cannot use guns at all.

The new fan (mask) system adds a refreshing spin on the old system from the original game. Each character only having access to a few different fans, and these give only slight differences in abilities. Gone are the days of cycling through the tens of different fans trying to decide which would best suit your playing style or be most effective for that specific level. All fans are effective in each level in their different ways.

The story, while confusing at first does tie up all the loose ends upon completion of the first run. Even going so far as to explain the history behind the original Miami Killer and other seemingly minor characters in the original game. I would highly reccomend immediately starting a replay on hard mode after completing the first playthrough, as there are some small differences at the beginning of the hard mode story.

The gameplay is as good as ever, with only slight issues where elements that appeared to be part of the floor actually end up getting you stuck and killed. Upon switching to hard mode the levels actually flip, with the same layout but this time from a different perspective. While this seems as if it wouldn't change much, it does make the levels harder, changing sight lines of enemies and the way that you approach that 20X combo. In hard mode guns you pick up will have extremely reduced ammo, with shotguns only holding 3 rounds instead of the regular 6. (This is the only one I remember, as I don't usually pick up any other type of gun) Enemies in hard mode seem to have almost supersonic hearing and hawkeye vision, forcing you to react much more quickly and plan everything on the fly.

An incredible soundtrack accompanies the game. I downloaded the soundtrack weeks before the game was released, and enjoyed it extremely. Back to the roots of the original Hotline Miami, the synths and deep beats keep you on the edge of your seat while mowing down enemies one after the other.

Not much can be said about the graphics, pixely as they are I fell in love with the art style of the original Hotline Miami, and no changes were made for this one, making me one happy guy. *cough* Binding of Isaac Rebirth *cough*

The only real issue I had with the entire game was that one floor of the apartment where the stairs were set up in the most awkward configuration. Who hired that architect? No wonder there was a serial killer in that complex, if I had to go through that every day I'd probably be on the lookout for someone too.

reviewText: A game about the epic struggle between a baseball bat and a skull.\nHotline Miami 2 takes everything about the first game and kicks it up a notch, the levels are bigger, there's more story, and there's more blood to spill. The premise is simple, you're put into an area and your job is to make sure nobody in that area is still alive when you're done with them. There's a little less replayability in the levels because many of them lack masks, but the levels are more tightly designed than Hotline Miami's. The gameplay is fast and satisfying, the music is loud and chaotic, and the visual are polished to mirror shine. If you liked Hotline Miami, you'll like this. If you haven't played Hotline Miami play it first, not only is it cheaper but you'll need to have played it to understand what the game's strory is about.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number impression and Review
This review will probably contain spoilers. I will, however, mark them as spoilers. Just don't click on them even if you find it tempting, because everything under that is story related. Good? Good.

The first Hotline Miami was released back in 2012, and it became a large success, critics and fans alike praised it for its fast paced, adrenaline fueled ultraviolence to the catchy soundtrack made by several rather unkown but very talented artists, unlike most games which featured a single score made by one person.
The story in the first Hotline Miami was simplistic, and relied on more subtle means to tell its story. The main character never speaks, although there is dialogue in the game.

The gameplay consisted of fast dispatching of russian mobsters with various blunt weaponry such as a pool cue or a baseball bat, kitchen appliances, throwables such as bricks, darts, and glass bottles, as well as firearms.
The levels were rather small, enemies were in a reasonable distance from each other and it was all a very compact format, which lent itself rather well to its very melee-centric combat. You kill fast and die fast, one hit and everyone's out, unless you throw your weapon or punch them when not wearing a tiger mask.

The second game is the same in core principle, albeit with some changes. It feels a bit slower, heavier in a way.
But the most jarring part of it is the level design. Initially rather well done, soon you can't help but feel that they are too big for their own good. Hotline Miami is a concept that doesn't lend itself to large levels. Here's a list of problems that arrives with the large level format.
The levels become cluttered with all the gore, bodies, and guns. Easy to lose track of your enemies.
Can't always see the entire way forward, even with shift-look it sometimes won't be enough.
Large chance to get shot offscreen by something you didn't see
Here comes some story stuff.
The story in Hotline Miami 2 is a lot more developed than the first game, and has several links and returning characters. The barkeep from the first game was in the army with Jacket, Richter was caring for his mother and biker... Well.
Hotline Miami has several characters that it focuses on. The detective, who plays like Jacket except can shoot faster and aim faster with the shotgun, the Writer, who has a non-lethal style and allows for the combo to be kept up by picking up guns and unloading them,  but can go berserk if you kill two people. As well as the fans"

reviewText: The follow up to the excellent Hotline Miami. This time you take the role of multiple characters each with unique gameplay styles. While it may be a little daunting storywise due to the amount of characters that are in the story, it still holds a solid narrative to the bitter end. Levels are much longer, varied and much more difficult, but I believe that challenge is a good thing since it can keep you playing again and again. If you thought the first game had an amazing soundtrack than prepare for another dose of the most heart-pounding, neon-soaked adrenaline rush beats in the game industry. I personally think the soundtrack complete outshines the original's OST. My only gripe with the game is with the story, I feel like there was little bit more room to develop certain characters more.\n\nOverall, a solid sequel to an already solid game.

reviewText:
The biggest thing that Hotline Miami 1 and 2 have done in the terms of a great game is it's ability to stay in your mind after you play and enjoy it.
Hotline miami 1 is a great arcade version of the game with a snappier control, super retro feel and sound along with the mystery of the enitre situation at hand.
Wrong number unwraps the entire picture before you if you are able to piece everything into place, but most importantly, it rises above the 1st game in it's ability to stay in your mind after everything is over with.
(SPOILERS BELOW)
It's much like what the colonel said with his panther mask with the 50 blessings mark in the forhead said We're all animals and deep down we enjoy it." We enjoy snapping and having instinct take over rather than try to plan it all out and fail from 1 mistake.
You enjoy running down the mobs
date: you enjoy dodging the shots and predicting the movements of your eneimes to score wicked combos. That's why all the playable charecters mostly simulate how jacket played in the first game
recommended: but they still have their own uniqueness to them in their gameplay and personality in the story.\nBut they

reviewText:
I just finished hotline miami and I have conflicted feelings about it. It took me around 9.5 hours, and I did have fun the whole time. I had played the first one and loved it so I gave this one a try, and boy did I spend my money right. The gory mess of corpses combined with the amazing soundtrack was so fun I'm playing the entire game over again.

Pros:

-AMAZING soundtrack (seriously, I could listen to it forever)
-Gory fun
-Challenging yet addictive
-Story

Cons:

-Story
-Length

Story is a pro and a con at the same time. If you're looking for a understandable story. This isn't for you. The story is all over the place and when the credits rolled I still had no idea what all of it meant. If you play the game over or simply look it up, you can understand more but there is still a great mystery behind all of it. The game is pretty hard. One shot or one bash to the head with a pipe will kill you. Same for the enemy though. I found it challenging but still very fun and addictive. The one thing I was very disappointed at was the length. Not that is was too short just the fact I WANT MORE HOTLINE MIAMI.

So overall this is an absolutely great game and you should get it. You will have an eargasm from the epic soundtrack and your eyes will turn red from all the blood and guts you will see. And I promise you. You will love. Every. Damn. Second.


P.S.

DO NOT ACHIEVEMENT HUNT THIS GAME. I tried to get a 15x combo and ended up throwing and shattering my mouse againest the wall. I warn you, do not achievement hunt this game.

reviewText:
Quick Review: 7.8 out of 10

Extended Review: Keep in mind I've yet to finish the game's story but I'm far enough in to make a fair assessment of the game.

Hotline Miami 2 in many ways lives up as a sequel to Hotline Miami and it explains various events from Hotline Miami and the soundtrack of Wrong Number sounds off just as good as the first games. However, what really takes the biggest hit on points are two of the things that I am not so happy with. Firstly this game relies far far too heavily on windows, which ultimately makes the level design feel more like quantity over quality whereas Hotline Miami's was quality over quantity. Second and most problematic is the way Wrong Number relies much more on gunplay which is disappointing because part of the appeal of Hotline is the chaotic melee violence, but with how many enemies tend to be in this game with guns or the fat bruiser types, you're more than likely going to have to rely on a gun for good portions of the level and that really ruins some of the fun for me. I still recommend the game because despite those two glaring faults it's still a fun game and the soundtrack is ear candy as well.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number impression and Review
This review will probably contain spoilers. I will, however, mark them as spoilers. Just don't click on them even if you find it tempting, because everything under that is story related. Good? Good.

The first Hotline Miami was released back in 2012, and it became a large success, critics and fans alike praised it for its fast paced, adrenaline fueled ultraviolence to the catchy soundtrack made by several rather unkown but very talented artists, unlike most games which featured a single score made by one person.
The story in the first Hotline Miami was simplistic, and relied on more subtle means to tell its story. The main character never speaks, although there is dialogue in the game.

The gameplay consisted of fast dispatching of russian mobsters with various blunt weaponry such as a pool cue or a baseball bat, kitchen appliances, throwables such as bricks, darts, and glass bottles, as well as firearms.
The levels were rather small, enemies were in a reasonable distance from each other and it was all a very compact format, which lent itself rather well to its very melee-centric combat. You kill fast and die fast, one hit and everyone's out, unless you throw your weapon or punch them when not wearing a tiger mask.

The second game is the same in core principle, albeit with some changes. It feels a bit slower, heavier in a way.
But the most jarring part of it is the level design. Initially rather well done, soon you can't help but feel that they are too big for their own good. Hotline Miami is a concept that doesn't lend itself to large levels. Here's a list of problems that arrives with the large level format.
The levels become cluttered with all the gore, bodies, and guns. Easy to lose track of your enemies.
Can't always see the entire way forward, even with shift-look it sometimes won't be enough.
Large chance to get shot offscreen by something you didn't see
Here comes some story stuff.
The story in Hotline Miami 2 is a lot more developed than the first game, and has several links and returning characters. The barkeep from the first game was in the army with Jacket, Richter was caring for his mother and biker... Well.
Hotline Miami has several characters that it focuses on. The detective, who plays like Jacket except can shoot faster and aim faster with the shotgun, the Writer, who has a non-lethal style and allows for the combo to be kept up by picking up guns and unloading them,  but can go berserk if you kill two people. As well as the fans"
