reviewText:
Sequel to the original, wildly popular Hotline Miami, Hotline Miami 2 seeks to fill in some of the gaps in the original's story and show some of its impacts.

Gameplay is pretty par for course by Hotline standards. Quick, rapid paced, and brutally violent and unfair, where success comes through a combination of luck, dexterity, and just a bit of clairvoyance. Differences are in the details. Unlike the first game, Hotline Miami 2 follows several independent, yet intertwined storylines, each with a small selection of masks and abilities. In each level, only those in the active storyline have masks that can be used, as opposed to the original, where any mask, once unlocked, could be used in any level. Some new mask abilities include having two characters, one melee with one button and one shooting with another, to dual-wielding submachine guns and dodge rolling.

The weapon selection has expanded from the previous game to include a host of silenced weapons, SMGs, assualt rifles, and pistols. Melee weapon variety has been greatly decreased, being reduced, for the most part, to pipes, golf clubs, and knives.

While the game play and music remain enviously good, the story aspect has suffered a bit. The lack of a single protagonist and the rapid jumping between storylines is, at times, confusing, and often the wild rampages seem a bit out of place. For many such rampages the reasons behind boil down to 'just because', something I'm kind of on the fence about as to whether it aids character development or is an excuse for more violence.

As in the first game, Hotline Miami 2's protagonists all invariably suffer due to their actions, leading to one hell of a finale. All in all, the game isn't bad at all. It's a bit rough around the edges at parts and can be brain-crushingly frustrating at others, but it's still fun and remains king of the kind of violence only Hotline Miami can do.

reviewText:
I've come to believe that 'Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number' might just be the best game ever created. Many ascribe that title to the likes of 'The Legend Of Zelda: Ocarina Of Time', 'Batman Arkham City' or even 'The World Ends With You', however, those aren't nearly as astonishing as Wrong Number. Any major publisher can throw a pile of money at a development team, cater to the masses and market the hell out of it but to create something like Hotline Miami, even the first one, it takes true artists. When the latter released in 2012 Jonatan Söderström and Dennis Wedin created something completely unique and their own. No compromises were made to appeal to a wider crowd and everything in the game served a purpose and not just because it looked 'cool'.

When you would be asking yourself why you have to mash the A button to open up a ventilation shaft in Arkham City (when we clearly agreed that this was shitty busywork which adds NOTHING to the experience of any work of art a decade ago), no one would ask a similar question when it comes to Hotline Miami. In a sense, Hotline Miami can be seen as a 'Gesamtkunstwerk', all of the elements (story, graphics, gameplay, soundtrack) strive for a greater goal than the sums of their parts. Without the story it could be written off as just another mass murder simulator, without the graphics and their effects it wouldn't have the same kind of feeling, the pixilated violence contributing a special bit (ha) overshadowing any childish bloodfest in 'Grand Theft Auto' or 'Metal Gear Solid', without the gameplay you wouldn't have the interactivity and immersion the story so desperately needs and without the soundtrack you wouldn't feel you heart pumping at every beat, wanting you to go on.

If the first game had already established the perfect formula, then why do we need a sequel? Because Hotline Miami had one major problem: It was only 2 hours long, when players were hardly fully satisfied (in fact it has been scientifically proven that it can take a lifetime of playing Hotline Miami for it to get boring) so the sequel made sure to include at least 7 hours of playtime, unlocking a hard mode for additional 15 afterwards. In addition, even though the first one had a near flawless story, OST and presentation, that didn't mean they couldn't be improved, so they turned them up to 11. All these improvements aside, Hotline Miami 2 also did a thing almost every other sequel is afraid to do (see Zelda for example): It picked the difficulty up right where the first one left off. With no thought spent on filthy 'newcomers' to the series feeling left out, Dennaton created exactly what they and their fans wanted and as most series should do, told everyone to play the first one or get fucked. It's just a shame that Deus Ex exists.

reviewText:
This is a tough one.

If you haven't played HM1, don't buy this. Play the first one and then decide, honestly I think it's still better.

HM2 carries over some of the charm we know and love from the first installment of the series but still makes slight changes in level design that change gameplay fundamentally.

Going 'Melee only' is a lot harder now than it used to be, as the game encourages guns and combos more than its predecessor.

The experience changes drastically because of this, as it makes the game a lot more strategic and tactical and gives up some of the flow I loved in the first game.
Often times you will find enemies (with guns) far away from you and will die to situations that are simply impossible to survive without knowing what waits for you behind some long distances. These enemies will be impossible to kill without stopping or slowing down to press shift to look further out, which heavily influences flow.

Without giving anything away I can tell you that the story will now have you play a multitude of different characters which means that choosing a mask rarely happens at all and usually without a lot of variety. This isn't something I miss too much though, because the unique character designs really manage to make up for it.

I'd say the game is inferior to the first one in very many ways, but that doesn't make it a bad game at all, considering just how amazing Hotline Miami was for most people who played it.

The story good enough and still manages to keep some of the 'what is happening?' confusion you might have felt during the first game alive.



All in all I would probably recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the first game. If you're sceptic, try to pick it up on sale.
If you feel like the first game lacked a bit of strategy, then there really isn't a whole lot for you to think about. Buy it.

reviewText:
Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number impression and Review
This review will probably contain spoilers. I will, however, mark them as spoilers. Just don't click on them even if you find it tempting, because everything under that is story related. Good? Good.

The first Hotline Miami was released back in 2012, and it became a large success, critics and fans alike praised it for its fast paced, adrenaline fueled ultraviolence to the catchy soundtrack made by several rather unkown but very talented artists, unlike most games which featured a single score made by one person.
The story in the first Hotline Miami was simplistic, and relied on more subtle means to tell its story. The main character never speaks, although there is dialogue in the game.

The gameplay consisted of fast dispatching of russian mobsters with various blunt weaponry such as a pool cue or a baseball bat, kitchen appliances, throwables such as bricks, darts, and glass bottles, as well as firearms.
The levels were rather small, enemies were in a reasonable distance from each other and it was all a very compact format, which lent itself rather well to its very melee-centric combat. You kill fast and die fast, one hit and everyone's out, unless you throw your weapon or punch them when not wearing a tiger mask.

The second game is the same in core principle, albeit with some changes. It feels a bit slower, heavier in a way.
But the most jarring part of it is the level design. Initially rather well done, soon you can't help but feel that they are too big for their own good. Hotline Miami is a concept that doesn't lend itself to large levels. Here's a list of problems that arrives with the large level format.
The levels become cluttered with all the gore, bodies, and guns. Easy to lose track of your enemies.
Can't always see the entire way forward, even with shift-look it sometimes won't be enough.
Large chance to get shot offscreen by something you didn't see
Here comes some story stuff.
The story in Hotline Miami 2 is a lot more developed than the first game, and has several links and returning characters. The barkeep from the first game was in the army with Jacket, Richter was caring for his mother and biker... Well.
Hotline Miami has several characters that it focuses on. The detective, who plays like Jacket except can shoot faster and aim faster with the shotgun, the Writer, who has a non-lethal style and allows for the combo to be kept up by picking up guns and unloading them,  but can go berserk if you kill two people. As well as the fans"

reviewText: If you enjoy mass murder, then this game is for you. If you don't, get it anyways because it will make you enjoy mass murder. Hotline Miami 2 turns brutal murder into a self-satisfying hobby that never gets old. Blowing people's brains out with a shotgun has never brought such an evil grin to my face; it is harmonizing, quick, and fluid. Once you get the hang of it, you never really let go - especially when there is an epic electro score to accompany your journey. Life in this game means little and you'll find yourself restarting lots. But don't get discouraged...because the restart button is part of the gameplay itself: you kill kill kill and die die die. There is a rhythm involved and it's what makes the game ever so obsessively addicting. But unlike addiction, you are rewarded progression for breaking the pattern you find yourself stuck in...the pattern that keeps getting you killed. In fact, it is dying that makes you want to take a risk and attempt something risky! And when you finally pull it off right, you feel like the king of the world! So go ahead, brave warriors, don't be afraid to restart or change up your ways, since this game will always have a road open to victory.

reviewText:
Sequel to the original, wildly popular Hotline Miami, Hotline Miami 2 seeks to fill in some of the gaps in the original's story and show some of its impacts.

Gameplay is pretty par for course by Hotline standards. Quick, rapid paced, and brutally violent and unfair, where success comes through a combination of luck, dexterity, and just a bit of clairvoyance. Differences are in the details. Unlike the first game, Hotline Miami 2 follows several independent, yet intertwined storylines, each with a small selection of masks and abilities. In each level, only those in the active storyline have masks that can be used, as opposed to the original, where any mask, once unlocked, could be used in any level. Some new mask abilities include having two characters, one melee with one button and one shooting with another, to dual-wielding submachine guns and dodge rolling.

The weapon selection has expanded from the previous game to include a host of silenced weapons, SMGs, assualt rifles, and pistols. Melee weapon variety has been greatly decreased, being reduced, for the most part, to pipes, golf clubs, and knives.

While the game play and music remain enviously good, the story aspect has suffered a bit. The lack of a single protagonist and the rapid jumping between storylines is, at times, confusing, and often the wild rampages seem a bit out of place. For many such rampages the reasons behind boil down to 'just because', something I'm kind of on the fence about as to whether it aids character development or is an excuse for more violence.

As in the first game, Hotline Miami 2's protagonists all invariably suffer due to their actions, leading to one hell of a finale. All in all, the game isn't bad at all. It's a bit rough around the edges at parts and can be brain-crushingly frustrating at others, but it's still fun and remains king of the kind of violence only Hotline Miami can do.

reviewText: While staying just as violent as the original, this addition seems to have a more meloncholy vibe. Yes there is still the fast music and the punishing combat, but all the anger of the original is gone and replaced by a mellow sadness. The cutscenes play slower more calming music, the narritive is more clear and focused. Every character in this game seems troubled, but unlike Jacket, more defeated than enraged. The combat, while it still keeps your pulse up, trys to be more strategic. Many users have complained about the designers use of windows, but i enjoy it. They aren't giving you what you want, they want to keep things unfair. I found myself planning my attacks more precisely than the first and i felt much more rewarded. The gameplay is still mostly unchanged, aside from the smaller collection of masks. Each mask is much more gameplay changing than any mask in the original game. The fans kept me entertained right up until their unfortunate demise. Overall what really defines this game is the music and storytelling. The combat is excellent as would be expected, but the music has much more diversity and style than the original. The soundtrack goes perfectly with the story to make moments feel more emotional. I found myself genuinely invested in the characters, hating some with my whole heart and loving others to death. In the end there is no happy ending. This world of death and violence simply cannot get one, perhaps it doesnt deserve one. However there is peace to the ending. The violence is over, the rush has faded, and like a long, hypnotic fever dream, it fades away. Goodbye Miami, your neon lights are gone for good, did you ever really find peace? (I was stoned when i made this review, but i like it so screw off)
